I guess it shouldn't come as a surprise that keeping up with good content is something that could last forever. But this is why shows end. How about putting this show down once and for all? It has outlived its course.

A new season and such horrible first episode, I don't think I will watch Simpsons anymore. It used to be great and funny tv show but since Disney bought it it gets worse and worse. Like they completely ran out of ideas.Life is too short for such boring unfunny nonsense.

The Simpsons, back in the early to mid 90's, was by far the greatest sitcom ever on TV. With strong jokes, humorous parodies, funny slapstick and wonderful plots it swept the nation by storm. For those who don't know, the Simpsons is about an American family called the Simpsons (hence the title) who live in the fictional town of Springfield. The father, Homer, is a beer bellied not so smart guy who works in the local nuclear power plant. His wife, Marge is a doting housewife and mother, and they have three kids, Bart, Lisa, and Maggie. This show, back over a decade ago, stood out for two reasons. One, it was an animated sitcom (which was based mostly on reality, fantasy elements shown in typical cartoons appeared briefly) and two, the Simpsons was a dysfunctional family, except the volume was turned way up. Back in the 90's sitcoms involved families who were a strong unit and cared for each other and all that stuff, but the Simpsons were constantly having problems and such, always getting back together in the end, which was the theme of the show and what kept it on top. The prime of the show would be, in my opinion, around 1993-1997 (or the third through the sixth season,) After that, the show began to lose humorous edge, and by the early 2000 period, the show really began to fall apart. It is now 2006, and with even worse episodes being churned out, the show probably should of called it quits by 97 or 98 when it showed signs of age.So what happened? The show is clearly different now then it was ten years ago but there seems to be a lot of little things that made the show go south. I noticed by the 11 or 12th season, the show started to include very ridiculous and crazy plots that would never happen in real life (and every celebrity on the planet would start to appear in every episode, one by one) Now before anybody flames me and says "It's a cartoon dumbass!" (I couldn't figure that out, thanks guys!) It is important to understand that in the prime of the show it had plots that were realistic, things that normal people could go through every day (Maybe it would go outside the barriers of reality, but only briefly) You could relate to the characters, and actually cared what happened to them. By the way, celebrates did appear in the past, but they were usually cameos or voiced characters, rather then playing themselves like now. But now that the plots and ideas are so nuts that I don't really care what the resolution will turn out to be. And now the celebrity guest will have a whole episode involving him, which really makes the show boring in my opinion. Another problem with the show is that the jokes simply aren't as funny or interesting anymore, and that is what really is hurting the show. The writers try hard to be funny, but fail miserably. But I believe the number one problem is the new personalities of the characters.Homer, back in the prime of the sitcom, was at times a big jerk who sometimes did things to advantage himself and hurt others, but in the end, he always did the right thing at the conclusion and he was a good guy overall. And although he wasn't a very bright man (His stupidity is one of the highlights of the show) He only had moments when he was a complete dumbass. But now the writers dummed down homer to look like a total retard, he has also evolved to be an unbearable jackass with no redeeming qualities whatsoever (and it seems like now he is spending every minute of every episode doing something incredibly stupid beyond sanity.) Bart used to be a mischievous kid who did get into trouble on occasion, but always knew his limits and acted like a typical ten year old kid. Now, he's more of a whiny brat who tries really hard to be a tough criminal. He also tries to act tough by bullying his nerdy friend Milhouse, whom in earlier seasons, had a good friendship with Bart and he saw Milhouse as an equal and not his flunkie like today. Lisa was a very smart eight year old who had strong beliefs over issues but really tried to live a normal life as an eight year old, but now is a intolerant PC hippie who believes her views are superior to anyone elses. And Marge, well, shes still the housewife, but she seems to care less nowadays and will sometimes try way to hard to be "cool" and "hip" but always failing to be funny. Maggie is the one who changed the least, but shes only one year old, so you can't expect much. The side characters (Moe, Mr. Flanders, etc) also seemed to change as well, though for the worse.Finally, the Simpsons was the greatest sitcom back in the heyday, but now is crumbling like a wall. I stopped watching the show a few years ago because I just couldn't take the declining quality anymore. The bad plots, poor jokes and repackaged personalities of the characters are beginning to cause the show's decay. I won't dismiss the show's past accomplishments, but the new episodes are downright unbearable. I recommend the show, but get the seasons three to six, you'll laugh out loud. The first two seasons are good, but didn't get that edge just yet. Anything later then 1997 I wouldn't watch, but like a wise man said, "Opinions are like assholes, everybody has one" So see it for yourself and make up your own judgment.

The Simpsons first aired in December of 1989. With that first episode in which Bart Simpsons gets a tattoo for Christmas and scandalizes his family, the antics of this functionally dysfunctional family was established. The voices behind the characters are Dan Castellaneta, Julie Kavner, Nancy Cartwright, Yeardley Smith, Hank Azaria, Tress Mcneille and many others. The Simpsons has enjoyed huge success. For 16 years, seasons, and more than 200 episodes, they are still the funniest and smartest cartoon on TV. If you take a good close look, you will see that the Simpsons are witty and clever social satire on today's society. It's really a cartoon adults can enjoy as well.Homer Simpson is a man who is not afraid to embrace his primitive instincts. He is a boorish, drinks beer at Moe's often, is bald and fat at first glance represents the working class in America. But he is a loving father and has managed to pitch in on his side of the parenting as much as the more mature and wise Marge Simpson, despite the fact that Homer could be lazy. Marge Simpson can be annoying only because she's too level-headed and too cautious. Lisa Simpson stands out because she's bright, sensitive, intellectual and cultured. She is a liberal at heart and actively participates in environment protection, animal rights and is a vegetarian Buddhist. Bart Simpson is a brat with a heart of gold, who despite his wild child nature, has his moments. There are too many episodes that are among my favorite- Bart dates the scheming and bad Reverend Lovejoy's daughter, Homer becomes morbidly obese to get on disability and work from home, Homer nearly cheats on Marge twice (with Country singer Lurlene Lumpkin and Mindy Simmons who is a female version of himself) Lisa gets a crush on a Jewish substitute teacher and then must learn to deal with his parting, Bart and his friends battle it out with rival Shelbyville boys over a stolen lemon tree, the Burlesque House, Marge and Homer explore their sexual relationship through risky sex in public, any episode with Flanders as the focus, the classic episodes from the 90's- Who Shot Mr. Burns ? Lisa gets her first experience with competition when a smarter girl shows up, Homer and Flanders go to Vegas and accidentally get married, all the Halloween episodes "Tree House of Horror series" and many others. Among the more colorful characters in Springfield are the evil and hundred plus millionaire, power plant owner Montgomery Burns, his closeted gay assistant Whelan Smithers, bullies Nelson and Jimbo, hilarious Police Chief Wiggums and his son Ralph, Sideshow Bob and Sideshow Mel.. Krusty the Clown, Apu, his wife Manjula and their eight kids. Many celebrates have appeared on the series over the years among them Mel Gibson, Elizabeth Taylor, Butch Patrick, James Woods, Michelle Pfeiffer, Helen Hunt, Lucy Lawless, Frankie Muniz and many others.

Way before most of you might remember, The Simpson's was just a little short that aired in small snippets throughout each episode of The Tracy Ullman Show. That's when my brothers and I began to watch and we were hooked. It was a genius part of our childhood showcasing some of the quirkiest characters, hilarious humor, and brilliant writing.What ruined it? The show became politically correct; it's producer & writers began pandering to sanctimonious whiners who complained that Abu was offensive. Instead of taking a stand and saying 'If you don't like it, don't watch it,' the weak and perhaps self righteous writers cowed to a millennial mindset that suggests the world censor its content to appease their entitled mentality.So The Simpson's caved with no regard for the opinions of those who'd been with them from the beginning. Viewers like myself who'd watched for decades, were disgusted and the choice to pander to bullies instead of having the integrity to stand by characters they had created.

Yet again, Disney ruin something which was once brilliant. I used to watch The Simpsons and always had laughs at the gags and character exploits: not anymore. Why do they have so many musical numbers and Woke storylines? Dull and uninspiring writing now. Not for me. I don't watch it anymore.

SpoilersThe Simpsons was one of the greatest cartoon shows alive.  I loved this series.  It was funny.  But things have changed.  And to see how much has changed, let me review the series.Season 1:  Somewhat mixed season, but still good(loved it when Homer was mistaken for Bigfoot).  Season 2-3:  Is now starting to find the direction of the series, and its characters.  The animation is also now finding itself.  Also, the series is now on Thursdays.  Seasons 4-5:  Hilarious. The Simpsons has finally struck gold.  These have to be the best in the series(especially season 4).  Seasons 6-7:  Moves back to Sundays.  Still good to watch, even if the "pure magic," isn't as light as it was during the previous seasons.  Seasons 8-9:  Good, but starting to drag down.  Some weak episodes in both seasons.  Seasons 10-11:  A bit better.  Some really good laughs here, although still a weak episode or two.  Season 12:  Mixed.  Some episodes were hilarious(like Trilogy of Error), but others were an embarassment(like the Boy Band episode).  Season 13:  Only a handful of good episodes.  It's obvious the series is losing a lot of steam.  Season 14:  An insult.  The humor is gone, and the characters are now caricatures of their former hilarious selves.  What happened to the good old Homer of yesterday? Season 15:  Okay, the new season won't start for a few weeks, but from what I've read, it's obvious that the writers are running out of ideas for the series, as it will involve the return of old characters from the show, like Mother Simpson, or Rabbi Krustofski.  Not a good sign.This show used to be the best, but it's going down fast.  FOX, hire some new writers, or pull the old ones to put down one amazing finale, but whatever you do, don't let this end on a bad note!BOTTOM LINE:  Skip the current stuff.  The original classics are the ones worth viewing.

This has to be one of the best darn cartoons/comedies ever to grace the T.V screen. The fact that it has been going for nearly 10 years says it all. The comic timing is just right and the jokes are so funny that you're guaranteed to be begging for more! The reason why the show works so well is not because of just the family,no. The minor characters are spot on and they will have you rolling around the floor in fits of laughter more often than Homer, Marge and co. Mr Burns is THE best person on the show in my opinion. People often say that Matt Groening is a genius after every time they watch a show. Okay, I give credit to Matt due to him making up the Simpsons but it is the massive crew which make the Simpsons what it is today. It is the dozen or so writers that give us the dialogue which is unbeatable by any other programme. ( a big cheer to my fave writer John Swartzwelder is in order here!). It is the many gifted animators which give us the many hilarious moments on the show. Without these people and the rest of the crew there would be no Simpsons. Also, another key element in it being enjoyable is the cast. The many talented actors who supply their great voices. (Another big cheer for my favourite voicer Harry "Handsome" Shearer.He is my Hero!) Anyhoo, enough is being said. Just don't forget all the crew and praise them as well as Matt Groening. Simpsons Forever!

And thats because it's very, very funny. The first series of The Simpsons, first aired all those years ago when I was an elementary school student myself, were very child-like, both in animation and script, and as the show gained momentum and subsequent seasons made it more and more of a success, the subject matter got more serious, but it retained what it always had from the beginning: a unique wit for pointing out the idiosyncrasies of the real world.By around season 5, the writers had build up an entire world, based around the fictional town of Springfield. Not only that, but all these characters had their own relationships with each other, that remained consistent and believable. The central characters are the Simpson family themselves. Parents Homer and Marge, kids Bart, Lisa and Maggie, their cat and dog, then the extended family: Grumpy grandpa Simpson, who can keep people distracted for hours by telling stories that go nowhere. Marge's unmarried, chain-smoking twin sisters Patty and Selma who live with their pet lizard and despise Homer, then there's all the other characters: next-door-neighbors The Flanders who are so religious only a cartoon could convey it. The staff and students of Bart and Lisa's school, Homer's co-workers and co-drinkers, Krusty the Klown, the TV clown who Bart worships, Police chief Wiggum who is so lazy he believes that people should "take the law into their own hands", sleazy bartender Moe, Apu, Reverend Lovejoy, Mr. Burns Homer's miserly boss as well as other interesting characters introduced in later seasons, such as Gil, the hapless loser who's wife has left him and seems to lose every job he gets. And brilliant once-off characters such as Hank Scorpio, The evil head of Globex corporation, who, it could be argued, is a rip-off of a James Bond villain. But that argument is quickly settled by the fact that no James Bond villain has ever been this funny, or indeed, evil. I could go on and on about these characters, but I won't, because if you've never seen the show I wouldn't dare spoil it for you.Now in it's nineteenth season, with the long-awaited feature-length movie about to hit movie screens, I believe The Simpsons has had an incredible run. Its not nearly as funny as it used to be and hence not as popular, and I feel it's substituting very dark undertones where it used to have clever and funny jokes. I don't like this and I think The Show has given us enough laughs for the last 20 years to easily last another 20. I still don't tire of the old shows and there's so many of them the by the time you've sat through them all you've forgotten the first ones. Whether they decide to wrap it up in the next year or so, or if it Rolling Stones approach of going on and on way past its sell-by date, one thing is imminent: The Simpsons will not be forgotten.

I don't really know what I can say about it. Everyone should have seen this and if you haven't seen it.... watch it now. Seriously. It may be the most quotable show ever. Of course when you have a show that goes on for that long, you can't really develop the main characters much, or you may run the risk of jumping the shark in the eyes of some. But luckily there are many secondary characters who have been able to have some changes made to them if only for a little while, for example Ned Flanders, Barney Gumble and Apu Nahasapeemapetilon. (wow... I love the show so much I was actually able to spell that right.)I honestly don't see it possible for someone to have no love for the Simpsons. Really.The Simpsons can be seen as a breakthrough in prime time television... opening up the world to a more adult form of animation, paving the way to many other shows, such as King of the Hill, South Park and Family Guy. I believe that without this show, it is possible that none of these would exist.I would like to take some time to talk about the characters now. I'll start with Homer, who is a lovable oaf who is just impossible not to like, especially since he always comes through in the end, even though it's clear that he never quite learns his lesson. In more recent seasons he has become a bit more obnoxious, but it is made clear that he is not a bad person, just not very smart. Bart is the bratty 10 year old who actually has a really big heart. The series shows that he is more than just a little pest and that he is willing to go the extra mile to do the right thing. Lisa is the child genius who just wants to make the world a better place. Marge is the housewife who loves her children and her husband with all her heart. And Maggie... she loves her pacifier. Not forgetting Abe Simpson, Homer's senile father who loves to tell stories of the old days. Unfourunately for him, very few of the stories actually make sense.So far there have been more than 400 episodes, and I have watched almost all of them. Most of them I've seen many times. Many of the episode focus on the relationships between the family members. For example Life on the Fast Lane focuses on the relationship between Homer and Marge, Lisa on Ice focuses on Bart and Lisa, Grampa vs. Sexual Inadequacy focuses on Homer and Abe, and Make Room For Lisa focuses on Homer and Lisa. These are just a few examples of many.The show offers a lot of heart, especially considering it is an animated comedy. Episodes like Moaning Lisa, A Streetcar Named Marge and Bart vs. Thanksgiving are just some of the examples of the great and heartfelt writing that went into many episodes of The Simpsons. And I don't think that heart is gone. We saw some good examples of it in the movie, Marge's Son Poisoning was nice, and I thought Regarding Margie was a sweet episode. (In the literal sense.)This is the show that has always been there for me. It started in 1989, which was the year I was born. And I've watched it for as long as I can remember.I can admit the show isn't as perfect now as it was years ago, but I hardly think it is as bad as people make it out to be. The comparison between early Simpsons and current Simpsons is not really a fair one, as how how can you compare stuff to something that was at the level the early episodes were at. I feel that if they were showing the newer episodes back in 1990, people still would have been hooked. That's just my opinion though.It could always rely on it to make me laugh when things were rough. Even if I'd seen the episode a million times before. I don't care what people think, I still love the show. And that includes the new episodes. It has its faults but it still constantly makes me laugh. I can't thank this show enough for helping me get through rough times with its humour. I will always be a fan. I hope it stays around to entertain me for many years to come.10/10 Every time.
The old episodes were so good but in season 12 it began to get worse.
But before that it was wonderful watch the first 10 seasons and don't watch the rest.

Since the talented voice cast has remained the same low these many years, I put all the blame on this squarely with the Fox network who refused to let this show go out gracefully when Groening siphoned off his role to work on his dream project, the now far superior 'Futurama'. In Fox's race to claim this endurance record they have turned a once edgy and visionary show into an institution with an assembly line production and revolving door of writers to match any of the other lame shows on TV. Behind the scenes, maybe the condescending we-can-do-no-wrong attitude of Maxton-Graham has dealt the show its biggest death blow, while producer Mike Scully sat back and ineptly let Maxton-Graham run it into the ground. In the end, the biggest blame may actually land with the "die-hard fans" that embolden the show by letting it get away with this junk. Yes, "The Simpsons" was ground-breaking and every adult animation in the future owns it a bit of gratitude, but blind loyalty to a show only for how it performed in the past isn't healthy. Since it has hit long-running status the critical bandwagon jumping has begun and "Simpsons" is more popular than ever amongst critics that want to be on the inside of history. We've now reached a point where the bad episodes and bad entire seasons outweigh the good and that, I'm afraid, is going to be the sad legacy of "Simpsons" . A train-wreck of crass, childish humor, grainy animation, oddly misplaced satire and forced parodies of only the most obvious pop culture targets. 10 years ago I didn't know what I would do without "The Simpsons" but now, particularly with the emergence of satisfying new adult animated shows ('Futurama', 'Family Guy' and 'South Park'), living without it might be pretty good.

Yes, I thought The Flintstones was great, but The Simpsons is by FAR the best animated show on TV, and with few exceptions--The BEST PERIOD!!! I didn't jump on until midway through the second season, but I've been a die-hard-foam at the mouth Simpsons fan ever since. I go into withdrawal if I don't get my Simpsons fix every day. And Thank goodness for DVD, so when the show does fold or people get too greedy (as those Hollyweird folks tend to do), we'll have it forever! It's irreverent, rude, and just plain funny! It offends just about everybody, but I haven't seen any group complain. And look at the celebrities that seem to be waiting in line to do a cameo. One thing, Simpsons producers... Get the Treehouse of Horrors episodes on their own DVD set - Christmas too! It'll sell--Trust me! THE SIMPSONS FORVER!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Let's face it, the Simpsons popularity has grown over the last twenty years ever since it made it's debut on the Tracey Ullman Show. Unfortunately that show ended but this show has thrived with some of the cast mates like Julie Kavner and Dan Castellnata as Marge and Homer Simpson. Being an animated show has it's advantages though, gone are those silly actors and actresses because you only need voices. The show works because of the powers behind the show's success. Maggie is still a baby, Bart is still a brat, and Lisa is well the middle child who is smart. The fact that the producers decided to maintain the characters in the same age for 20 years is an achievement in itself. In live sitcoms, the children age and stories change and attention shifts from one character to another. There are episodes that are good and plentiful. They have done everything from Shakespeare to Edgar Allen Poe. I don't know how long this show will run but as long as the audience wants more. They'll be happy to comply.

Now you are probably what I meant by that huh? And you also probably wonder what "The Simpsons" and "Ren and Stimpy" have in common, huh? Well here, let me tell you:Well, both were funny shows once, even funny when being gross, offensive or shocking at times. But now, both the shows are so disgusting, shocking and offensive, it is not even funny anymore. Bart becoming alcoholic (What hypocrites! Adult alcoholics aren't funny, but child alcoholics are? WTF)? Marge getting implants and becoming an exotic centerfold? Lisa joing a band of Vegan Hippies? Homer becoming an internet marketer? YES, I know it is a cartoon, but the plots are getting stupider, whether they are in animated form or not.I remember the show used to be funny, the characters used to be believable and the balance of everyday realism and surrealistic fantasy. Now this show has gone out of its mind.Sorry to say, the Simpsons have done everything possible now and Matt Groening should own the rights to the show back and end it for good.OR Groening shoul make spin-off shows on the more interesting characters in the show and work on new and interesting projects.

Probably one of the best programes on t.v. . The voices , animation are all perfect . After nearly 10 years it may be starting to show signs of ageing , but  it's still up there . It's the voices , especially of Homer , that just sets it apart . If you're not a fan of the Simpsons then you're crazy .Essential viewing .

Like so many other great shows ("Rugrats", "All That", etc.), this show continues to get worse and worse as it barrels along.  "The Simpsons" should've stopped by the end of the 2000-2001 season.  You know, when they were still somewhat funny."The Simpsons", a spin-off of the "Tracy Ullman Show", started out as an overly dramatic, crudely-drawn show that was at best decent in the first season.  By the next season, however, it was clear the show was on the rise. In season three, it reached its creative peak, with such classic episodes as "Lisa the Greek", "Flaming Moe's", "Bart the Murderer", "Separate Vocations", and "Homer Defined" (probably THE best Homer episode).  The last great season, in the true sense of the word, was Season 7 (1995-96), ending with the classic "Summer of 4 Ft. 2" (in case you didn't notice, I used to be a huge Lisa fan).Season 8 was a standard season: many classics and quasi-classics, almost completely good.  But Season 9 was the sign that things were on their way down.  There were a few funny episodes ("Lisa the Simpson", "Realty Bites", "Girly Edition", "The Joy of Sect", and "The City of New York vs. Homer Simpson"), but as the show went, it was a mediocre season.
Even after last year's travesty of a season, Season 10 remains the worst season.  Phil Hartman died: that affected the show more than it would appear, because, obviously, his characters, down-and-out movie star Troy McClure and corrupt attorney Lionel Hutz, were extremely hilarious. At first, it  didn't appear that these characters were a necessity (though of course they were missed), but the show lost some of its satirical and even just plain regular humorous edge. As if that weren't bad enough, such God-awful episodes as "Bart the Mother" (Hartman's last episode), "Trash of the Titans", "Maximum Homerdrive" (I laughed maybe three times throughout the duration of that episode), "Monty Can't Buy Me Love", "The Old Man And the 'C' Student", "Mom and Pop Art", and "They Saved Lisa's Brain" (until this season, the worst, and only crappy-with-not-a-single-redeeming-feature-what-so-ever) were churned out. Homer had become an unbearable jack@ss; Lisa was an intolerant, tree-hugging, PC b**ch; Bart was completely out of character (apparently the creators want to spend more time hammering home the "Bart may be gay" subplot that prevails throughout many episodes of late); and Marge, well, she didn't really care anymore.  Most of the supporting characters stayed in character, but since the show focuses on the Simpsons themselves, we (or at least I) CANNOT forgive them.  The guest stars were wasted worse than ever (save Isabella Rossalini, who for her part did the best she could with the material, and Lisa Kudrow, who I'm not particularly fond of anyway), and their appearances were pointless (eg. "When You Dish Upon A Star", with Alec Baldwin, Kim Bassinger, AND Ron Howard [I know Bassinger and Baldwin are married, but what the hell was Howard doing there, save the "Happy Days" joke at the end?]).  Plots were recycled and overused (Homer gets a new job, they go on vacation, etc.), and the show relied too much on sight gags (a flaw that first became apparent in Season 6 and only continues to get worse).  And just out of curiosity, WHY does everyone seem to think that "Simpsons Bible Stories" is one of the greatest episodes ever?  "Thirty Minutes Over Tokyo" was hilarious (though not classic), esp. the end with Godzilla and friends, but obviously it couldn't save the season.Season 11, for the most the part, got back into the swing of things. Again, save the sight gag problem, the episodes were hilarious, such as "Beyond Blunderdome" (the one with Mel Gibson), "Pygmolian" (Moe's my favorite character, so I pretty much have to like it, given the relative scarcity of Moe episodes), the one with Bart on drugs (forget what it was called), "Last Tap Dance In Springfield", "Bart to the Future" and the finale, "Behind the Laughter", a somewhat self-depricating parody of "Behind the Music".  There were some episodes I wasn't thrilled about ("Hello Gutter, Hello Fadder", "Eight Misbehavin'", and "Kill The Gator And Run" sucked out loud), but most of the season was very good.Season 12 was a minorly substandard but still quite hilarious one.  Again, gross-out gags and sight gags notwithstanding, this was almost as good as the previous (though hardly classic), with such episodes as the great Halloween one, the one with the Party Posse (actually my favorite episode all-time), the one when Bart, Homer, and Grandpa pull all the heists/jokes, and "Simpsons Tall Tales".  Of course, there were crappy ones: "Bye Bye Nerdy", which I actually liked until the cop-out ending, another standard Simpsons problem, "Lisa the Tree-Hugger", another episode reinforcing the self-centered PC hippy brat that my once-favorite Simpson has become, and, of course, "Simpson Safari".  HOW is rhinos hatching out of eggs, Greenpeace being evil (which they might be, but here in a different way), an evil Jane Goodall wannabe who has lots of pearls (what does this have to do with the plot in anyway?), inside-out mosquito nets, hippos afraid of water, and other needless absurdities and reversals of fact funny?  It appears the show has now degenerated to pleasing younger (and, in some cases, MUCH YOUNGER) fans. The finale, "Simpsons Tall Tales", made the season a mostly good one overall.Now, Season 13 is here and sucks louder than the Barisal Guns, blows harder than a hurricane, bites harder than a hyena, shark, and pitbull combined, and eats more than a shrew.  The first two episodes of the season were decent, but "Homer the Moe" was the worst episode ever.  It wasn't funny in the first place, the hunting scene was another stupid sight gag gone awry (not like it would've been good anyway), and the end with the vegetarian turkey or whatever the hell that was is as funny as being shot in the face while having your heart scraped out with a spoon and your testicles each having a white-hot poker sticking through them with a shovel tearing your stomach out.  YES, IT'S THAT BAD!So I'm through with "The Simpsons".  I might check out the next season just for the heck of it, but I sincerely hope it ends soon.Only watch the classics (Seasons 1-8).
Talking about beating a dead horse. Just end it already.

I absolutely love this show. It's one of my all-time favorite TV shows. Ever. It's so funny, and it keeps getting better and better. There is a reason why it has been going for twenty-six years and why it's recently been renewed for Season 27 and Season 28. Because it's freaking awesome. I'm not going to go through the trouble of listing my favorite seasons from best to worst because there is too many. So I'll just say my Top 5 seasons. Season 14, Season 15, Season 16, Season 17 and Season 18. I wonder why I like the middle so much. My favorite character is definitely Homer. He is just hilarious. I think he is so funny and so entertaining. It is weird to think that if it was a normal show, where the characters age, Bart would be almost forty years old. That's super weird.This cartoon show centers around the Simpson family. Homer, Marge and their three children, Bart, Lisa and Maggie, go through so much stuff and go on so many adventures. Overall, I give this TV show a 10 out of 10, which in my ratings book is: Freaking Ridonkulous.

The Simpsons started off great and went strong until around their movie and outside the Treehouse of Horrors episodes has been average at best since.I get it, the show has been around forever and ideas are drying up. What used to be crazy at times is now perpetually safe. No boundaries are being pushed and half the time episodes feel like lectures instead of entertainment. It has become boring, and that's about the best thing to say about the current episodes.

OK so many say that this show is slowing loosing it's luster. I beg to differ slightly. Family Guy seems to be the "in thing" right now and though I love that show as well, The Simpsons is still the hierarchy or animated television. This show can be enjoyed by all races, religions, and ethnicities alike. It's not as racy as the aforementioned competition but still just as (if not more) funny. Things do tend to wear over time and people's likes/dislikes tend to change. I've enjoyed every episode from the first one up until the current ones. The competition does touch topics that, if this show would touch, it would be kind of tasteless. I'll be a fan up until the last and final episode. Nothing has really changed except for people's opinions. Along with Seinfeld, Martin, and Married With Children, The Simpsons is and always will be a most noteworthy sitcom in t.v. history. That is All!!!

With all my collection of video tapes and d.v.d.s I seem to find myself digging through my Simpsons box, when I need something to watch. It would be hard to pick a favorite episode, because of so many. It would be even harder to pick a least favorite because there is very few that could be less appealing. But boring is one thing that the Simpsons could never be considered. The writers have changed ideas, episode structure, and kept the Simpsons on a continuous exciting adventure. Anytime of the day or no matter what seems to be the mood , the Simpsons is always satisfying to to view even over and over and hours on end.

The Simpsons, which first broadcast as a half-an-hour TV show over twenty years ago, was at first a TV show everyone loved (though i can't say that with true honesty since I wasn't born then, but I have seen the older episodes and they're amazing, and my mum and dad loved it back then). Almost all of the jokes were 100% original and it was the funniest show on air (according to my dad). But the newer ones... are just painful to watch. Groening is rapidly running out of ideas, and now it's showing.I have the seasons 1-13 at home, and have watched seasons 20+ on the TV. I love every single episode from seasons 1-11, but when I first watched the twelfth on DVD, I was thoroughly disappointed. I only enjoyed a few of them. In hope, I bought season 13 on DVD, but that proved to be worse. I haven't bought one since. I didn't want to pay for something that isn't worth watching. I watched an episode on Sky, which I believed was season 23. I didn't even crack a smile. This is why the series - originally awesome - gets only a slightly respectable 8, rather than the 10+ the original episodes deserveI don't know when & how the series will end, but I hope it happens soon before even the long-time/die-hard fans start to realise the series is going no-where
No one watches this garbage anymore, like why is it still on

For its first nine or ten years, The Simpsons defined great television. It was the ultimate series. The family was slightly dysfunctional, the plots could be twisted, but down deep you knew the characters actually cared about each other and you knew it was an excellent portrait of the struggles of a middle class family under the oppressive regime of the rich and powerful (and hilarious) Mr. Burns. Each of the five main Simpson characters were strong and valuable.I highly recommend the series (as if anyone isn't already aware of it) for its first few years. The rest went downhill and became less intelligent and enjoyable, but the series it started out as is some of the best TV you can find. Indeed, I thought it was the best comedy TV until I found Arrested Development, which is the classic Simpsons amplified in all aspects.

That's right. Better than "Seinfeld", better than "Cheers" better than anything out there in years. Forget that it's a cartoon. The writing is superb, the comdey is hilarious and BEST of all... It is often not expected! I can not count the times I have had near disasters while drinking a beverage during the show. For me the musical numbers are the best part. The "Sherry Bobbins" (Mary Poppins) episode is classic viewing! The laughs originate in left field and settle in your chest, to the point of painful laughter. No other TV comedy can come close to this effect week after week. While the characters may be 2 dimensional, their depth is equal to that of humans. They have become part of our society and part of our life. We identify with them! Bravo to the Simpsons and all the wonderful actors and actresses who for so long have made us laugh!

I'm sorry but I'm pretty sure it's common knowledge by now the show has been on a decline for years now, but at this point I believe there is more bad episodes than good with a lot of meh sprinkled in. Much like most great rockstars, the Simpsons should have died a long time ago.It's sad to see one of the greatest animated shows of all time become so tired and worn out.It's been slowly getting worse over the last 15 years but it's got to a point it's now complete unwatchable. Which as a life long fan I feel genuinely sad about.

Yes The Simpsons may be past its best but it still notches up more laughs per episode than any current American sitcom I have seen. The characters remain fresh and the writing is still great. Sadly the standards of those early seasons was so high that nothing can top it.The Simpsons have become part of American culture and they bring joy to so many people. Everyone has a favourite Simpsons moment and can recall a favourite line from Homer and that surely is the biggest compliment that can be paid to the series.I hope this series continues to be enjoyed and watched for many years to come.

I love the Simpsons. I think every single person in my whole entire family just adores the Simpsons. My favorite episode in the Simpsons is King-Size Homer. My favorite character is Dr. Nick Riveria.The Simpsons is one of the few cartoons in which someone actually dies. Maude dies, Bleeding Gums Murphy dies, and Hans Moleman constantly dies. Moleman is a peanut like man that always has mishaps and always dies. It is impossible not to love poor little Hans Moleman.The Simpsons is about a family that lives in Springfield that constantly have realistic adventures and plot twists. The family members are named Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa, Maggie, and Grampa Simpson. There are actually some emotional and heartwarming episodes. The Simpsons is also one of the few cartoons that actually have sad endings. Mother Simpson has a sad ending.The Simpsons is probably the funniest cartoon ever. Seasons 3 to around 8 are the golden years! (My opinion) 10/10 there just classics and funny still today. But with all these recent episodes I must give the show at most, a six. The writing is no where near as funny as It used to be, the characters have changed to much and sometimes there doesn't seem to have a b story, and I love the B stories! But the most tragic thing is the animation, it has got so incredibly boring and robotic there is no life and no matter how "clean" it looks it just does not look right. I never thought I would want this show to end but I really couldn't care anymore It's starting to overstay it's welcome, I could watch old repeats all day but the show has lost it's touch.

The Simpsons has always been true TV brilliance.  Everything about it is remarkable: the art, the characters, the voicing, the humor, the story, and the satire.  The show pokes fun at all of society's sacred cows, leaving no stone unturned, which partially explains its enormous popularity.  Without a doubt, the shows best character has always been Homer Simpson, the loveable goof and head of the Simpson household.  Many irate fans have noted that Homer's increasingly stupid behavior hsa led the series down a path of ridiculousness.  True, the stories are more ludicrous than ever, but the show is every bit as fun as it was back in its heyday (season 7 and 8).  As a matter of fact, season 12 may very well have been my favorite season, period.  Season 13 featured one of The Simpsons' most hilarious episodes, entitled "Hunka hunka Burns in love."  Admittedly, season 14 hasn't been particularly good, with the only standout episode being the Halloween special, but the show is still entertaining and nothing else on TV approaches its scathing brilliance.

Kowabunga!! The characters are all classics on this show. What this show does so well when you watch it a lot is defines it's characters sharply & throw in so much comedy that the throw away lines are even great. When you watch this enough & think Bart, Homer, Marge, Lisa, Maggie, Moe, Crusty the Clown, Montgomery Burns, & Abu (among others), you get a mental picture of the character & sometimes see people in your real life who resemble them. Some of the resemblance is deliberate when you consider Matt Gronig's mind. Some of it is happen stance.Regardless, the show will always have its critics because it does shoot from the hip & hit raw nerves about almost any subject. In truth, it is that edge that makes it great. It takes any topic & lampoons it. It recreates great scenes from past TV & movies & lampoons them. Nothing is sacred on the Simpons. That's Funny!!!

In 1989, The Simpsons came into FULL existence with their first season ever and since then, through the 90's, We were introduced to Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa and Maggie Simpson who were so god damn interesting! Each character we got introduced to were so interesting to see, Moe and Barney along with Karl and Lenny, Kent and Patty and Selma... UGH! I can't deny but say I loved each and every single character except for Marty. A fair few Simpsons Episodes were highly enjoyable and entertaining. I'm going to pick some of my personal favorite episodes which are... Summer of 4ft. 2, The Springfield files, Homerpalooza, "HOW 90's could you get with an episode like that!!!???!?!?!, they had the Smashing Pumpkins in for voice acting and Sonic youth along with cypress hill.... OH MY GOD!!!! If they did this episode any earlier around, 1992 or 1993, they would of been able to have Kurt Cobain in the episode... But, We can only dream..." ALSO DID YOU KNOW, Sonic Youth threatened not to be in the episode if Courtney Love was cast in it? Now you do. Homer the heretic, Homer the Moe, The Mysterious voyage of our Homer, Hurricane Neddy, Lisa's date with density, A Milhouse divided, And many more...I believe season 21 is where things started to feel more drained, they weren't that funny and I can only stumble across 1 or 2 episodes that I might like each season...I'm sorry but I just don't like season 21 and the other seasons that came after it...I just think they're getting desperate to stay irrelevant... I'm more of a fan of seasons 2 through 20 than I am season 21 and onwards.You see, I grew up watching the Simpsons; I would sit at the dinner table watching the Simpsons as it came on at 6pm every night on channel 10 here in Australia. Such good times! Classic episodes and wonderful memories! Each and every single time I watch these older episodes, I get a strong flow of Nostalgia! I highly recommend watching seasons 1 through 20, 9/10

Who don't know who are Simpsons? the Simpsons are one of most influential TV shows ever made and the longest broadcasting animation on TV. Nowadays they have 17. series and over 370 episodes..that is two times more than Flinstones (the 2nd longest cartoon show) Simpsons have started as a part of Tracy Ullman Show.after that creator of Simpsons, Matt Groening, has got his own time and he made first twenty minutes long Simpsons.through years character of Simpson figure have changed, but the typical sense of humor has never changed..Homer is choleric with chimpanzee IQ, Marge always push around, Bart makes always mischief, Lisa is very intelligent a this is problem for she and Maggie has never said a word..And all this and many more makes the Simpsons a legend..What is more there is something that Simpsons overstep others cartoons..Simpsons are the only show (not only cartoon but all) that is broadcast in prime time over 15 YEARS!!

I was a 15-year old when the show came out in 1989 for a pilot. As it was from the Tracey Ullman Show in 1986 I think. As the show has been on for over twenty years and it will be sad when it is canceled just IF it is! As the family from you know where led by Homer Simpson as he means well but can really come off really a jerk. Though with a heart of gold. His straight man like wife Marge, hardworking homemaker who tries to keep the peace but fails.As Bart the underachiever oldest of the three, may go down that path. Lisa is the brilliant genius and makes straight As. And is on the verge of being first female President perhaps. And Maggie the cute sucking pacifier baby who shows signs of genius as well.But they are so dysfunctional that they are so laughable. That is what makes them like a family of ours. I fear for The Simpsons Movie. It's either going to be great or be cr*p - there's no in-between. There is little denying that the show has started to take a tumble in recent years - the distinct Simpsons style of humour is getting weak, and though Matt Groening and co. can always cook up interesting new plots at will, the episodes are starting to fall in general quality and laugh-factor. One particular recent episode was very funny - I forget what it's called, but it delivered one classic quote from the Comic Book Guy who was speaking about Stan Lee - "His mind is not in mint condition!" (Was it Stan Lee? I'm not sure.) Though the animation is not hot in the 1989-91 episodes, those were the days when the Simpsons was fresh, new and something like nothing which had never hit screens before. But over 300 episodes later, the formula is starting to get tired, and though it's very enjoyable to watch, I'm fearful that The Simpsons Movie will be just bad and immature. But there is also a chance that it will be bloody brilliant, and I still give The Simpsons a 10 for the plain fact that it has completely changed TV and our modern world. 10/10

Simpsons did really pioneer tv, but nowadays it is just struggling to keep up. it is still a great show, but doesnt really stand out anymore. the characters are great and fleshed out at this point, and memerable. some funny jokes, but mostly the kind that will just make you blow air out of your nose.6/10: still good, bot not great (anymore)

Much can be said about Matt Groening's "The Simpsons", it paved the way for modern day adult animation with political comments mixed with absurd humor and traditional sitcom laughs. However, since the 1989 premiere, "The Simpsons"declining quality has been obvious. It's been happening slow and steadily and the reasons can be discussed. Perhaps has the time ran away from this classic show, with alternatives such as "Family Guy", "South Park", "Rick and Morty" and others, most of which are more raw and unexplicit, the place for "The Simpsons" might just have been taken. Nothing lasts forever, and while the vast majority of seasons has a good standard, this series should end before it spirals down further into the pit of irrelevancy.

I hate it that people who grew up with (and loved) The Simpsons have stopped watching it. You can't say that the quality has gone downhill if you aren't watching it.The early Simpsons seasons, yes, were amazing. They were iconic and they were a big part of our childhood. If you compare new episodes to what the Simpsons meant to you in the 90s, then of course it is not going to hold a candle to that. The Simpsons was ground breaking and made a huge impression on my generation (and a whole lot of other people). Are the new seasons as good as classic seasons? I wouldn't say that, but I also would argue that it is not fair to compare them.New Simpsons episodes are for the most part good. In the range between B and A/A+They are not the same as classic Simpsons and they are not all consistently the same quality, but I look forward to it every week and it rarely disappoints.It is comfort food TV. It had been on for most of my life and has been a constant staple. In my opinion, still the best show on television.

There once was a time, when i couldn't bare to miss a single episode from "The Simpson". That was sometimes in the mid 90's. Couple of years from that the jokes and episodes began to turn more and more forced and it all began to turn unfunny. Now I really don't have so much of a hurry to see the newest episodes, I won't mind if I miss the entirely or by half.It would be good time, actually it has been that for couple of years now, for the producers of the show to realize, that this cow has been milked empty. Time to make the great big bang and end the show while they have any viewers, who respect the show.Time to let Matt Groening go to create something funny (like new episodes for Futurama) for a change.Score: 3 out from 5.

I really love The Simpsons, the 90's episodes are the best. I really liked it going up to season 13 but it started going downhill. But it really started going downhill after its 20th anniversary. The early episodes are excellent. There's no doubt about it. Some of the best episodes include Lisa's First Word, A Streetcar Named Marge, Hurricane Neddy, Homer's Odyssey and of course the episodes with Sideshow Bob in them. They had lots of laughs, were very entertaining and if you had a bad day, they would lighten you up.After the tenth season, the quality started to decline. Although an episode originally aired in 2001, New Kids on the Blecch, I really enjoyed. Other episodes in seasons 11-13 I liked as well. But episodes in seasons 14-19 weren't as great. After its 20th anniversary, the series declined immensely. They had guest stars like Justin Bieber and Lady Gaga. Why!? The episodes from seasons 20 on aren't funny at all. The animation improved, that's the only thing good about it. I think it's time to wrap up the series altogether. It should have stopped after its 13th or 14th season.I don't like the newer episodes at all, but I love the 90's episodes and the episodes in the very early 2000's. I love The Simpsons truly so I'm going to give it a 10/10.

The world longest run in cartoon series. They might have done something absolutely right, to have the show run over 10 years and the viewer seem to getting more and more. This is <U+0085>The Simpsons.Set in the small town of Springfield, lives the family of five yellow people. Homer <U+0096> a wacky loving father, Marge <U+0096> super mom, Bart <U+0096> the wicked son, Lisa <U+0096> Nerd, and little Maggie <U+0096> still unable to walk.Each week the series provide us with some of the wackiest situation and unpredictable storyline. And that is what make this show so loving; especially with character of Homer and Bart. The series also have loads of guest star using the actual voice of that person making it always fresh and new.With now in its 15 season, The Simpsons has come a long way, and one could clearly see how the show have develop themselves including the style of drawing, humor, and the characters personality. Homer is now the icon of American dad, sloppy, drunk, wacko, but loving parent and husband. And Bart is now the symbol of mischief child with soft heart.Note: now that you see the present date episode, Season 1-3 now look really weird.Recommendation: I Love This Show, And Urge Other People To See It.Rating: 9/10 (Grade: A)

You can cancel "Games of Thrones" or "Family Guy" and nobody would care, but the heart of soul of Television is<U+0085> (clouds separating) The Simpsons.After three decades (can you believe it?), Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa, Maggie and all Springfield's townspeople went the distance, resisting criticism even from fans of the first hour. The show didn't let itself dictated by fans, a mistake most sitcoms do, but on the contrary, found the way to precede their own tastes and expectations. Of course, nothing will ever beat the magical 90's, a time were theSimpsonsinfluenced Pop Culture before Pop Culture would influence them, but you can't expect something that spans three decades not to evolve the slightest bit, format and style-wise.And it's a credit to Matt Groening, son of Homer Groening, not to just have come up with the simplest yet most ingenuous concept (something he put on the paper in less than thirty minutes in a waiting room, borrowing names from his own relatives), but to have made it last. And it lasted because it evolved, however unpleasant some changes were. Just take Walt Disney, the show's regular punching ball and check for yourself the differences between"Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" and "The Sword in the Stone",26 years later. Now, speaking from my experience, I had to wait till the mid-90's before watching the first episodes. So it was a late discovery, but I watched the show starting with the first seasons, and since I was raised by 80's sitcoms like"The Cosby Show", "Who's the Boss" or"Growing Pains", I loved to see an animated series that carried much more depth and realism than all these live-action programs combined. It was just, to use a hackneyed term, like watching your family in a mirror.Indeed, Bart was the bratty underachiever with a good conscience, Marge was the loving and hardworking housewife, Homer the well-meaning, sometimes idiotic, sometimes hot-tempered father and Lisa, the voice of reason. It was just fine, and I was cringing whenever something 'unrealistic' happened, Maggie sleeping with bears, an angry mob wanting to kill Bart after he decapitated Jebediah Springfield's statue, Homer spectacularly falling in the stairs in"Crepes of Wrath"or Bart's slavery in the same episode. I was thinking, can't they make an episode like"Moaning Lisa"for instance? Yeah right, "Moaning Lisa"!After Season 1, I hoped it would never get over the top and spoiled that trademark realism . Guess what happened after? The channel aired Season 5, so talk about a chronological leap, so many new characters from the Mayor to the Comic Book Guy, and so many ludicrous plots. I hated every single one of them, even the classic"Cape Fear" and the racks scene annoyed me like you can't imagine. I was done with the show. I feel ridiculous now, but the funny thing is that many comments on the Internet capsule expressed similar doubts, and it was years before the official "Pauper"s shark-jumping episode, a time deemed now as Golden Age. A few months after, I bumped into an episode of Season 2, and I thought it was surprisingly good: realistic, warm and funny with a little touch of zaniness. Season 2 is still my favorite season because it revived my love for the show, one that never faded, and it featured some of the most classic moments: "Bart the Daredevil"'s unforgettable climax, the Fugu episode, Homer meeting Marge, Bart crying after getting an F and my all-time favorite,"Lisa's Substitute"(Homer's finest hour at the end makes it one of the best twist endings of the series). Season 3 and 4 were, as Burns would say, excellent, and when the 5th season was re-run, I finally enjoyed the episodes because I could see the transition.After that, I think we can all agree that the chances of being disappointed hugely dropped and Season 6-7-8 provided some of the best episodes of the show: "Lisa the Vegetarian", "Homer the Great" or "You Only Move Twice" to name a few.But that never stopped the criticism, and after the "Principal and Pauper" episode, no one would've bet a penny on one more decade, and the following seasons made it even worse. Now, Season 11 is a classic full of so many great moments such as the octuplets' birth, Maude's death and the cow mooing"Tomacco!". Many episodes aged very well, and that's a credit to the writers' talent. Even the then- detestable"Saddlestore Galactica" is now regarded as a brilliant episode full of tongue-in-cheek humor from the authors, telling fans, we understand what you don't like but you better get used to it, because that's the new way of the Simpsons And let's admit it, wouldn't we watch the so hilariously over-the-top "Marge vs. the Monorail" rather than "Moaning Lisa"? In the late 90's and early 2000's most animated shows were satirical, pushing very far the parody button. The Simpsons didn't wait for"South Park" or"Family Guy"before making 'crazy humor' the rule rather than the exception. Of course, now, Homer became the main character, Lisa's liberalism became annoying and Marge isn't much of a character (there must be more episodes centered on Moe than Marge alone) but there was always a reason or a combination of reasons for all these changes.In the end, "The Simpsons" created characters, places, catchphrases, songs and words, a whole parallel universe that isn't just part of America's Pop Culture but the world, imagine that almost a quarter of the population was born when the Simpsons already existed, it's an era-defining phenomenon just like Chaplin or the Beatles, of the same epic scale as the Human Comedy by Honore de Balzac, tailor-made for the TV format and liable to evolve in the most disconcerting ways, like we all do.These are facts and they transcend personal opinions, so, don't have a cow and enjoy the show, and if you feel 'meh' about it, remember THEY popularized this word.

The Simpsons used to be such a great show, easily the best on TV. It's humour and satire were brilliant and it was very well written.It seems that almost every kid nowadays will quote "The Simpsons" to each other, even I still quote it to my friends at University.But, like a lot of great series, it started to become sour. The series started to go downhill around season 10 and hasn't stopped since. I first noticed how bad Simpsons had become with episodes like the one where they go to Spring Break, and the Halloween episode where Homer gets cloned. To get an idea of how bad it's become, in the most recent season there can be maybe one laugh for every 3 or 4 episodes. In fact, there are more laughs and clever moments in a single episode from either series 5,6 or 7, then there are in an entire season from 14 onwards.Arguably some of the earlier episodes weren't that funny either, but they're missing the point. Those episodes were mostly satirical, plus there's the hit-and-miss quality. It's like comparing Dr. Strangelove to any of the Scary Movie's. Dr. Strangelove is a brilliant satire, and when it tries to be funny it mostly succeeds. Scary Movie, however, piles on the dumb jokes hoping that for every 20 jokes that aren't funny, there is 1 that is.In summary, watch if until season 10 or 11, after that don't even bother.

It's not really funny, I mean honestly who can honestly say this show frequently makes them "laugh out loud" cause most I ever do is half hearted giggle once in every blue moon.
It's more on the relatable and interesting to watch than on the funny side.
Humor is as repetitive as possible, heavily relying on Homer's doh's and woohoo's, on Flander's diddly diddly and on Burns' "excellent." Same thing in every episode in 30 seasons. Never gets old, huh? Well it does.
A very large number of episodes is downright boring because it revolves around side characters, which are... Well bland, basic, boring, nothing very funny or interesting about them. And then they make whole episodes about them. I mean Krusty, Patty and Selma, Moe, Barny, Apu... Really. Ugh.
And worst thing yet, the nasty small town mentality. Bunch of dumb religious zealots, hypocrites. Everyone knows everything about everyone, you can't even bat an eyelash cause the whole town will magically know about it within minutes. Then they praise or condemn you, depending on what you did... Everything you do is their business. It can be funny at times, and would be fine if it was limited to a few episodes, but instead it's something that happens in most episodes.
Still it can be interesting to watch at times. Irritates and bores me pretty easy though.
Simpsons seasons 1-10 are 10 stars. 11-13 are 8/7 stars. It goes down hill quickly from there

When I saw the Simpsons show I was really into it and entertained and I thought the show was hilarious. I enjoyed and loved some of the jokes they had, but as the show progressed it got offensive by it started bashing God and Jesus and I am a man of faith. I couldn't watch the show anymore because of the things the show said. After I still gave it a chance and stayed open minded and tried not to judge it, but the things the movie said made me uncomfortable. So I am writing this review to say that I would've enjoyed it, if only the bashing of not only my families beliefs, but also, other people's beliefs in a higher power wasn't thrown as jokes like that. It's fine to have your own opinions, but don't bash people's beliefs. That's messed up. All in all, I would never watch the show or movie again.

I used to love the Simpsons just like everyone else and would never miss an episode on channel 2 or sky one, but i haven't watched it in ages, probably haven't seen a new episode since about 2001 (except the one Simon Cowell was in and the one Ricky Gervais wrote) and this is because the new ones are nothing in comparison to the earlier ones.All programmes lose steam after a while and they usually end after eight or so series but here the Simpsons is still going after 18 years and they've run out of good ideas! I wish they had ended it years ago when the show was on a high but now i get to the point where i think "Oh god not another new Simpsons episode" because there's no where else to go with it, they even had to bring in Ricky Gervais for a change of pace which failed miserably because that episode was self indulgent and boring. Please end it now before it gets even worse! OK i'll stop being negative now and get to the good points. The characters are hilarious and there are so many to choose from, my favourites being Lisa, Mr. Burns, Sideshow Bob, Ralph, Chief Wiggum and Homer.The early episodes were not only funny but also silly and witty at the same time, the writing was unmatchable and it was hard to believe you were watching an animation. So many episodes stand out like the hilarious 'Cape Feare' or the funny yet sad 'One fish two fish...' and other such as 'Brother from another series,' 'Lisa's substitute,' and 'Bart sells his soul' are great too.I'm not knocking the programme as i was a fan all through my childhood (still am a fan of early eps) and it's always nice to turn on the TV and catch a repeat of Homer, Bart and co.

This is definitely the best ANIMATED show on television. I have been a Simpsons fan for a long time, and over the years it has been going downhill, but recently its been really funny! I think that this is best for people who LOVE SEEING GREAT COMEDY AT WORK! Matt Groening is one of the funniest TV people ever (though I should be fair, a lot of the Simpsons is the writers, if not most of it). For those who don't know, it's about a dysfunctional family living in a town called Springfield (the state is unknown!!!!). There's Homer, the dimwitted father working at the Nuclear Powerplant. Then there's Marge, the housewife who is the classic mom. There's Bart, the spiky haired hell-raiser who has a knack for getting in trouble. There's Lisa, the intellectual middle child who plays the Saxaphone and is the smartest one in the family. Then finally there's Maggie, the baby that only talks in sucks on her pacifier. All in all, each episode includes their many misadventures including a meteor hitting the earth, and Homer causing Y2K. Bottom line, totally funny!

It was the funniest, the most heart warming, the most ingenious, ... , to simply put, it was the best show ever created on TV. But then, as so many have pointed out, something went wrong after 10 seasons or so.So what went wrong? the simplest way to put it is to say that somewhere along the line the show had lost its soul. Last few episodes I've watched, it was a bit like watching Simpson robots acting out Simpsons, doing and saying what they are supposed to in a Simpson's like story line. Everything was just too forced and too contrived.Just look at Homer, when the show started despite all his flaws and failings, he had a sweet nature that was endearing. He was a terrible father and a terrible Husband, but still, he was a loving father and a loving husband. He didn't just go on a misguided adventures just for the sake of it, usually they were with good intentions, and we could always count on him to do the right thing when the push came to shove. But in today's Homer Simpson all these characteristics were drained from him and what is left is just a shell, which is nothing more than a programed robot countlessly repeating Homer's catch phrases and acting out only the idiotic nature of what once was a Homer Simpson. There is nothing endearing about the Homer you see today, and you can say the same about the rest of the Simpsons characters.It is easy to criticise what is wrong about the show today knowing how good the show was and the bar it had set was simply not possible to maintain forever. Simpsons will never reach its golden heights again, but does it need to? The answer is no, its legacy was already set during first 10 seasons, and that has kept the show going some 15 years later, still. I do not watch the new episodes of Simpsons anymore but I rarely turn away from any of the old episodes if I happen to catch them.

there's no denying it. the Simpson's is a mere shadow of its former glory. of course its a universal constant that what goes up must come down, and the Simpson's reached their peak about series 3-6. i cant even watch the first threes series any more because i have simply thrashed them to death, i must have seen each episode at least 40-50 times. but thats why i love the Simpson's with such a passion: i grew up with them.with its reliance on violence and lame jokes that a writer for "Friends" would balk at, the Simpson's is just a money making machine now...no inspiration or comic genius is apparent and yet, somehow it still remains watchable.

Why does everyone keep saying that The Simpsons is the best show on television?  If anything, it's a lamest show on earth! I must admit I have watched it a couple of times during the first season when it was at the height of it's popularity.  It was hate at first sight to me!The reason why I'm against it is because it's an absoloute insult to everything, it rips off scenes from movies, it's that pop-culture thing. And what makes it even more insulting is that they portray Bart and the kids as the heroes and the adults on the show as the enemies.  Also, it's child exploitation to the extreme!  Showing Lisa get pushed around, beat up, Bart going around like a little sociopath, goofing off and Bart has no heart whatsoever, don't be fooled, people!  And you got the drunken Homer who's totally pathetic and seriously unfunny, and the domineering wife, Marge. Also, the writers put the kids in situations that adults would normally be in.Also, it's another one of those endless stream of family/kiddie sit-coms with precocious smart-allecky kids, and dumb parents.  I hope The Simpsons gets axed and put in a deep, dark spot in hell!  Or, al least end up in the trash heap, where it should've gone to begin with!!!!  DEATH TO THE SIMPSONS!!!!!

Too be completely honest, I don't like very much cartoons, and I don't understand why some of them are so popular (Like the annoying and overrated series called "Family Guy") However, I do like "The Simpsons", and I think that it is one of the best television shows ever made, having lots of different characters (I Think that Homer is quite annoying, but the other characters are very interesting and funny, specially Lisa Simpson, Maggie, Marge and Ned Flanders) many funny situations and lot of good celebrities occasionally appearing in the series, making it more entertaining.The jokes are fun, and the cultural references are very clever and well done. This is a very enjoyable series, with something to offer to everyone, and I think that's the main reason why "The Simpsons" could be easily considered the best cartoon ever made.

I have been an avid fan of the "The Simpsons" since in started when I was only four years old. The show has been almost always uniformly perfect from the start. My whole childhood and adolescence would be unthinkable without them. I thought I might grow out of them but the series has grown up with me. I love it. I haven't always been able over the recent years to watch and cherish all the episodes due to school and work. But I always watch the show when I have the opportunity. I have seen the trailer for "The Simpsons" movie and cannot wait for it to come out. I will be first in line to see it. "The Simpsons" have inspired "Family Guy" and "American Dad". I hope to be still viewing it when I am old and gray. Vive La Simpsons!

Ever since I started watching "The Simpsons" when it first started, it has been my favorite show. They just make fun of EVERYTHING! Aside from the fact that there are an infinite number of pop culture references and spoofs, they always look at current issues. Whether it's anti-immigrant sentiment, jingoism or gay marriage that passes through Springfield (the semi-fictional city where the show happens), you can count on "The Simpsons" to do something about it.And the characters. Homer is the D'oh-grunting, dim-witted, beer-guzzling, TV-obsessed, short-tempered, dangerously overweight dad. No matter what happens, he always comes close to screwing up everyone's existence. His constant injuries are pure belly laughs.Marge is the ever-concerned mom with hair shaped like a cactus. As everyone in the family often gets into some kind of trouble, she always has to scold them, usually unsuccessfully. Also, she always has some complaint for the local government, whether or not they listen to her.Bart is dude-saying, skateboarding, Krusty- and Itchy-and-Scratchy- and Radioactive-Man-obsessed, El-Barto-spray-painting son. His abundant pranks tend to get someone in trouble. His best pranks are of course his uncouth phone calls to Moe's Tavern, which result in massive embarrassment for Moe.Lisa is the left-wing, vegetarian, Buddhist, sax-playing daughter. As the only true intellectual in the family, she is often the one who gets the family out of trouble. She is always involved in the latest political cause (including tree-sitting).Maggie is the pacifier-sucking baby. Naturally, there is little to say about her...or is there? As for the other characters, there is Abe, the grandfather who tells dubious stories about his exploits; Patty and Selma Bouvier, Marge's sullen, DMV-operating sisters;Ned Flanders, the excessively pious neighbor;Principal Seymour Skinner, a Vietnam veteran with a tyrannical mother; Edna Krabappel, Bart's half-attentive teacher who is usually having an affair with Skinner; Groundskeeper Willie, the janitor who never lets anyone forget his Scottish heritage;Apu Nahasapeemapetilon, the Kwik-e-Mart owner who sells the unhealthiest food; Moe Szyzlak, the crude-mannered barkeep whose attempts at relationships are overshadowed by Bart's prank phone calls;Mr. Burns, the power plant owner who epitomizes the crass capitalist;Waylon Smithers, Mr. Burns' very gay lackey; Lenny Leonard and Carl Carlson, Homer's co-workers who may or may not have something going;Julius Hibbert, the physician who chuckles at inappropriate times; Tim Lovejoy, the drawling reverend; John Frink, the buck-toothed scientist who seems like a cross between the "Gilligan's Island" professor and any character from "Revenge of the Nerds"; Comic Book Store Guy, always obsessed with "Star Trek" or anything else involving androids; Joe Quimby, the John Kennedy-esque mayor who has a million affairs and is always beholden to the mafia; Clancy Wiggum, the corrupt police chief who finds more time to eat donuts than to arrest criminals; Krusty the Klown, the kid-appealing clown who makes a whole array of dangerous products; Kent Brockman, the sour and oft biased anchorman; Rainier Wolfcastle, the Arnold Schwarzenegger-esque movie star who appears in the most idiotic action flicks; Fat Tony, the local mafioso who can buy out any authority figure; Milhouse Van Houten, Bart's geeky, bespectacled friend; Nelson Muntz, the school bully who always has a soft side;Martin Prince, the school nerd who remains eternally stuck up; and Santa's Little Helper and Snowball II, the Simpsons' dog and cat, respectively.Like I said, the whole show just makes fun of everything. Their best episodes are at Halloween (examples: Bart resurrects zombies, Homer becomes 3-D, and a Harry Potter spoof). What's really good about the show is that all the characters are flawed, but they're all well-meaning. Except for Mr. Burns. He's consistently malicious, doing things such as blocking out the sun so that the whole city has to buy power from him.So, that's why "The Simpsons" is, and always will be, my favorite TV show. One change that I have noticed is that the show used to be more Bart-centric, but is now more Homer-centric. But that's okay. I recommend "The Simpsons" to anyone and everyone!

THE SIMPSONS is a really cool television show and I'm going to explain this into 10 facts, instead of just an in-depth review: 1. The characters are just memorable and the voice actors plays them very well.2. The show spawned into a mega franchise, including a movie, which came out in 2007 and I reviewed it on IMDb.3. The animation is still great today, as it was in 1989, when the series first premiered on Fox.6. The "Treehouse of Horror" episodes are not really all that scary and is just simply cool and amazing as hell.9. The character designs are just amazing and I give credit to the creators including Matt Groening and James L. Brooks 10. The couch gags on every episode of the TV show is just amazing and really well thought out and very amazing. My favorite ones are the Etch-A-Sketch gag, the 500 episodes gag, the "Treehouse of Horror" episodes couch gags and of course, the dancing couch gag with the elephants and the Egyptian dancing in the second episode of the second season.Overall, these are the reasons why I watch THE SIMPSONS.

This cartoon series has everything you'd want - memorable characters, funny gags and insightful stories. Each episode is like a window into American society and it shows so much about different areas of our lives. The characters themselves are so fleshed out that it's like we know then personally, which leads to some very personal and emotional moments at times.

Okay, who's honestly reading this, thinking "Hmm, should I watch The Simpsons?" ? With 26 seasons and daily reruns on Fox, everyone has watched some episodes, if not many.I believe I've watched all the episodes, for better or for worse. ^^' I believe its the best thing I can watch on prime time. Its nice to watch during dinner, doing dishes, or to pass the time.Since every episode is stand-alone, and there's over 550 episodes through three decades, I have to talk about the show in broad terms. So, here's the top 3 best things and worst things about The Simpsons.THE BEST 1. The characters are pretty good. They are cartoonish, but likable, three dimensional, and funny. There isn't a character in the large regular cast that I hate to see. I particularly enjoy the unfortunately true-to-life Comic Book Guy, the rude child entertainer Krusty the Clown, and the apathetic elementary teacher Edna Krabappel. The cast is ready for both blunt satire and heartfelt moments.2. Speaking of which, the best episodes do hit close to home. The Simpsons financial difficulties, Bart caught stealing a game, Homer and Marge settling with their lot in life. My favorite one is where Lisa makes friends on vacation. It reminded me so much of those one-week friendships I'd make every summer. Sadly, most of these serious episodes are only in the first half of the franchise.3. The Simpson's best trait is the one that's the least tangible. Its just plain funny. Balanced in timing and variety, even the bad episodes elicit chuckles. I just like this style.THE WORST1. This is the show that brought us the term "Flanderization" - where characters become simplified and exaggerated as a show goes on. Ned Flanders, for example, started off as an ideal, friendly neighbor, but devolved into a friendly, paranoid religious nut. Most characters undergo this change. Admittedly, it does give some characters more personality, but for others, it severely damages their character. The worst example of this is Patty and Selma. They've always disliked Homer, but now its canon that they kidnapped and attempted to murder him. I'm serious.2. As if you can talk about canon in The Simpsons. They haven't aged a day in 25 years. The vast majority of episodes exist in a vacuum. Thus you'll never have character development beyond the half hour of each episode. Since nothing changes, a lot of themes have to be reused. Expect a lot of episodes where Homer and Marge kiss and makeup, Lisa makes friends, or Bart bites off more than he can chew. They'll never learn their lessons forever, which is frustrating on the macro scale.3. I dislike most episodes that completely drop the character and satire. They're just pure cartoons, something the typical episode of The Simpsons would criticize. I skip every "The Simpsons Go To X!" episode (And no, Bart vs. Australia isn't the "good one"! >:I), classic stories with Simpsons characters forced in, and most of the Treehouse of Horrors.Those are my thoughts. If you are the lone person whose curious about the show, watch any episode that's airing at the moment. If you like what you see, then you can use the web to find the best episodes. They're on Hulu, so you can check the highest scoring entries on IMDb and see them yourself.
