To me, the first nine seasons the Simpsons is one of the greatest times in TV history, and no, I'm not waxing nostalgia, I'm saying this because the show Groening and Co created was not only a smart and entertaining body of work, but it also did it with likable characters you could empathize with and great stories to boot.However, as all good things must come to an end, the "Great" years of the show stopped as soon as the powers that be decided to dumb it down to make it a show that's more family (and ratings) friendly (season 10 and beyond). Combined with a total lack of regard of competent storytelling, horrible puns, dated storytelling and the new sterile HD switch the past few seasons are existing only on the show's popular name.
This show once was one of the best shows ever. Now is painful to watch, dumb, nonsense humor, not funny at all. The worst thing is how awesome it was time before

When it first came along, "The Simpsons" took the world by storm, because it was not only hilarious and sincere all at once, but also unique. Whoever heard of an animated sitcom about a normal suburban family, without superpowers or giant talking animals or anything like that? It was unthinkable. Matt Groening's world sucked everyone in simply because it rang true... remember the now-famous adage, "There's a Simpson in all of us?" well, it was true, we loved the series because we identified so well with the characters. We could laugh at our own faults and troubles, and forget about them all at once. I always thought it was a LITTLE overrated, but it was still very good. I practically grew up with them. Sure, its sudden success produced the inevitable morass of bad ripoffs, parodies and tributes, everyone trying to jump on the bandwagon and attempt to capture just what made it unique, butthe Simpsons still stood in a class all its own. But a happy ending wasn't to be. In the grand tradition of so many of the greatest TV shows of all time ("Are You Being Served?"), the Simpsons' writers did the inevitable: They ran out of ideas. Suddenly they were recycling jokes, becoming steadily more offbeat with their humor, and writing plot lines that tried way too hard to be funny and wound up just being stupid. Before long it felt that each episode was being written by committee. I still remember, during December of 1998, praying to God to please, let the series die a dignified death, just have them make one last FANTASTIC final episode and let that be it, don't make them keep dragging it out for another 9 years after it runs out of juice, please... But that wasn't to be, either. Instead they've done exactly that, they've propped it up for years and years past its lifetime. A moment of silence if you please.It used to be one of the best shows on TV, back when it was actually somewhat original.

Okay, maybe I was too harsh when I said that, but the truth is, this show is, in fact, extremely overrated. Don't get me wrong, I USED to love it, but now it's getting old; as in it should've never even entered the 21st century.To start off, I'm very unimpressed with the animation. It's dull and tacky; and where's the vibrancy? Plus most of the character movements are forced, particularly the facial expressions of Marge Simpson and "Comic Book Guy" (who came up with these names?); to be honest, it looks as if this show is made on the cheap. I may or may not be the only one to complain about this, but the characters' skins are mostly yellow while others are brown, which indicates a pinch of laziness, and it certainly doesn't help that color's all over the place. Even "101 Dalmations: The Series" had better animation than this, and yet it was low-budget for goodness sake.The music isn't much better. The music scores and the theme songs are both kind of pleasant if unmemorable, but in general the musical numbers are poor. Maybe not as bad as those ear-bleeding songs from the "Mr. Hankey the Christmas Poo" episode of "South Park", and not as badly sung either, but it isn't saying much. I think I need to talk about the worst one. That is "Freedom" from that one episode where children fight against grown-ups, and in my opinion is a perfect example of complete unnessecaty, and one that's so bad it's hilarious. With the uncanny music, non-sense lyrics and horrible singing, it was bland and terrible to listen to. Which is rather pathetic, seeing how Danny Elfman has done wonderful music scores for "Chicago", "Corpse Bride" and "The Nightmare Before Christmas". Perhaps he's uninspired with what he has to work with.Maybe I am alone in this, but the characters aren't that very likable. Homer Simpson, instead of being the headstrong funny protagonist I keep hoping for (maybe my expectations are too high), is always dry as a cactus. Bart and Lisa are rather clichd children, and despite one being a troublemaker (Bart) and the other being smart, intelligent, and caring for the environment (Lisa), are as dried up as well, and Marge's voice is so dried up that you want to smack her in the face. Not even Maggie or any other side characters have any real charm.The episodes are, how do I put it, bad. There is very little humor in each episode, and the writing is stale and the lines clichd. You always feel as if you've seen it before, I certainly have. So much so, the side characters have very little to do in Springfield, and the dialogue is sappy and wishy-washy. If there's any comedy in an episode, it's unintentional. I am of course talking about everything -- the regulars, the two-three parters, even the "Treehouse of Horror" specials. The endings leave me dissatisfied, not only 'cause they are all happy endings but also 'cause it makes each episodes feel rather abrupt.But as the characters are lifeless and unengaging, same applies to the voice acting. While most of the voices are annoying, others have few points of energy to carry on an episode. Dan Castellaneta tries his best playing Homer, Grandpa Abe, Groundskeeper Willie, and so many others, but is always hampered down by the material he's given. Same applies to Yeardley Smith as Lisa. Most of the actors, like Julie Kavner as Marge, Patty and Selma, Harry Shearer as Ned Flanders, and Tress MacNielle as several females read their lines as if they're reading out of a story book, and believe me, that's quite boring. Nancy Cartwright appears to be the only one having fun, but, like Castellaneta, is given so much to do as Bart, Ralph Wiggum, Todd Flanders, etc.Overall, this show is mediocre. It's not terrible, but bland. **** out of **********.
They made terrible parodies for everything! I hate Simpsons! Ugly, yellow figurines, this show must end!

The season opener is just awful. Disneyfyed to the hilt.Marge has a new singing voice? Disjointed script. Predictable.Sad to see The Simpsons go but this season opener is a certain warning of impending death for the series.Disney sure didn't wait to grind the "edge" completely off.

This is one of, if not the best show there has been in the history in television, especially from America. The greatest cartoon ever made started in 1989, and it's still going on. The Simpsons are the family that live in the town of Springfield. The Simpsons family is a 10-year-old son, Bart; an 8-year-old daughter, Lisa; a baby daughter, Maggie; a mother and wife, Marge; and of course, television and the programme's greatest character, the stupid, lazy, sometimes rude and disgusting father/husband, Homer Simpson. Throughout the show the family have many weird and wonderful adventures, happenings and goings on. All funny, lovable and brilliant stories are what keep the show going. Homer is obviously the biggest story maker of the show. There are also some lovable characters in the extended family and neighbourhood to like, including Abraham "Grampa" Simpson, Patty and Selma, Santa's Little Helper and Snowball II, The Flanders: Ned, Maude, Rod and Todd, Milhouse Van Houten, Apu, Ralph Wiggum, Chief Clancy Wiggum, Dr. Julius Hibbert, Martin Prince, Reverand Lovejoy, Nelson Muntz, Cletus and Brandine, Mr. Charles Montgomery Burns and Waylon Smithers, Lenny and Carl, Principal Seymour Skinner, Superintendent Chalmers, Edna Krabappel, Grounsdkeeper Willie, Otto Mann, Jimbo, Dolph, Kearney, Mayor "Diamond Joe" Quimby, Snake, Fat Tony, Comic Book Guy, Sea Captain (MacCallister), Lionel Hutz, Squeaky Voiced Teen, Professor Frink, Hans Moleman, Krusty the Clown, Itchy and Scratchy (in TV cartoons), Kent Brockman, Troy McClure, Rainier Wolfcastle (who plays McBain), Bleeding Gums Murphy, Moe the bartender, Barney Gumble, Dr. Nick Riviera, Dr. Marvin Monroe, and many more. Stars of these voices are Dan Castellaneta, Julie Kavner, Nancy Cartwright, Yeardley Smith, This Is Spinal Tap's Harry Shearer, Hank Azaria, Pamela Hayden, Tress MacNeille, Marcia Wallace, Maggie Roswell, Russi Taylor, Joe Mantegna and Phil Hartman (till his death).The other reason the show is so popular is that it is the cartoon sitcom with the most celebrity appearances. These include: Kelsey Grammar as 'Sideshow Bob', James Earl Jones, Jon Lovitz, Danny DeVito as Herbert Powell (Homer's half-brother), Frank Welker, Ringo Starr, Dustin Hoffman, Sting, Bob Hope, Sir Tom Jones, Bette Midler, Hugh Hefner, Dame Elizabeth Taylor (as herself and Maggie (once), Brooke Shields, Barry White, Michelle Pfeiffer, Sam Neill, James Woods, Kathleen Turner, James Taylor, Winona Ryder, Meryl Streep, Woody Harrelson, Patrick Stewart, Mel Brooks, Susan Sarandon, Sir Paul McCartney, Glenn Close as Homer's Mom, Donald Sutherland, Kirk Douglas, Jeff Goldblum, Christina Ricci, Johnny Cash, David Duchovny, Gillian Anderson, Jack Lemmon, Willem Dafoe, Martin Sheen, Jay Leno, Helen Hunt, Rod Steiger, Bono, Steve Martin, Lisa Kudrow, Robert Englund, Jerry Springer, Alec Baldwin, Kim Basinger, Brian Grazer, Ron Howard, Mark Hamill, Sir Elton John, Stephen Hawking, Mel Gibson, John Goodman, Tim Robbins, Britney Spears, Jim Cummings, Parker Posey, Gary Coleman, Buzz Aldrin, Stephen King, Drew Barrymore, Michael Keaton, Serena and Venus Williams, Justin Timberlake, Pierce Brosnan, Matthew Perry, Paul Newman, Richard Gere, Delroy Lindo, Ben Stiller, Reese Witherspoon, Stan Lee, Carmen Electra, Elvis Costello, Mick Jagger, Keith Richards, Tony Bennett, Burt Ward, Adam West, Elliot Gould, Pamela Reed, Tony Hawk, Helen Fielding, James L. Brooks, Steve Buscemi, Michael Moore, British Prime Minister Tony Blair, Sir Ian McKellen, J.K. Rowling, Mr. T, Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, Sarah Michelle Gellar, Matt Groening (Simpsons creator), Kim Cattrall, Eric Idle, 50 Cent, Lucy Liu, Robert Wagner, Baha Men, Liam Neeson, William H. Macy, Michael York, Ricky Gervais (who also wrote his episode), Joe Pantoliano and so many more.If you've never watched this, you should, it is just the most outstanding cartoon and sitcom ever created. Winner of and nominated for numerous awards including 3 British Comedy Awards, 6 ASCAP Film and TV Music Awards, 23 Annie Awards and 20 Emmys, through seventeen years on TV! A movie will be coming out in 2007! It was number 6 on The 100 Greatest Pop Culture Icons, it was number 12 on The 100 Greatest Christmas Moments (for all Christmas episodes), it was number 1 on The 100 Greatest TV Characters (for Homer Simpson), it was number 1 on The 100 Greatest Kids' TV Shows, and of course, it was number 1 on The 100 Greatest Cartoons. Outstanding!

I like this show, but...Matt Groening and company really got carried away with the celebrity cameos. I watch "The Simpsons" for its FANTASY element, because it takes place in a world that never was - not so I can see yellow-skinned, lipless versions of the REAL world's movers and shakers.Tony Bennett, Aerosmith, Linda Ronstadt, Adam West, Leonard Nimoy, George Harrison, Johnny Carson, Elizabeth Taylor, Luke Perry, Mel Brooks, Bono from U2, Ron Howard, Mel Gibson, Britney Spears...arrggh! It's not that I don't like these people, but their overexposed mugs belong in live action and not in cartoons! I watch "The Simpsons" as a means of escape from reality, so it's frustrating that I get reality shoved right in my face about 75 percent of the time when I watch this show.The really annoying episodes are the ones where the celebrity's name is said over and over and we're supposed to be entertained just because that person is famous. "Gasp! It's James Woods!" "Oh my God, it's Kim Basinger!" "Wow! It's 'N Sync!" (actually said TWICE, by Milhouse) Give me a freaking break! True, celebrities have made cameos on other cartoon shows; but at least then they had the good taste to play satirical versions of themselves (like "Ann Margrock" on "The Flintstones").In closing, let me just say that "The Simpsons" would be a perfect show if it weren't for all these celebrities shamelessly self-promoting themselves. I don't mind the celebrities, but I wish they would play fictional characters and not themselves. Then the pristine atmosphere of Springfield could be protected from the incursions of modern American life. "The Simpsons" is a fantasy - and it should remain that way.Oh, and one more thing: I wish they would shut up about what state Springfield is in! NOBODY CARES!All that aside...I really like "The Simpsons."

I rate this show 10/10 based of the first 9 seasons. It was witty, it had so much heart, it was hilarious and the stories were good enough that even if you have seen an episode 10 times and know every joke, you can still enjoy it just because of the plot. The characters were great, the show had such a great balance between humor and emotion. Now, if I were to include anything past those season, specially the current ones, I'd probably give the show a 6, if you think about it, the golden era is only one quarter of the show now, meaning that 75% of the show goes from enjoyable or watchable to terribly boring and underwhelming. I wish this show had followed on Jerry Seinfeld's footsteps who knew when to end his show and went out on a high note. Both shows started in the same year and I have always felt they had a similar evolution through the years until Seinfeld ended. Then The Simpsons came out with their 10th season and although enjoyable the decline in quality was noticeable.I just wish there was a way to separate the eras of the show and rate them accordingly.

this cartoon is the best cartoon in the world. It's the longest running animation series since the Flintsones,and now on its tenth series its shows seem to be getting better and better. I think when the cartoon first started in 1989 (in its own show) the cartoon was aimed at children but as it's come on, the storylines have quite a lot of adult references which to me makes it more funny

It does not seem as long as over two decades ago since 'The Simpsons' bounced onto our television screens. The yellow skinned cartoon family from the fictional American town of Springfield first appeared on Fox's long forgotten 'The Tracey Ullman Show' from 1986 to 1989. These crudely designed skits created by Matt Groening saw the eccentric family enacting various activities, such as taking a trip to the zoo or going fishing and proved to be the most popular part of the show ( though when 'The Tracey Ullman Show' was screened in Britain, 'The Simpsons' sketches were not included as the controllers at BBC Television thought the sketches were too strange to find an audience in Britain. What? Stranger than 'Monty Python's Flying Circus' or 'The Young Ones'? Surely not! ) so thoughts turned towards developing the characters into a sitcom format. In December 1989, 'The Simpsons' kicked off with 'Simpsons Roasting On An Open Fire'. It caught on immediately and from there has since notched up 574 episodes between 26 seasons as well as a feature length film, which went on release in 2007.The head of the dysfunctional Simpson family is Homer, a drunken, bumbling idiot who when not filling his face with donuts or swilling bottles of Duff beer at Moe's Tavern is to be found slacking from his work at the Springfield Power Plant. His wife is Marge - tall, husky voiced and with a huge blue bouffant hairstyle. They also have three children - 10 year old tearaway Bart, 8 year old brain box Lisa, and baby Maggie. The plots each week would normally focus on a perfectly normal situation escalating into total surrealism and like most American sitcoms, 'The Simpsons' was loud, daring and incredibly corny, yet was frequently hilarious. Homer and Bart proved the most popular with viewers, the latter for providing much of the visual humour with his mischievous ( and often dangerous ) antics and the former getting many of the laughs by either destroying everything he touched, saying the wrong thing at the wrong time, or simply just standing and looking bewildered. Homer's ''D'oh!'' catchphrase ( usually yelled when something or someone caused him to come a cropper ) to this day is still used worldwide.As 'The Simpsons' steadily rose in popularity, supporting characters such as bumbling school headmaster Principal Seymour Skinner, inept policeman Chief Wiggum and his mentally disturbed son Ralph, sleazy barman Moe, Homer's slobbish drinking buddy Barney Gumble, devious children's television presenter Krusty The Clown, Kwik-E-Mart proprietor Apu ( ''Thank you, come again!'' ), Homer's senile father Grandpa Abe Simpson, luckless Hans Moleman and white bearded pensioner Jasper Beardly became just as much an integral part of the show as Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa and Maggie did. Also brilliant were the 'Itchy & Scratchy' sequences ( which were shown as sketches on Krusty's television show ) in which a cat and mouse would try to knock ten bells out of each other, with the cat inevitably getting brutally killed. The idea for 'Itchy & Scratchy' was clearly influenced by William Hannah and Joseph Barbera's animated classic, 'Tom & Jerry'.Many well known celebrities lent their voices to the show such as Danny DeVito, Elizabeth Taylor, Bette Midler, Robert Wagner, the late Gary Coleman, Sting, Mick Jagger, Britney Spears and, surprisingly, Professor Stephen Hawking! Aerosmith and U2 also joined in the fun.My favourite episodes included 'You Only Move Twice' ( Homer moves to Cyprus Creek when he is offered a well paying job there ), 'Flaming Moe's' ( Moe steals the recipe of an alcoholic drink which Homer invented ), 'Itchy & Scratchy Land' ( the family take a trip to a theme park dedicated to their favourite cartoon characters ), 'One Fish, Two Fish, Bluefish, Blowfish' ( Homer consumes a poisonous blowfish and thinks he only has 24 hours left to live ), 'Bart Gets An F' ( Bart is warned by his teacher that he will be held back another year if he fails his history test ), 'Homie The Clown' ( Homer gets a job as a Krusty The Clown double ), 'Bart After Darkness' ( Bart is given a job working in a burlesque house ). Best of all was 'Das Bus' in which the pupils of Springfield Elementary school end up washed up on a remote desert island after their school bus crashes over a bridge. The Halloween specials ( usually titled 'Treehouse Of Horror' ) were classics in their own right too. Full marks must not only go to Matt Groening for creating the show and its characters, but also to the voices behind the characters - Dan Castellaneta, Julie Kavner, Nancy Cartwright and Yeardley Smith among many others.Two and a half decades on, the show's status as a comedy classic remains untarnished, which is testament to the genius of its creator. Groening later followed up 'The Simpsons' with 'Futurama', an animated period piece sitcom set in the year 3000. Though it build up a large and loyal following, it was never in any danger of eclipsing 'The Simpsons' in terms of popularity.

I love this show, I was 4 years old when it stated and I've grown up with Homer,Marge,Bart,Lisa & Maggie,But after 20 years now and a Disappointing Movie it's starting to show it's age, the 22 minute stories which were sweet and believable are now becoming far fetched and nigh on ridiculous, but it's still one of the best shows on TV. I just miss the standard of the earlier years, and hope that they don't milk it until it gets axed for falling viewers, it deserves to go out on a high. 10/10 season 1 to 117/10 season 11 onwards

It was inevitable that the show would change; in fact, it's been changing since season 1.  But after Season 12, the show hit a brick wall.  Each episode was carefully strained to filter out all but the most unintelligent and unfunny remarks and stretched them out as far as possible, filling everything in between with previous show references.  There's just nothing there anymore, and it's terribly sad to see what the show has become when you see what is used to be.I would refer to the show's golden years as the end of season 2 through somewhere inside season 6.  This is when the show was truly funny. Afterwards, until around season 11 or so, the show was still funny and had a charm you couldn't find anywhere else, they just weren't the best of the best anymore.  My favorite episodes are "Selma's Choice" and "Last Exit to Springfield,' although perhaps the "strange" season 4-type humor is more my cup of tea than the "stupid Homer doing stupid things" humor that later became the show's trademark.In a few interviews I've read, somebody always comments that the show is getting harder and harder to make because it's becoming impossible to find stories that haven't been done already.  In my opinion, most viewers don't care what story you give them, as long as it has consistently strong jokes; I believe the strength of the former makes up better for weakness of the latter, an opinion the writers don't share.  Speaking of writers, some should be hired who actually care about the show.  Recently, it seems like more and more film and genre spoofs (i.e., having the characters watch a movie or show) are required to garner a laugh.  The educational films have always been a high point, but when the writers are using them so often it seems like they need a break from the show, they should be given just that. If you can't make up something funny within the context that has been established for this show, you need to find another show to write for. Also, recently many self-referential comments have been made about the declining quality of the show (Marge once comments, "Well, I think it's good when a show goes off the air before it becomes stale and repetitive,' and the abrupt scene cut suggests it was a punch line) that are barely hidden and hit you on the head with a hammer to make their point.  If the writers realize how bad the show is getting, why don't they work on making it stronger rather than using the situation to wring a cheap joke from every now and then?The key to the show's undoing is the change in characters.  It's hard to believe the early and later prototypes are characters from the same show. Bart was a mischievous but loveable kid, the kind of 10-year-old you wouldn't mind having, with an affection for A Clockwork Orange and Three Stooges impersonations; he turned into a graffiti-loving, hopelessly stupid, whiny brat who relishes the thought of becoming a juvenile delinquent and can't tell the difference between right and wrong.  Lisa, the change of whom aggravates me the most, was an intelligent, girlishly cute, usually morally correct 8-year-old who stood up for her beliefs but was mostly concerned with being a kid; she transformed into an annoying, self-righteous, loud-mouthed brainiac who refuses to let anyone else harbor their own opinion and drives home the point long after anyone cares, both on and off screen.  Marge has probably changed the least; she has always been the glue that held the family together, the voice of reason, the ideal embodiment of mom and wife; my only real complaint is that she does display, more and more often, bad habits she has naggingly attempted to rid the family of for the show's run.And, of course, there's Homer.The most pivotal character in this franchise.  He was a dumb but good-hearted man, who lived for life's simpler pleasures.  He loved his family and showed it.  He didn't mean to be cruel, or lazy, or self-interested, but often his stupidity prevented him from seeing what the problems with these things were until it was too late.  Not so in the later seasons.  Homer became not only stupid, but a stupid jerk.  He indulged himself no matter what the cost to others, he openly admitted his disinterest for anyone but himself, and his aversion to work was more powerful than his desire to prove that his family was worth any effort.  I will never see this as Homer Simpson.  His comments have become much too formulaic.  How many recent jokes have there been in which Homer would say a sentence, and then repeat the last word of that sentence with more emphasis? ("I told you, my memory is fuzzy.  FUH-ZZY!")  Ax plus By does not equal comedy, I'm sorry to say.  I wish it were, then I might still find this show funny.  And the writers have been attempting to give him lines meant for Ralph Wiggum; coming from Homer, they just don't work.
The show cut and dropped and added and substituted until there was nothing left.  In its heyday it was the best, the ONLY thing out there; nothing else could ever touch the greatness of the aforementioned golden years. Unfortunately, the shows of that era have long since wandered off and disappeared into a thick forest of season 9+ episodes, and it's a rarity to catch them anymore.  9 out of 10 times, you're going to see an episode you just saw last month, and the month before that, and the month before that, and that's a real shame and a waste of good episodes.  I hope they go soon return to the times that made the show what it was; when they are forgotten, this becomes just another blip on the sequence of images as you flip through channels in a futile attempt to find something decent.

This is the best show. I love the Simpsons I've almost watched every episode! I have a Simpsons guide book of every episode from seasons 1 to 8. My favorite one is Bart. I can't Believe they've gone 12 seasons (12 years) and I heard there's going to be be a 13th season!

At over 20 years old, "The Simpsons" is wonderful, but it really would not be tragic if it were it to end. I remember that I would pretty much watch every episode when it used to air on BBC2 and there are some episodes of which I may still have a near-recital worthy knowledge. What consistently set the first ten or so seasons of the show apart from similar things (such as "Family Guy" and "South Park", which aren't all that bad themselves) was that it went beyond being a completely noisy and comical affair full of funny slapstick and cultural references and turned into something that one could truly relate to, more so than the average American sitcom. Yet I have to admit that, due to its age, it doesn't have the same kind of vitality that it once did. Don't get me wrong; it's still one of my favourites, but its run is truly miraculous enough as it is and it will still go down favourably in geeky television history.

You must not overlook this show never.

I can't believe it's taken so long for me to post a review for one of my all-time favorite sitcoms/satires. Well, the first 10 seasons is 10/10, but after that it was kind of hit and miss. But still, The Simpsons was subversive and a game changer for animation. The Simpsons wasn't The Flintstones for sure. It was for adults and kids, all at once.

The reason i have voted a 1 is because i'm not actually referring to the original few series of the Simpson's, i'm referring to the last 2 or 3, i have nothing against the first 10 or so seasons, they were all great and perfectly original but since the start of the new millennium the Simpson's have rapidly become one of the unfunniest animated shows on TV to date.And why not, when the public is exposed to such hilarity as Family Guy, South Park, Drawn together, and yes even the wonderfully colourful antics of Fairly Odd Parents, you start to see how uncreative and unoriginal the Simpson's have really become.i watched 4 newish episodes of the Simpson's in a row on Sunday 2nd July on Sky One's Sunday send-off dedicated to Malcolm In the Middle and 24 and no offence Matt Groening but the first 45 seconds of the final Malcomme in the middle was funnier than all four of those episodes together, this is no joke.I'd like to point out the following mistakes I have noticed with the last 3-5 seasons of the Simpson's.1. There have only been 2 episodes where Lisa picks up a saxophone but a whole lot of others where we see her playing an instrument she's never owned.2. In the last two seasons of the Simpson's, i have failed to see where the ending of each episode actually happens, what we are given are pointless and improper endings compared to the real endings of the 1990's, where are the endings? 3. There is an ever increasing AGF around the Simpson's (Anti-Growth-Field) some of the noticeable things are A. there was a new episode in the late 90's showing a flashback of when Bart was born in 1982, how can he be born in 1982 when he's still 10.B. There have been numerous Birthdays, Summer holidays etc in the Simpson's yet for some reason they haven't aged and haven't moved on in grade.C. On Lisa's last birthday homer did something to upset her and she said "dad, you've had 8 years to get to know me, it's too late now", so what's happened is that she's just had a birthday but she is in fact still 8 years old.D. Perhaps the most recent flaw with the age factor is the discovery of Snake's son who is currently Bart's age, well Mr world class animated show writer, i'd like you to explain to me how that's even possible, if any of you so called writers have paid attention to the show, you'll see why i don't find this feasible.E. why is it that Maggie is still in nappies, there were hints that she was getting older in the 1st series and then it all just kinda stopped from there, notice that Apu's children who were all born in around the 10th season are all now walking, talking and have full heads of hair yet Maggie cant talk and can barely walk although she was born before them, unless Asians have a gene which makes them grow faster, which is highly unlikely, also you'll notice that sideshow bob now has a son, who by the looks of it is at least 4 years old, don't tell me this isn't a flaw.F. a recent episode includes Marge writing a book and within this episode appears Dr. Marvin Munroe "Dr.Marvin Munroe, i haven't seen you in years" you'd think it had only been weeks since the AGF is still surrounding you all.4. Has anyone seen where all the characters have gone, recently i've seen a dramatic decline of characters featuring in any episode even for a moment, and when they do it's just as a pointless side joke.5. Why doesn't homer have a job anymore? 6. What happened to the Leftorium? 7. Where the hell is Otto? 8. Why doesn't Smithers admit he's gay? i cant think of anymore things to point out at the moment but i'm sure they'll come to me.i'm not saying that the Simpson's is a bad show, i just think that it's tasteless puns, pointless story lines and disappearing acts in terms of characters is starting to ruin whatever fame the Simpson's had before, and if it doesn't change soon then i don't think there'll be any line for the new movie when it premiers.if you have any complaints about my comments then just email me at this address.therubixtheory@hotmail.co.ukand if you can, please tell me where i can send a letter to Matt groening, i've been dying to tell him what i think.
A show made for dumb 12-13 boys and college dropouts.

When Matt Groening first introduced the world to his dysfunctional animated family the Simpsons on the Tracey Ullman show during the 1980's, it wasn't clear as to what the show was really trying to do. Beginning as crudely drawn five-minute sketches, the bizarre cartoon was a little quirky for most audiences, and didn't receive a lot of attention. It was not until Fox Network gave the yellow, three-fingered family their own television show that popularity began to ensue. Now, well into its seventeenth season, "The Simpsons" has done what no other television series has ever been able to do before or since. Not only is the show undoubtedly history's most successful animated series, and not only has it set amazing standards for hilarity and poignancy in the television industry, but it alone, of all the shows in the history of the world, has managed to traverse the gap between entertainment and iconic status of a first degree. It alone can be held on a pedestal above all others, because it has become beyond classic, beyond renowned. "The Simpsons" has indeed become so embedded in the fiber of Western culture that it can no more be considered just a cartoon than the Beatles could be considered just a band or James Dean could be considered just an actor.Groening's take on not only the dysfunctional American domestication but the entire American society begins with the titular family, of course. Homer (Dan Castellaneta), the dim-witted but lovable father, Marge (Julie Kavner), the sensible but a little over-conservative mother, Lisa (Yeardley Smith), the supremely intelligent and sensitive 8 year old daughter, Bart (Nancy Cartwright), the hell-raising but overly good-natured 10 year-old son, and Maggie, the silent but observant baby. These five characters are the primary mediums with which the show's creators dish out their scathing critique of America and the rest of the world with fantastic wit, but one of the beautiful things about The Simpsons is the vast and rich spread of stereotypical caricatures the creators have to choose from in the family's hometown of Springfield. Not only does the town appear to represent all that is wrong with American society, but nearly every character serves as a representative of an aspect of that flawed society, from Moe Sizlac (Hank Azaria), the miserable bartender, to Ned Flanders (Harry Shearer), the Simpsons' uber-Christian, nice but condescending neighbor, to Krusty The Clown (Castellaneta), the substance-abusing and emotionally damaged children's entertainer, to the town's evil, monopolizing capitalist millionaire, Mr. Burns (Shearer). The list continues with many other instantly recognizable characters used to attack the legal system, political corruption, education, environmentalism, sexuality, bureaucracy, consumerism, celebrities, pop-culture, American values, you name it, they've mocked it. But despite the fierce disdain that one could perceive lies at the heart of the show, The Simpsons rarely comes across as snide or nasty, because the writers are willing to accept that the joke is just as much on them as on any one else.This self-awareness is one of the things that make the world of "The Simpsons" such a comfortable and accessible place; the characters are so extreme that it becomes obvious to most audiences that the humor is based also on the ridiculous caricatures of the subject matter as much as the subject matter itself. It is in this respect that the voice talents for The Simpsons, as much as the writers, make the material rise to practically unimaginable heights of hilarity. Creating an entire town of people with only a handful of actors would have been a daunting task for some, but thanks to this infinitely gifted cast, almost every member of Springfield has become a delightfully unique and celebrated personality. The three most astounding of the actors involved in giving voice to assorted Springfield-ers are Dan Castellaneta, Harry Shearer and Hank Azaria, who all do some dozen characters each, and probably have the most famous voices in television history. It is because of these actors, and these actors alone, that the more slapstick humor of the show is as funny as it is, as well as the stand-alone, nonsensical jokes that only serve the purpose of cheating the audience out of an expected and typical outcome. However, the more Monty Python-esquire aspects of The Simpsons are skillfully interspersed with what can be called without question some of the cleverest humor seen on television in years.It is in simple jokes such as a historical park having recently changed management putting up a sign that reads "Sorry, but there's profit to be had" or a wistful Homer telling his little boy in a loving tone that "If something's hard to do then it's not worth doing" that the reason for The Simpsons' deserved stature lies. The show-runners could have, at any time, copped out and made their series a collection of jokes about the stupidity of an American father or the antics of a rebellious son, but instead they made it meaningful and poignant. It is for this reason that whatever happens to the show now, whether it declines into dismally low ratings and is cancelled for lack of interest or gets its second wind and comes back strong with the best we've seen yet, "The Simpsons" will always be the absolute and undeniable epitome of television entertainment.

Okay, back when the Simpsons aired in 1989 off the Tracy Ulman show (premeired 1992 in Hong Kong), it was one of the most wonderful, funny and poignatic show. Sure there might have been some mild profanity and crude humor, but it seemed like just about everyone enjoyed it. I felt like adopting the Simpsons as a second family.......... ..........Until after 1997, after the death of Phil Hartman, it seemed to really sink low and be more aimed for the "Teen Crowd". I also hate how the characters got REAL personallity face-lifts. Come on, Barny becoming sober? Sideshow Bob becoming evil AGAIN (despite the fact that was brother was mentioned was another head scratcher)? Bart Simpson driving a tank? What the.......? This is just blowing my mind. I also hate how Homer became from lovable dumb lug with a short fuse to being a crazed fame-thirsty jerk. I also hate the Lisa Simpson makeover too. She used to be my favorite character with alot of good advice to give out. Now, she's a total crazy stereotypical hippy! And didn't Bart used to be more miscievious? Don't get me started with the episodes with Brittany Spears or N'Synch either!!!
I just wished that Matt Groening would focus on more projects (eg. Futurama)......-_-*SIGH* Those were the days......

I love this show.Well-drawn characters, dead-on dialogue,  literate allusions and a hilariously subversive perspective make this the best half-hour on television.  These talented people don't make a throw-away episode. Devastatingly observant and incisive, The Simpsons says more about morality and the virtues and downfalls of American society than any of those so-called "uplifting" or "life-affirming" shows (you know, they usually involve angels). Somehow this show manages to be both high-brow and low-brow at the same time.  The laughs come from all directions, and resonate for hours afterward.   Like other great television shows from The Mary Tyler Moore Show to Seinfeld, the best laughs come from strong witty characterization and a skillful ensemble cast.Though animated, the characters inhabiting Springfield seem more recognizable and alive than those in most live-action shows on television today.  I suggest that the Emmys add a category, in Phil Hartman's memory, for best voice performance and award it to a different Simpson's voice artist every year.  Then they can start from the beginning and go through the cast again.  Hank Azaria, Harry Shearer, Nancy Cartwright (ha ha), Dan Castellaneta, Julie Kavner....... these people voice vibrant human life into the Springfield community each week.I hope this show goes on forever at the same level of quality it has maintained for the past ten years.  Already classic television, The Simpsons deserves to be enshrined in television history.

Grew up with this show and remember sneaking to watch it, and now I have to keep my kids from watching it. It is definitely adult, and not for young kids however it isn't as bad as American Dad, or South Park. It is a show that survives by making paritys of current events using the Simpsons universe. However it has a atheist under tone with a lot of fun poked at Christianity.

When the core writing staff left The Simpsons for Futurama, the show changed beyond recognition. It's been all downhill since. This rating started much higher, but The Simpsons has been terrible for three times longer than it was good. Every year it stays on the air does more damage to the reputation it earned in those early seasons.

What can I say, The Simpsons is in my opinion, the greatest show of all time. The skits and jokes work on so many levels. Even the so-called "bad" episodes at least have a few great gags in them. I remember in most of primary school (I'm 14 now) I hated this show. I started liking this show pretty late compared to others around me. I would always criticise people for liking this show, saying that it was for idiots. This all changed one day when my best friend told me to watch it for once. Although I can't remember the episode I watched, I really enjoyed it. So I watched it for the next few nights. I was hooked! Sometimes I have this thing called the "Simpsons drought" where for some reason I don't watch it at all for maybe six months for no apparent reason. I finished my last drought early last year. Since then, I have tuned in every night at 6:00 (I live in Australia) and also tune into all the new episodes.The most obvious aspect of The Simpsons to fans is its unfortunate decline. It starts to get a bit rotten around late season 9 with a fair amount of good episodes in season 10 and beyond.Every episode revolves around a different character which makes it even more exciting. The characters are classics. I am so proud of the writers and directors of The Simpsons. Just for the record, this show is not just for children and teens. It is meant for every age group. Sometimes the writers like to get a little cheeky and add a little hidden joke about sex or something. Overall, this show is gold.I love The Simpsons!

I think for most of us that if The Simpsons ended far earlier it would be without question a 10/10 show, and really it pains me not to be able to credit the amazing early work with the score it truly deserves since i'm technically reviewing the show as a whole and not just the parts I want to.I'm a very lenient person, for many the series was killed at Season 9 Episode 2 why this specific episode? They took a beloved character and turned his entire backstory into a lie, 9 seasons leading up to this point and all ruined in one moment. I completely get why that is the turning point for many, and I agree that it definitely was a turning point. But I do think that there were still some great episodes after that right up until as far as season 14 admittedly they were becoming few and far in between at that point.Even listening to the dvd commentaries you can tell the difference, they lose several writers and contributers and they slowly seem to lose the enthusiasm as the series wears on. After all they're not up to about 30 seasons, and to be honest even I haven't been able to stick through all of the episodes just yet. I do recommend watching the episodes with commentary, it makes you appreciate the early episodes that much more. You even discover more jokes and references that are very obscure or hard to pick up on. It's for that reason that I still rate it this highly despite over half of the episodes being nowhere near that standard, and the fact that it would be criminal to rate it very low considering the amazing episodes it did give to us. In a perfect world it would have ended after season 14 and Futurama would never have been cancelled as early as it was.
The Simpsons started off amazing but after season 9 the show slowly got worse and worse. The newest episodes just don't have that zing the older ones did. That's why I give it a 6/10.

The Simpson's has gotten to a point where they have truly run out of ideas and instead of being funny it's just weird.My friend agrees with me that if they aged the characters, for example Bart and Lisa up to High school and Maggie into elementary school then the show would gain some freshness to it.Think about it, it could open the door for some new characters to come along and we could still have Principal skinner and Miss Hoover and Willie and the rest. But it could give them the opportunity to give the show some credibility in it's final years.I long for the day when I can say "The Simpson's Have got it back again!"

To me, it's hard to picture life without The Simpsons. All the sub-personalities that compose my dark side get permission to live and breathe when I watch that show. Everything that can possibly go wrong does, and it makes me so happy that it's happening to them instead of me. Of course, it's a bit disconcerting that Homer rarely even notices that things are constantly going wrong, but then, that frees him from taking responsibility. Oddly enough, he ends up taking responsibility by accident, which makes my inner Hallmark self happy. Marge is even more oblivious than Homer except when the day really needs to be saved, then suddenly she becomes supermom. Bart is busy trying not to be like Homer, which makes him twice as dangerous. Lisa is a perfect person, which makes it perfectly obvious how insane everyone else is. And Maggie is just an innocent baby... or IS she? I find most of the older episodes better than the newer ones, but it's still the Mad Magazine of the new millennium.

It's hard to express how I feel about "The Simpsons". It's perfect on nearly every level (the only thing holding it back from reaching perfection on every level is its slight lack of morality). The characters are very well developed, the jokes are incredibly witty, and the backgrounds and props are typically pretty well designed. So why did I give it only 9 out of 10? The decline of the show's quality is the answer. Just this year, our beloved show reached a new low. A low that can only be compared to Family Guy; possibly the worst prime-time animated series ever made. Here is a best-to-worst list of all the seasons so far:season 4, season 7, season 5, season 6, season 3, season 8, season 9, season 10, season 18, season 11, season 12, season 17, season 1, season 16, season 2, season 15, season 14, season 13, and season 19Thanks for reading my review.

when i come home in the afternoon, tired and feel like crud, there's only one thing that cheers me up: The Simpsons! is it just me or have t.v. shows reached an all time low, kid's programmes take over in the afternoon and then it's soap opera's in the evening. Comedy shows like Only fools and horses or Red Dwarf are getting less air time which leaves anyone with sense, drowning in a sea of bordness! This yellow family stay true to what television shows should be: enjoyable. marvellous puns, witty one liners and great story lines is what has kept this show running to it's 17th season. people of all ages are sucked in to the world of Springfield. Of course the characters, along with the family, are ones no-one forgets like: Chief Wiggum, Moe Syzlack, Ned Flanders, Barney Gumble and Nelson 'Ha,Ha' Muntz are to name a few, and it's never ending list of special guest stars like most recently, Ricky Gervais. People get so lost in the episodes that some even forget it's a cartoon. 'The Simpsons' has given hope to those who believe that T.V. will never return to What it once was. This truly is the Best thing on T.V.

While it may have started off as a small segment on the Tracey Ullman show, nobody back then would have predicted that the Simpsons would go on to be the longest running cartoon of all time.Everyone's favorite four fingered family (most notably Bart the underachiever and Homer the iconic blue collared slob) have had many adventures, and with the progression of the show we can look back and see many events and trends over the past decade encapsulated in some form of another, and see how things have changed in this decades episodes.Originally the show was a humorous look at everyday life in middle American society, covering topics like religion, politics, work, and family commitment. Most of the humor was in the creative writing, which was full of intelligent jokes that compelled you to watch and re-view again to spot more intricate details (As in memorable episodes like Bart the Genius, and The Head of Jebediah Springfield).However, as time progressed the quality of humor and story continuity started to break down. Somewhere towards the end of the 90's the show's focus shifted towards zany and unrealistic situations, and became more reliant on visual and crude 'below the belt' humor. Also noticeable was the shift away from family related scenario's in favor of following the exploits of Homer's get rich quick schemes and new one-episode jobs.As a fan of the show from it's origin, it saddens me to see how the newer writers have butchered what used to be a funny show.

One of the greatest and most influential comedy series in history.The (animated) life and times of the Simpson family - Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa and Maggie - living in Springfield. Hijinks ensue.Incredibly funny, with something for all ages. Kids can relate to the what Bart and Lisa get up to and for the adults there is the clever skits and dialogue.Very influential too. While there had been animated comedies before, these were largely cartoons, involving physical comedy (think Micky Mouse, or the Roadrunner). The Simpsons brought well thought out plots, dialogue and clever humour. These effects can be seen today, in every animated comedy show. You can't watch shows like Family Guy or South Park and not think "The Simpsons did it first!".

If not "The Simpsons" there surely wouldn't be such a great cartoons as "Family Guy", "South Park", and "American Dad".After so many years i still can't get enough of this family (other characters too). It's also amazing that creators still have new ideas, with so many episodes already aired, and with very big competition from other shows. I heard that people were complaining about last seasons, but i think that it's still an entertaining cartoon.I hope that they won't stop making it after releasing "The Simpsons Movie", cause it would be a huge waste.

There's a lot of hate coming from people on this site, giving the show 1 star by complaining about the newer episodes. Let's look at The Simpsons as a whole, rather than focusing on certain seasons.The characters are diverse, the writing is smart, and the satire is golden. You have a whole universe within the show of Springfield residents and mayhem that goes on. Within each episode, something happens that changes everything (Homer gets a pet monkey, Bart accidentally burns down the Christmas tree, etc.) and at the end, they have to resolve it. It paints a picture of upper middle class American families and how they deal with everyday situations. A lot goes on in Springfield and some of my favorites are voiced by Hank Azaria and Harry Shearer.Overall, The Simpsons is great entertainment that is family-friendly for the most part. There's a lot to like about this show and try to focus on it as a whole series because let's admit the newer episodes aren't as good but that doesn't stop it from being an amazing show!

I feel compelled to review The Simpsons even though this is one of hundreds of reviews and will therefore not be read. I feel compelled because I think The Simpsons is the best TV comedy series ever. To be sure there are many episodes from other comedy series that are funnier than many and perhaps even most Simpson episodes, but over the long haul -and it has been a very long haul- The Simpsons are on top the comedy meter.The early entries are not particularly funny. In fact, they are kind of odd, almost surreal. Even the appearance and animation were not yet up to snuff. The show had yet to find its stride. That took about a season. When the writers and animators finally got it going on all cylinders, the show was destined to become a classic. In my opinion it has long since left the comedies I Love Lucy, Seinfeld and Cheers behind. And aside from the somewhat annoying I Love Lucy, I thought those were great series.I do not know how many repeating characters The Simpsons have. Jimbo, Mayor Quimby, and one of my favorites, the always downtrodden Gil are just a few. There are two sets of twin sisters: Sherri and Terri who are classmates of Bart Simpson, and there are Patty and Selma, Marge Simpson's cigarette-puffing sisters.As I said, it took a season or so for the show to gain steam. It might be that in the last season or so it is beginning to lose steam. Lately there have been a few entries that have seemed a little flat and short of zing. After nearly 30 years, maybe the end is in sight. If so, it has been one helluva run.

"The Simpsons" never fail to make me laugh. I have been watching for years and I still get a kick out of even the re-runs.  Some people put this show down saying "It's a cartoon so it's a T.V. show"  This is incredibly wrong, in fact this is one of the most adult shows on T.V.  I don't think kids will get the references to "A Clockwork Orange" or "Vertigo".  Not only is this show hilarious but it deals with issues that other shows won't deal with like drinking and religion.  No other show shows drinking in such a bad light.  So I urge you see this show, for after one episode you to will be a "Simpsonian".

by now everybody knows or everybody should know that the Simpsons is the greatest television programme ever made, it's a fact, other excellent animated shows have come such as Family Guy and South Park but none of them have been able to match the intelligence the popularity or the hilarity of the Simpsons.The Simpsons has every ingredient of a great television programme the characters are believable, three dimensional and funny.The stories are sometimes surreal and wacky but mainly they are good story lines with one simple point at the centre of them and at the end the characters learn some what of a lesson .The animation itself is something of beauty seamless and complex but superbly done.so far there have been eighteen seasons of the Simpson's and people usually tend to focus on the negatives when talking about the new episodes, i personally think that the new episodes are quite funny and when they are compared to other comedy programmes on television they hold up quite well but when they are compared to the old episodes they arr not as funny but how can people expect a programme to be as fresh and new and funny in its eighteenth season as it was when it first hit our TV screens?I cannot wait for the release of the Simpson's movie by the looks of the new trailer the Simpson's feature length adventure will captivate all the jokes and visual puns that made us laugh so hard in the early days of the Simpson's. to conclude this is the best, funniest, smartest and most interesting television programme of all time and i don't think that's going to change any time soon.

I am well and truly devoted to The Simpsons, and I have every season on DVD boxsets. Whilst season 1 is low budget, from season 2 onwards you will notice the improvements that come with the success of the show. The characters develop and evolve, the plot lines become more exciting and wacky, and the jokes just get funnier! The best thing about The Simpsons is that it is perfect for family viewing, because kids will love it, and adults will get the jokes that the kids don't understand because they're too young, so I recommend this to anyone who wants to watch hundreds of episodes of comedy gold!

The show had an excellent start, and was great for many seasons. Simply put, it was iconic, quotable, and universally loved, as the show combined humour and meaning well.Some watchers argue that the show went downhill, rapidly after about the 10th, though I'd say that there were plenty of funny episodes right up to the late teens. While there were a few good moments in the 20s, this is when The Simpsons lost its charm. It went from a timeless, quirky show to something that we need a lot less of: a jumble of pandering and meaningless drivel. It tries too hard to be hip and it's a real shame to see voice actors go after so-called 'controversy' and a few, ignorant demands.The show just isn't what it used to be. It is no longer satisfying or funny, and it's time it was cancelled.

Judging TV shows is nothing like judging movies. The longer they go on, the more they change.When "The Simpsons" premiered in early 1990, there had been no animation in prime time since 1966. It was a huge pop culture phenomenon, but whether it would last or peter out in a few years remained to be seen. Nearly 20 years later, it is an institution. But it isn't the same show it was in 1990, 1995, or even in 2000. Because in those years it had a right to call itself the greatest show of all time. Now the show is like an old man trying to recapture the glory of his youth, and he just won't die."The Simpsons" of the 20th century was smart, witty, sophisticated, satirical, unconventional, and populated with memorable characters, laugh-out-loud situations and dialog, and a family dynamic that was neither idealized or vilified. Not even the best live-action sitcoms could beat it. Homer Simpson was a character like no other, a classic clown who tried hard to please his family but either screwed up or lost his temper. With the saint-like patience of his wife Marge, the moral center of the family, his arch, scheming, trouble-making son Bart, his sweet, gifted, and inquisitive daughter Lisa, and his baby daughter Maggie, and a cast of thousands (literally), the weekly trip to 742 Evergreen Terrace in Springfield, USA was an event, as if one was watching Babe Ruth hit one home run after another. But then something happened. "The Simpsons" of the 21st century is an embarrassing travesty.It is difficult to pinpoint the exact moment "The Simpsons" began its downhill slide, but Lisa's increasingly strident preaching <U+0097> manifested as early as season 4 but kept in check for a little while <U+0097> certainly didn't help. While Mike Scully allowed the episodes to become broader and allowed the tightness of the plots to slack, he was able to keep it consistently funny for awhile. But by season 11, you could see the show at its best one week and at its worst the next. Season 12 was even worse. By season 13, Al Jean, who had been with the show since day one, took over from Scully, and things have gotten even worse. Many gags are no longer funny in and of themselves. The plots are forgettable affairs that tend to evoke memories of older, better episodes. The show has sacrificed nonpartisan satire for leftist advocacy. The characters are stereotypes of stereotypes. Some recent episodes even stray into "so-bad- they're-hilarious" territory. What is worse is that not only do the writers seem to care, but they have responded to the increasing complaints by fans with unsubtle attacks on them. Yet they keep on with this horrific betrayal because it's still a healthy paycheck.Perhaps the show is a victim of its own success. They're far from the only game in town now. They have to compete with "King of the Hill," "South Park," "Family Guy" (the object of a silly and pointless feud), and now the return of "Futurama", not to mention dozens of other animated shows supposedly for adults, all of which exist because of this show's early success. The movie was the exception, though. It had real emotional pull, its jokes were mostly funny, and it made the characters seem interesting once again.When other hit shows go bad, they get canceled. If you truly love "The Simpsons," you will write to Fox and ask them to put the show out of its misery so that it can die with dignity.

I used to like this show. The key word there is I USED to like it, but it's gotten so stupid anymore that it's too late to kill it while it still has some dignity. When `The Simpsons' started out as a full-length TV show back in December 1989, it was very uncertain of itself. There were too roads it could take. It could be a children's lightweight entertainment series with morals and little or no humour. Or it could take the world by storm and become THE funniest show on television. After a while, it thankfully chose the latter. But between '89 and early '92 it remained as childrens fodder, (Homer's Oddesy, Moaning Lisa etc.) but it was finding its voice. Then for a few years it became an absolute laugh riot. Laughs just kept on coming and the familiar matters were consistently entertaining. It knew its limits and appealed to children and adults alike. Episodes like `Last Exit to Springfield' and `Marge in Chains' are good examples of this. Between '96 and '98 the show was still enjoyable, but hadn't quite rematched it's former peak of excellence. But the episodes were still moderately entertaining. But now, the show has reached rock bottom and it's still digging. Of course, there are one or two exceptions to the rule, (Trilogy of Error, etc.) The episodes are getting worse every single week with their ludicrous plots and sometimes-tasteless jokes. I think they fired all the good scriptwriters. Nowadays, they just resort to increasingly adulty sexual references and making fun of countries, races and ethics. Every week, they seem to have yet another celebrity voice. They are also making fun of actors, singers and other celebrities. In order to like these jokes you have to be familiar with the material, which most people are not.
The characters are losing their appeal aswell. Bart is now a spoilt brat. Homer is an annoying jackass. Lisa whines and complains a lot and Marge is <U+0085> Marge. The plot concepts are getting more and more far out as the weeks go by. Indeed, `The Simpsons' should have ended year's back, before it entered this downward spiral. It was once brilliant, but now it's just plain rubbish.

This is perfection my friends 18 years later and i'm still in love with the first king of animated comedy. Even if you are one of the five people who don't like The Simpsons you must respect it for it's originality, success, and the pure iconic way it has cemented itself into life.I believe this is the perfect mix of comedy it's wacky, over the top, character humour, that often has a dosage of random, political, and satirical humour it has something for everyone. The only thing i can complain about is that it is too obviously republican in it's messages and it picks sides instead of giving a middle alternative opinion. This show however has created a memorable family and over 500 memorable supporting characters everybody knows and loves. I hope in the future they do more episodes centering around supporting characters as they've been doing in later season with Willy, Principal Skinner, Moe Sizlak, Apu, etc. The Simpsons can always hold your attention with a hilarious plot but what makes them so great and so consistently funny is the fact that they have created some of the best, lovable, and most iconic, characters in television history. I personally love their Halloween specials entitled Treehouse Of Horror which is The Simpson's free pass to spoof three horror movies or stories and give hilarious spins on popular stories. In a certain few later seasons they seemed to go downhill i think because they were trying too hard to compete with Family Guy which i consider equal ground to The Simpsons. The one thing The Simpsons has over Family Guy is when they spoof something by making say Dracula Mr.Burns the character has relevance and originality while Family Guy just reenacts a scene and replaces the person with a Family Guy character.I think now that it's nearing it's nineteenth season it's soon time to end television greatest animated achievement and FOX's #1 show for years. I think given the movies success they have another few years to entertain us before going out on top. Matt Groening is a genius as is every writer and voice actor that brings these original, innovative, and lovable characters to life. The Simpsons will forever be a part of me and a part of TV milestones and achievements.

I really don't need to explain myself or the background of this show to state how epic it was and still is today. In it's early beginnings on the Tracy Ullman Show, no one ever knew that it would shape up to be one of the biggest television successes the medium has ever seen. Because of this, I wouldn't be surprised if fans still praise the Simpsons fifty years from now, since it made so many headlines. Furthermore, the show may be used to study how we entertained ourselves in the near future. Since everyone here has already contributed to what has made the Simpsons such an epic show, I will skip the details and backgrounds to get right to the point. At it's very best, the Simpsons was something that EVERY American HAD to watch. Everyone loved seeing their favorite dysfunctional family on-screen. Homer Simpson, the dimwitted but lovable father, is hilarious in his blunders (D'oh!). Marge is the voice of passion, and puts her family as top priority above everything else. Lisa is the smart and intellectual younger sibling, who often gets frustrated with her older brother. Bart is the infamous school hating prankster who devises a scheme or two to enrage Homer. The Simpsons, along with everything else in Springfield, has something that almost any television viewer can relate to. To summarize this up, it had witty, clever, sophisticated humor that made Matt Groening a multi-millionaire, pushing the Simpsons to the top of the list. Since it's debut, it has remained one of the most popular television families in America.The Simpsons however, isn't without it's flaws. I consider Season's two to eight to be masterpieces, and arguably the "Golden Age" of the Simpsons. Unfortunately, the writing has declined a bit thru the years, which made our beloved Simpsons not as well as they could be. The antics became more unrealistic to the point of being unfunny, and many famous guest stars would simply just pop in without any explanation or purpose. Furthermore the cast just didn't seem to care as much anymore. But as with everyone else, what comes up must come down. And the Simpsons is no exception, which is why I rated this a nine instead of a perfect score. That being said, it's still better than most modern television sitcoms. I just happen to be a Simpsons fan who has seen it evolve into the phenomenon it is today.So there you have it. Twenty years later and the Simpsons is STILL going strong. It may not be as culturally powerful as it was in it's heyday, but it's pretty obvious at this point that we will continue to discuss this show for generations to come. It has been awarded more times than ANY other show out there, and the Simpsons is simply a master of it's craft. Even if you aren't a fan of situational comedies or animation works of art, I highly recommend you watch this series at least ONCE. You can learn a lot from this show, even as it continues to laugh at politics, popular culture and even itself.Whether your a fan who is leaning towards the older seasons of the Simpsons or if your seeing it for the first time, the cultural awareness and fan-base surrounding this show proves that it won't be leaving our television sets anytime soon. If you can't notice the details, you aren't a television buff. Nine out of Ten.

"'The Simpsons' is rich in satire. Without question it is one of the most intelligent and literate comedies on television today. (We know that's not saying much but still...) It may seem incongruous to those who have dismissed it as a mere cartoon about an oaf and his family (and we've seen plenty of those) to say that the show is intelligent and literate, but attentive viewing reveals levels of comedy far beyond farce. We see layer upon layer of satire, double meanings, allusions to high as well as popular culture, sight gags, parody, and self-referential humor."From the opening introduction of "The Simpsons and Philosophy," edited by William Irwin, Mart T. Conard, and Aeon J. Skoble.That says a lot of what can be said about "The Simpsons." Matt Groening, the creator, had struck gold when he decided to introduce the world of Springfield, USA, and its most prominent citizens. (No, not C. Montgomery Burns; I'm talking about the Simpson family.) Duh. This is one of the richest, funniest, and damn entertaining cartoons on television right now. (I've heard it's on its way to Guiness and if it's already there, more power to Groening and his team of writers and animators.)Yes, we all know who they are by heart. There's Homer Simpson, the father and lackadaisical head of the family. Then there's Marge Simpson, the loving and supportive wife. Bart, the underachieving son (and proud of it, no less) who is also the town's little hell-raiser. Then there's Lisa, the brilliant, righteous daughter - the one who's not messing up her life. And lastly, there's little Maggie; silence is golden, isn't it? ("The Simpsons and Philosophy" contains a rather interesting essay about Maggie and why she matters.)I completed reading "The Simpsons and Philosophy" a couple of weeks ago and it contained a number of insightful essays on the underlying philosophical elements and satire running in the cartoon's undercurrent. It's impossible to watch "The Simpsons" and not get swept up in the numerous gags and references to popular culture.Everything gets parodied in some fashion, from "The Twilight Zone," "North By Northwest" (1959), "The Matrix," (1999), FOX's own "King of the Hill," "The Critic," "Night of the Living Dead" (1968), "Godzilla" (1954), and numerous others. It doesn't seem like anything is safe from Groening and his team of creators.I've seen them all, and it's easy to pick out favorites. Who can forget the oh-so-romantic story of how Homer and Marge first met, how Marge went to prom with (future) egomaniac Arty Ziff, and then drives along the highway to find Homer walking in the mud. Pure romantic. And also, who can forget that episode where Bart cuts the head off the statue of Springfield's founder, Jebediah Springfield? Or when Lisa gets a pony, forcing Homer to work two jobs? Or when sweet little Maggie is welcomed into the world? And last, who shot Mr. Burns?Each episode is colorful, taking to task a number of issues from gay marriage, to the NRA, to religion, to immigration, to the legalization of marijuana; it doesn't stop anywhere for anyone, and I anticipate "The Simpsons" on going a lot further than anyone could have ever imagined. It all comes together in a take-no-prisoners fashion that leaves you to question what's really going on inside Groening's head.And there's plenty of supporting characters to choose from: Smithers, Abraham Simpson, Patty and Selma Bouvier, Apu the Quik-E-Mart shopkeep, Moe, Dr. Hibbert, Chief Wiggum, the Flanders family, Principal Skinner, Carl, Lenny and countless others. Let's not forget the frequent guests, who have included The Clash or Jon Lovitz (as "Simpson"-produced acolyte Jay Sherman, "The Critic"), or the late Robert Stack, who reverted back to his "Untouchables" days and once voiced Eliot Ness-inspired prohibition officer Rex Banner."The Simpsons" is, hands down, my favorite, current-running animated program. In 50 years or so, it'll probably still be going and remain just as fresh as it was back in 1987 when it first appeared. Matt Groening, you are genius.

What stemmed from a series of primitive animated shorts featured on the Tracey Ullman Show has evolved into what is considered by many to be the funniest TV program in syndication. THE SIMPSONS' success was phenomenal during its first year, and has been TV's highest rated cartoon show ever since. Right from the get-go it formed a gigantic cult following, making Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa, and Maggie worldwide household names. And as anybody who watches the show will tell you: it's not hard to see why.THE SIMPSONS was truly ahead of its time. The surreal situations presented within are often driven by cleverly disguised scrutiny on both morality and the absurd, often hypocritical nature of the American people, but they all seem make sense in their own weird, Springfieldian way. However, aside from the biting satire and social commentary tucked away in every episode, the show boasts a brilliant sense of humor that has so far been unmatched by any other series. Each episode is crammed with so much hilarity that multiple viewings will always yield something new. But for those who aren't fond of watching reruns, have no fear! Since the jokes work so well on so many different levels, repeat viewings aren't at all boring.The town of Springfield, where THE SIMPSONS is set, is alone enough to capture one's interest. Springfield is a world all its own. It has every possible landform and climate in the books, and is home to a nuclear power plant, a television station, and a maximum security prison, yet it somehow effectively maintains that small-town atmosphere. The hundreds of residents within are as dynamic and lovable as they are hilarious and eccentric, and they are each given unique personalities, voices, and backgrounds. And with each passing episode, these characters continue to develop.It's great to see that after 13 years, Matt Groening's amazing cartoon is still going strong. In fact, it has actually improved with time and continues to get funnier and funnier with each passing season. I can honestly say that I hope this show goes on forever, and I know that I am not alone when I say that.

When this show debuted as a sketch on the Tracy Ullman show on the fledgling Fox network in 1987, it became so popular that Matt Groening was forced to create a tv show that became the longest running TV show ever, and the stuff of legend. D'oh!!!
