The simpsons tv show is super good later seasons kinda sucked but the first few wow it was great I loved it all unfortunately the treehouse of horror episodes getting kinda lame because it's not scary anymore that was a disappointment for me but wow overall simpsons is great.

I think this is the best motion picture, television show and animation ever. The freshness of the plot has remained consistent, the neverending gags never wear, and one could entertain himself for millenia watching repeats. For those few grains of the solar system of rice who haven't seen it, it features the lives and connected activities of the Simpson Family, and of the citizens of their town, Springfield. Springfield, an anytown U.S.A filled with stereotypes, satires and hilarious parodies of American characters, has a constant supply of adventure, comedy and all round glorious fun. The best thing about this series is it's failure to tire. Every new season brings with it a multitude of new fodder for fans and casual watchers alike, and who could miss such a modern day classic? The main characters, Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa and Maggie, the human members of the family, each have their own deep personality, gained from exerience within and without the show, much of it within. As we watch from the first shorts to the latest episodes and the movie, we see a progression in character unlike any other show. Not only is the irony of this progression next to the stillness of image (Maggie is still a baby after twenty years) magnificent, but characters develop phases, reflecting culture and views of the years they inhabit. In recent years mobiles and laptops have become more frequent, yet still the family cars remain the same 80s models they used to drive. The classic opening credits will never be forgotten. All in all, 10/10 easily.

You heard the title right. Those Simpsons may have predicted the future many times and got it right but there's one thing they lied about for 30 years, they're the longest running cartoon in the world. Now The Simpsons were on air for 30 years, much longer than cartoons now. But after some web surfing I found out that the original Looney Tunes shorts aired from 1930 to 1969, a total of 39 years(39 FRICKEN YEARS) that's 9 years more than the the Simpsons. And they're not even the second longest running cartoon. Scooby-Doo is 50 years old, Tom and Jerry are 79, and Mickey Mouse just celebrated his 91st birthday and the Simpsons are only 30. So they are 5th longest running cartoon. And to make matters worse everybody thinks they are instantly the best cartoon when they're not even close to being the best. Now cartoons like the Looney Tunes, Scooby-Doo, Tom & Jerry, Ren & Stimpy, even Spongebob can be qualified as the best but not the Simpsons. And to make matters even worse they are now inescapable. Everywhere I go there they are. Anything cartoon related in the Guinness Book of World Records deals with the Simpsons, when I look up longest running educational tv show on Google Images I see a picture of the Simpsons alongside Sesame Street( which is 100 times better), and when I look up best cartoon characters/ series, guess who's number one? That's right, Mr. Big Yellow Stupid head and his family. Now I will be fair on the first few seasons because without those we wouldn't have the Shinning or the glorious Steamed Hams. But after that it took a turn for the worse. Everything got bad, Bart forgot how sincere and kind he was and turned into an all out jerk, Marge and Lisa( who I actually like) were voted the worst Simpsons characters, Homer doesn't give a dang about his life and is as dumb as a doorknob, the violence level boosted by a lot, and they are just not funny anymore. If you agree with me then don't stay silent, let your voice be heard. Spread the truth. Start a riot, invade Fox studios, and end this abomination before they go on forever. Hurry before it's too late.

Are the later episodes of "The Simpsons" a notch below earlier ones? Yes, but even lesser episodes improve on repeat viewings (and between Sky One's current screening of 19 episodes a week (you heard me, NINETEEN) and BBC2's further weekday airings, you have plenty of chances to view them again).Do the characters go a bit too far sometimes? Yes, but with Al Jean taking over from Mike Scully the signs for the new season are good (and in fairness to Scully, he did introduce some more continuity - just as Lisa's vegetarianism is an ongoing thing, so is Apu's love life and Barney's staying on the wagon... I'm glad they realise alcoholism isn't funny).Do guest stars ruin the episodes they're on? With the exception of Mel Gibson, no (I even liked the one with 'Nsync).Has "The Simpsons" degenerated as much by its thirteenth season as "The Flintstones" had by its sixth and final season? Let me put it this way - have any aliens become regular cast members (and no, Kang and Kodos don't count)?When it ends, it'll have its share of weak episodes, but all long-running shows do, and no one will remember anything but the long-raning success it was/is. Ultimately stories like "Insane Clown Poppy" and "Beyond Blunderdome" are the equivalent of a few rotting apples in the barrel; I haven't mourned "Seinfeld," but I'll mourn this.

The Simpsons is possibly and probably the biggest show on Television, and has been for the past 14 - 15 years or however long it's been running. Sure, there's all that stuff about Reality Shows but The Simpsons is still talked about a sure lot. Earlier seasons have shows re- run on UPN channel, while new ones play on Fox about every Sunday night. The older ones are classic. Everyone in the cast is excellently scripted, with such an amazing flow of humor and such a way of making you laugh very hard. Unfortunately, the new season(s) seem to be falling short, and are just relying on old, dying humor. The voice- acting all around is amazing, with very big attention to details (little grunts, etc.). As I mentioned before, the script is excellent, really packing a punch in each episode. Sure the new ones aren't doing quite so well as the old ones, but the script is still solid. The Simpsons is probably one of Television's biggest shows in History, and in a sense it rightfully deserves to be. However, it's getting old and should be cancelled soon, but the older ones are great to just sit back, leave your brain at the door and enjoy. 9/10

The Simpsons is an exceptional animated TV sitcom, still going strong and making TV history after a good 17 years (and still guaranteed to be on the air for a few more years), with an animated feature film also to look forward to in 2007. This show stars Homer Simpson (voiced by the great Dan Castellaneta) and his family Marge, Bart, Lisa, and Maggie and their life in the town of Springfield (it's a running joke that we don't know where in the US they are located). While the show began very seriously, after a few seasons, it started to become a running gag, relying more on guest stars such as N'Sync and movie actors to keep the show fresh. Both the serious earlier seasons and the slapstick later seasons are fresh and hilarious, though in their different ways. Other supporting characters include Grampa, Krusty the Klown, Groundskeeper Willie, Mayor Quimby, Patty & Selma Bouvier, Nelson Muntz, The Flanders, Ralph Wiggum, Moe Szyslak, Chief Wiggum, Apu, Comic Book Guy, Montgomery Burns, Waylon Smithers, Ned Flanders, Kent Brockman, Rev. Lovejoy, Principal Skinner, Edna Krabappel, Milhouse Van Houten, among MANY MANY others. I look forward to this show staying on for many more years.

The 90's. the simpsons were a college rock n' roll American laugh fest. The jokes were witty, they possess their unique style. truly it was understandable why it spawned so many seasons. The best were Seasons 2,3 and especially 5. There was so much memorable classic humor. Like on season 4 with Homer's hilarious day off church in Homer the heretic, Season 5's Boy Scoutz in da hood & And Homer rising to a god on Season 6 "Homer the great". But now it has all changed. Season 12 was The family's final moments And as the unlucky "season 13" Is let out, Me and my family have all been noticing a depressing change in the Quality of Humor used. It is, in fact depressing to watch the new episodes. When i hear another "Lame" joke. if My friends and family hear someone say a lame joke, We say that "Is a new simpson joke" because that is the New nature of the 13+ season simpsons. " gay this, gay that, Finish it! What are you a lesbian? " That's the only sort of things i here when i turn on the TV at 7:00 to everyones favourite cartoon family. Right now they are playing all the new episodes here. The simpsons have also lost their old standards. It's a lot more dirty now. i'll state the following things wrong with the new episodes: Characters use to much expression in their voice, Homer and bart are too outgoing, There is a lot more comical behaviour, Homer's shaking fist gimmick is lame, Marge talks a lot more and tries to be funny, everybody acts a lot smarter, Jokes from old episodes have been used again, Too much singing, too much crying, They're ALWAYS trying to be funny, The episode endings are real cheap and The situations they face are out of the original, im not done. The picture is too clear and perfect. Homer tries to live up to his stereotype and the facial expression aren't wacky enough. (If you want to see my idea of a funny facial expression, on season 5 "homer goes too college", look at Homer when he's holding the Toast.) People are just watching new episodes and not noting that they aren't funny because 12 funny seasons have made it second nature to believe Simpsons are funny. Soon they will realize it is now lame. Either rehire the old writers and artist, Use the ideas from Simpsons comics or just stop making them. It's now officially dead. It just will take a while too realize it. I loved the old seasons. too bad i'll never be seeing another funny episode of The Simpsons again.

I still can't believe this show is still going on. I heard rumours it could possibly end one-day, but that has yet to happen. It really should because the show today does not feel like the show we all enjoyed back in the beginning. The first several seasons of The Simpsons were the best. Many of the episodes were such classics!!! you could watch it more than a dozen times, yet still not get bored. That's how awesome the show actually was. What made this show strikeout were its characters - there were several of them. Each had a purpose, and we all had a favourite. Many of the favourite ones are Homer, Bart, Lisa, Marge, Maggie, Mr Burns, Ned, Apu, Skinner, Ralph etc. But I'm sure the most favourite ones among the fans were either Homer or Bart. This is a show where the entire family can sit down and watch. It's also a show which many kids seem to enjoy despite some of the many things within The Simpsons deeming unsuitable: that's one of the main reasons why this show was remarkable in the first place. I remember coming back home from school, and the first thing I would see on television is The Simpsons. I live in the United Kingdom, and as a child I would see The Simpsons on BBC. I didn't have Sky back then, but as soon as I did, one of the first things I did after coming back home from school was to watch The Simpsons on Sky One. There were several episodes on there simultaneously: it was like a dream come true. I enjoyed several of these episodes so much that I would eventually record them on my Sky player, so I could watch them. However, the same can't be said once the years rolled by. Since the start of the 21st century, the show started to go downhill, and the episodes started to get not just boring but very boring. You can tell, intuitively, just how poor a lot of the episodes from the later seasons had started to become. They were just nowhere near as good as those from the earlier seasons. I know there will be a difference in opinion, but I'm sure most will agree. Some of the episodes from the later seasons were fine, but not the majority of them for sure. The perfect time to have ended this show was right after The Simpsons Movie was released, which was a success. But I knew that wasn't going to happen considering how popular the show still was; how much a success the movie was; and how much money it was still making. You can't blame the producers really. I heard rumours that it will likely end after the 30th season, and I hope it's true because it has gone on for far too long. Also, I'm amazed the characters in Simpsons never seem to grow-up: that's what I truly find remarkable about this show.

It is well known that The Simpsons is the greatest animated show ever to be broadcast on television, and in writing a review of it I understand that I run the risk of only boringly reiterating what everyone already knows. There have never been any television shows that have approached the sheer brilliance of a show like The Simpsons, although I will admit that one show, Family Guy, possesses a level of utter hilarity and quality that it is more than able to hold its own against The Simpsons, although even that excellent show is able to surpass the great Simpson family.Homer Simpson is arguably one of the most entertaining and original characters ever broadcast on television, and is without a doubt the heart of the show, with Bart coming in a VERY close second and Marge, Lisa, and Maggie, as well as the mind bogglingly extensive list of side characters, are there to balance it out. There is a huge hierarchy of characters that are involved in show after show of brilliant comedy and entertainment. As they said in a song in a recent show, `Have no fear, we've got stories for years.' From the way that they've been going for more than a decade and continue to provide tremendously superior entertainment compared to all of the slop that pollutes the television airwaves these days (Survivor, The Weakest Link, Temptation freaking Island (by FAR one of the stupidest things I have ever imagined being aired on mainstream television), The Real World, Sorority Life (yes, I know it hasn't aired yet, but it was filmed about two blocks from where I'm sitting right now, and I have no doubt in the world that it is going to be a ridiculous mess), and basically everything else on MTV that's not The Osbournes).I could on for hours about the disturbingly lengthy list of complete trash that is regularly broadcast on mainstream television these days, and it will clearly a sign of human kind's descent into barbarism if we ever witness the cancellation of The Simpsons in the midst of all of this crap. We can only hope, then, for the sake of humanity, that the show will be aired indefinitely.

We all seem to know America's favorite family. A family that has influenced so much of pop culture. We've all been familiar with The Simpsons and their voices, along with the fictional town of Springfield. It will be Halloween next month, and it would still be really cool to dress up as a Simpsons character. However, one thing I've been hearing about on the internet and through a lot of your comments is the show isn't as good as it used to be, that a lot of us prefer the older episodes. I've been hearing it for many years as most of us seem to prefer the episodes before 2000, there have been a few good episodes since then, and even a lot of the newer episodes aren't bad, just not as good, memorable, or funny. About all this, I once saw a quick YouTube clip with Justin Bieber in it as he was in an episode and the top comment said, "R.I.P. The Simpsons 1989-1998." The show was at it's best during that time and it seems like it was at it's peak during the mid '90s like when they showed the "Who Shot Mr. Burns Episodes." I even bought a DVD at the Super Market a year ago which shows the Treehouse of Horror episodes from Seasons 5, 6, 7, and 12. While Treehouse of Horror for Season 12 isn't bad, it's not as good as those other ones where they show things like Homer Simpson going into 3D World and show things like Groundskeeper Willie being in all the kids nightmares. I have to tell you, those episodes don't get old. It is still nice to watch them years later. I remember like 15 years ago when the show was on 3 times a day. There used to be what they called double d'ohs of laughing I think at like 6:30 and 7:00 on Fox. They'd also show an episode at 11:00 PM on Fox. My oldest sister even liked a couple of guys that were obsessed with The Simpsons. However, this show lost its appeal and most of us probably don't care to see a lot of the newer episodes. I think Fox should start showing more of the reruns from when this show was popular. The episodes we're more familiar with as you can Google search an episode and be able to read all about it on Wikipedia. Most of the time when you look ahead on Tivo of the episodes that will be airing, most of them are the newer episodes. I think Fox would get more viewers if they started to show the old episodes. What makes this show good, we got to know basically all the characters in Springfield. The episode had interesting plots and the beginning of a lot of episodes often times started out with a different plot making the main plot of the episode unpredictable from the beginning. It was also a really funny show. Now, it seems like the show is trying to be funny but they're running out of ideas and humor. Overall, I'd give this show a 9/10 as it used to be really good and will forever remain a classic.
....or pitifully out of touch political pandering. One of the two. Not funny either way. Honestly it's just a series of tropes and cliches. I would strongly recommend people never watch this show.

I rate The Simpsons a 6/10, why? It is because from Seasons 1-10, they were classic, however, in more recent years most episodes were in one way or another a partial repeat of earlier ones, or just plain bad ideas.My belief is that everything had been done by The Simpsons, or everything that can come to mind for a show for audiences 14 or older.Repeatetive lines and events make the once great animated comedy a bore.Things such as Lisa's birthday, which she has had 3, and The Simpsons going to another continent, South America, Africa, Asia twice, Europe several times.The now annoying personality of characters such as Marge and Lisa and the seemingly Bart and Homer based new episodes have created a Simpsons for a new generation, children who didn't grow up in the 90s can enjoy Simpsons on the same level as those who did. However, as a complete overlook, in overall standard, the old and new episodes judged as one, I can safely say it's a modest 6.

Frankly, I agree with all the more negative reviews of this show. Yeah, there was a time when The Simpsons was the funniest show around, but let's be honest. When's the last time anyone watched The Simpsons and laughed WITH it?Personally, I stopped watching it after they killed Maude Flanders off the show. I know it's just a cartoon, but that was still a terrible way to do it. In fact, The Simpsons' ratings seriously dropped after that episode. And I've noticed that now the more celebrities there are, the wacker the episode is. (That episode with *NSYNC reminded me why I stopped watching it in the first place.)The chalkboard gags aren't even creative any more, the episodes feel like someone wrote them in about two minutes, and...you know, there should be a rule that Dan Castellaneta should never be allowed to write an episode again. There was one episode he wrote with his wife (from Season 11 or 12) called "Days Of Wine And D'ohses", and if it were up to me, I would have fired him for that if he didn't do so many voices.So in the end, The Simpsons WAS one of the best shows around, but it sure isn't now. If you think it is, quit living in the past.

The Simpsons is one of those rather rare TV shows that will appeal to every member of the family. It has jokes for both adults and children and generally there is a very good moral at the end of each story.First of all we have Homer. He is fat,lazy, and weak willed but beneath it all he is a good man whose heart is always in the right place. He loves Marge and the kids and despite being tempted more than once to stray he always stays faithful.Now Marge, she is the sensible calming influence, always ready to fear the worst and married to Homer that is usually the case. You often wonder why she married Homer but if she hadn't, Homer would have turned out like Barney.The kids are complete opposites, Bart is a very horrible little boy always getting into trouble as opposed to Lisa who is the straight A student. Maggie is only a baby.As with all great comedy shows the Simpsons benefit from a first rate cast of secondary characters. The religious Flanders, the washed up clown Krusty and my favourite Chief Wiggum. (In the UK the police are sometimes unkindly referred to as the Pigs, has anyone else picked up on Wiggums nose ?) With actors, politicians and sportsman lining up to appear on the show I am sure this will continue for another 20 years.Favourite episode - Santas little Helper, when Homer walked through the door on Xmas eve, broke because he hadn't got his bonus, with an abandoned greyhound he was in tears. Then Lisa said what a wonderful Xmas present the dog was for all the family .... I had a tear in my eye as well - that is the true meaning of Xmas.

I am mainly reviewing this up to the 7th year(and I own the sets up to and including that one). I will admit that the very first of this wasn't all great... drawings were crude, it was "messy", and it leaned towards the sappy/hokey on occasion... but it did have moments. And right after, from the beginning of the second season, this was an amazing show. The animation got to be rather good just about immediately. The writing more often than not packed with social commentary, sometimes silly, though with little to no exceptions, funny. This is consistently well-done, almost entirely invariably. The references(to everything in and outside of showbiz, within the last several decades) are typically well-done, and this was self-aware and sophisticated. The characters are relate-able, flawed and credible. The comedy usually steered clear of toilet humor and material tends to go for the smart, satirical gag. The show maintained a high level until the eighth or so, when it started to go downhill. Since then it merely seems to grow worse with each successive effort. The jokes(which really aren't worth much to begin with, even the few of them that aren't solely based on public humiliation, other disgusting stuff and/or physical pain/abuse) have multiple punchlines, go against the canon for no good reason, and they practically spell out how sucky this has gotten. The DVDs hold special features such as animatics, alternate language reels, deleted scenes, a commentary track for every individual collection of 22 minutes of fun(with relevant people who worked on them, and, if not always, actors), and crew people either sharing inside information or introducing the extras/episodes, and they tend to be worth your time. I realize that my criticism of the recently aired of this might lead some to avoid this altogether, so I suggest anyone considering it to not do so(and heck, if you do like even the new, have at it), or you would give up many hours of hilarious, finger-on-the-pulse cleverness. And that would be downright nutty. I heartily recommend this to anyone who enjoys laughing and has enough of a base of knowledge of pop culture and American society from the 80's through the 90's. 8/10

I was born the same year The Simpsons aired for the first time. Eight years later, I became acquainted with the show and since then I have been unable to stop watching it, even when I happen to see the same episode four or five times. Such is the charisma of what has to be the finest animated program to have ever come from America (or any other country, for that matter).In case someone wasn't familiar with the series (though it is unlikely), here goes: the show is set in an average US town, called Springfield. That's where the Simpsons live: Homer (Dan Castellaneta) is a lovable doofus who spends his days working at a nuclear power plant and drinking beer; his wife Marge (Julie Kavner), best known for her scary hairstyle, looks after their three children, quintessential TV brat Bart (Nancy Cartwright), saxophone-playing Lisa (Yeardley Smith) and the perpetually two-year old Maggie. Around them, dozens of other characters cross paths in often hilarious ways, exposing all things bad about being American.It is that satirical aspect, paired with endless pop-culture references, that have made The Simpsons a benchmark in intelligent entertainment (a paradox in several US sitcoms). Okay, so the quality of the gags has started to fade recently, but with the first 200 episodes or so being nearly flawless it is easy to forgive these shortcomings. The same goes for the characters: overblown caricatures they may be, but as long as the show exists the likes of Mr. Burns, Moe Szyslak, Seymour Skinner and Krusty the Clown will remain among the funniest creations of American television (although Homer and his immortal "D'oh" will never be surpassed). And while the satire is a little weaker nowadays, the stream of film references is as strong as ever: Pulp Fiction, The Godfather, Planet of the Apes, Citizen Kane, Raiders of the Lost Ark... There is plenty to be enjoyed by film buffs, who will also have fun recognizing the numerous celebrity voices that keep appearing in the series. Personally, my favorites are Mel Gibson as himself and Kelsey "Frasier" Grammar as the evil Sideshow Bob.And let's not forget the iconic opening sequence, which features Danny Elfman's most recognizable and instantly memorable piece of music.In short: no matter what weaknesses new episodes might have, The Simpsons remains essential viewing, as it usually packs more wit and brilliance in 22 minutes than most movies manage in two hours. 'Nuff said.
The Simpsons first 9 Seasons are definitely one of if not the best television show ever made.

"THE SIMPSONS," in my opinion, is an absolute FOX classic! I've seen every episode, and I really enjoy it. It's hard to say which episode is my favorite. However, I think it's always funny when a mishap occurs. I always laughed at that. It was a shame that Mrs. Flanders (voice of Maggie Roswell) passed away. Other than that, it's nice that just about every main character has stayed with the show throughout its entire run so far. It seems that no one stays with a show throughout its entire run. Everyone always gives a good performance, the setting is spectacular, everything about the characters is well-done, and the writing is always very strong. In conclusion, I hope this show will always live on in syndication when it finishes its run on FOX.

I dont know how many episodes I have seen(Almost every one)and I really love Simpsons.

1.Homer 2.Fat Tony 3.Bart 4.Maggie 5.ApuSEE it!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

When the Simpsons first started in 1990 the show was totally awesome, sure the animation the voices and lots of stuff was somewhat different but the stories were creative and funny. That kept them going for about 10 seasons. After season 10 I think the show has gradually lost it's touch. Matt Groening himself even said as the show continues it get's even harder to come up with new original stories. The show isn't even as funny as it was in 1990. In 2006 it still has many funny moments but it feels like "so what" After saying that the Simpsons is still one of my all time favorite shows.But because it's lost its touch, I give it a 7.

I really love THE SIMSPONS - I've seen every episode. I like the crude animation and Homer's Walter matthau Type voice of the first season to the technical brilliance of the later series, you never get tired of watching episodes over and over again -if you do your not a true fan- there are laughs a plenty in every episode. After over 14 years & over 300 episodes you may think that the series is getting stale, the jokes are getting thinner & the stories are getting more desperate - But you'd be WRONG, The series is better now than it's ever been, The actors (castellanta,cartwright,kavner,smith,shearer & azaria are as good as ever & deserve a lot more money than they're probably getting) HERE'S TO THE NEXT 14 YEARS & 600 EPISODESMy rating 10/10 (just brilliant)
This show is the show of my childhood, this will go down as the best TV series ever made!

What was once one of the greatest shows out has suddenly become a waste of the 8:00 sunday half hour. The Simpsons started out as a skit on The Tracey Ullman back when the FOX network got started in 1986-87, IT SUCKED and the characters and drawings looked like S***marks on paper. Then Came 1989, Still the show sucked but it was bound to get better. That was when Season No. 3 Came. The 1991-92 season, now that was when the show gained it's fame and Simpson Mania was at it's summit worldwide.This was the official show of the 90's. Nobody could deny that for a fact. Especially during the early to mid 90's when the show was No. 1 on sundays. Now sure during that time the show was on thursday and had to compete with Cosby and NBC'S Lineup. But it was bound to thrive and It did.The Last great season for this show I have to say was 1998-99. But after the new writers, or whatever it is, and after the tragedy of Phil Hartman, the show finally began to plummet.I would have to say that this show is getting worse year after year. The worst year being 2001-02 when the show only relied on guest starring celebrities like Carmen Electra, but all im sayin' is to either hire new writers of just cancel the show. This show had it's time in the 90's why keep it now. In fact you what would be better. BRING BACK FAMILY GUY AND PUT Them on at 8pm sunday. That show was better. CANCEL THE SIMPSONS!!

Long Live the King!It is with great sadness that I have reached the conclusion that what was once one of the greatest shows on television has run its course. Recent episodes have traded more on stupidity and slapstick, ignoring the satiric, incisive writing that made it great. Now that I've taken off my rose-colored glasses, I can see that the show was in decline as early as the twelfth season, and possibly a little before.This is still one of my all-time favorite shows; I won't let the mediocre writing of its declining seasons tarnish my memory - unless they KEEP ON with the mediocrity and decline, instead of going for a graceful finish. The Simpsons marketing is so powerful at this point that they don't NEED an active TV series in order to sell merchandise, so please, Fox, surprise me and make a good decision, here. Kill the series and put it in re-runs in the usual time slot. Show the entire series, from the very beginning, and show it in order. I believe it would be a HUGE ratings-getter, even with the DVD sets appearing sporadically.The show may die, but the Simpsons will live forever.
I connect this series with my childhood but In the latter seasons it was ruined by attempting to be modern and relatable to kids of the modern era. It's a series with an identity crisis

The Simpsons is the best show to ever hit the air. Who would of thought that FOX's most popular and successful program started out as one minute filler for the Tracy Ullman Show? Not me.The best character of all has to be none other than Homer. He is dumb, childish, and at times prone to accidents. Homer is like a giant child with a temper.The Simpsons is the best.

I think "The Simpsons" have been a great comedy since it was created. It's really normal to think that there are a time-limit with all the series, but I think they are great today. In Spain we get the new chapters every three years and I really missed the new ones till we could watch them in TV. We are suffering even more and more changes in the world and I like a lot to see them captured in that "particular" family since 1989, when I was only seven years old. I hope them to continue more and more years. Now we have similar series like "Family Guy", great too, with their particular style but showing that this formula have broken that time-limit of life till today. I like some of them too, but I think "The Simpsons" are of unequaled style which I like the most. I hope them to continue for too many years. I really hope to.
Simpsons you were a 10 when I was growing up. As your jokes got more adult and topics more contemporary through the years I thought I would like you more. Sadly you got too big for your boots

There have been a lot of reports recently about the fate of The Simpsons. With Disney acquiring Fox, the longest-running scripted programme in television history is only becoming more prosperous, and it's looking increasingly-likely that the show will continue to run and run well into the next decade. But should it keep going?The Simpsons is my favourite television programme of all time. That sentence used to be perfectly acceptable, but now it must come with a caveat - a tiny asterisk that won't make people think I'm lying or stupid. Here goes: The Simpsons is my favourite television programme of all time**as long as I pretend it ended before the year 2000.Yes, it's fair to say The Simpsons' classic years came to an end around the year I was born. 1997 saw the premiere of such classic episodes as 'The Itchy & Scratchy & Poochie Show', 'Homer's Phobia', and 'Grade School Confidential'. It also saw the premiere of 'Homer's Enemy', a darkly funny and self-referential episode that some people consider the start of the decline (I'm not one of them; the twisted tale of Frank 'Grimey' Grimes is one of the most transgressive stories the show ever told). From there, each season got progressively worse, reaching mediocrity by Season 13 and hitting an all-time low during the HD era. It's astonishing to think a show as beloved and iconic as The Simpsons has been declining in quality for twenty years now - twice as long as the classic years lasted.While America's favourite yellow family still has loyal viewers, it's fair to say the audience has decreased steadily. Ten years ago, the show averaged around seven million viewers in the US. Today, that number has dropped to below three million. Streaming and online services may have taken some of the audience, but even taking that into account, modern Simpsons has lost a hell of a lot of viewers. Personally, I haven't regularly watched the antics of Homer and family in nearly fifteen years; once the HD era kicked, any interest I had in the show went out the window. The animation was flat and boring, the voice acting was disinterested, and the stories grew increasingly tedious and repetitive. Truthfully, I couldn't even tell you the last modern Simpsons episode I watched.All of which brings me back to my original question. Should The Simpsons keep going for years to come?Surprisingly, I think my answer is still yes.Putting aside the fact that The Simpsons is still worth more than sense dictatses, I'm also just not sure I want to live in a world without it. No matter how mediocre it gets, there's still something comforting about knowing Bart and Lisa Simpson are still on TV. This is a show that's been on television since 1989. I was born with The Simpsons. Raised on The Simpsons. Got through my awkward teenage years with The Simpsons (admittedly, that wasn't the main activity that got me through my awkward teenage years). The thought of it one day ending still seems impossible.The future of The Simpsons is far from certain. Will Disney continue to produce it once they've taken over Fox and achieved Hank Scorpio-style world domination? Will the cast still be able to do the voices in a few more years? Julie Kavner is so croaky she's barely audible these days. Now that they've reached thirty seasons, how many more milestones are they prepared to hit? Forty seasons? One-thousand episodes? The last show still being produced on Earth before global warming wipes us out in (insert terrifyingly-soon year here)?Way back in 2002, the episode 'Gump Roast' ended with the song 'They'll Never Stop the Simpsons', which featured Marge becoming a robot and Bart owning a bear. While the writers haven't quite scraped those barrels, we've had Moe owning a talking dish cloth and a bizarre return to Kamp Krusty, so who knows just how many more stories the writers can squeeze out of everyone's favourite yellow family? I won't be watching, but I'm fully behind The Simpsons carrying on infinitum. After all, in life there are only three uncertainties: Death, taxes, and Homer Simpson injuring himself under wacky circumstances.

The early episodes were definitely hits (good ones...)Around 1997 is when it started to suck, now the recent episodes are just terrible...Too bad to see a show once in it's prime greatness to go down to stupid nothingness...Oh well, at least it made history with 300+ episodes and to be the longest running cartoon ever...too bad most of those 300 episodes suck. =/I doubt too that FOX will ever cancel it, this is one of FOX's FEW staple shows, heck, it's one of FOX's only shows that isn't a reality show!If you haven't seen the show yet (which I highly doubt) but if you haven't then watch the earlier episodes for some good laughs but kinda steer clear of the recent ones...

Well, in my opinion, the show was much, much funnier when the plots were somewhat believable. The show now is merely a collection of gags. Now everyone of them acts like goofballs.Some of my favorites are the episode with Ringo Starr and when Marge works at the nuclear plant. the Simpsons is a truly excellent show.  ALMOST everything goes right.  the show has a few bad episodes and a few awesome ones.  Homer is hilarious and i like him and Bart.  Most of the other characters are really cool and funny.Overall the whole show is mainly jokes and they are mostly funny.  Rating *** out of ****.

It's 2006. Everyone is talking about the Simpsons now. Mainly because of the teaser that premiered last week. Even the people who thought the Simpson's "sucked" tuned in. That's their own opinion. I'm sick of everyone saying how The Simpson's suck. Sure,the jokes are a little less funny, but just because it's not as funny doesn't mean bashing it all day. I recall one message board post saying they were beating a dying dog to death by keeping the show running. Wow, that's cold. If you ask me, The people complaining about the Simpson's sucking are doing more than you would hope to be legal to that poor dead dog. I love the Simpson's. I admit the best episodes were in seasons 5-9, but lay if i don't get every Simpson's season after it's over. If you don't like the Simpson's, Don't come here. The end.

The other day I realized that quite often, in trying to make a point, I would start a sentence with "It's kind of like that Simpsons episode, you know where ...."   This show really has managed to hit the mark on just about every aspect of modern American culture, and to make fun of it.  Like the time when they're in the future and Home and Marge are watching TV, and she remarks: "Fox became a hardcore porno channel so gradually I barely even noticed."  Ouch--nails the channel for all the sleazy fare they put on.  Or when Sideshow Bob yells out as he's going to jail (pre-Clinton) "You can't keep me in jail forever! Someday a Democrat will be President and then I'll be out on the street with all my criminal friends!"  Hilarious stuff.
Really the most compelling part of the show is the rich menagerie of characters the writers have been able to produce.  It's kind of like a modern day, funnier version of Dogpatch.  Characters like Dr. Hibbert, with his inane chuckle and ridiculous Cosbyish sweaters, or Patty and Selma, the DMV workers from hell, or Cletus the slack-jawed yokel, Dr. John Frink--a total take off of Jerry Lewis in the Nutty Professor, the list just goes on and on.  And of course, at the center of all the mania is Homer Simpson, my nomination for man of the decade; so impossibly stupid that even though a cartoon, no matter how foolish or idiotic we men may behave, we can always say, "well at least there's somebody dumber than me." It sometimes falls flat or rings hollow, but only rarely (the time Marge considers having an affair.  Marge?  I don't believe it)  But there are very few TV shows that have been on for as long and that have remained as fresh and consistently funny as this one.  How many shows can you say have been able to include references to both the profound, as in "Lord of the Flies", Poe's "The Raven," and the popular: Star Trek, Raiders of the Lost Ark? They come at such a machine gun pace, it's hard to keep up. 
Hope it keeps on going, though it really lost a big chunk of its charm with the passing of Phil Hartman (we all lost).  Without Troy McClure and Lionel Hutz, something definitely missing.

The Simpsons started off with the antics of Bart and slowly drifted over to Homer being the center of attention. I first liked the Simpson's because they were a primetime cartoon.  They were saying profane words that any cartoon hadn't said before,  but they still managed to pull it off so it was funny unlike some of the other run of the mill mature cartoons.  People have grown to love some the characters during the show's 14 season run, including my self.  I think the show will continue to make people laugh for another 14 seasons possibly more. :-)

I used to like the Simpsons during their first seven years on TV, but now, especially with new episodes, it just seems so much annoying rather than funny.  It's always the same d'oh for Homer, the same 'mmm...' for marge, the same 'hokily dokily' for Flanders, basically it's just the same plot, which makes the show even more annoying.  And here in Montreal, we get it twice a day on weekdays on channel 22, 45, and 49, and  once a day on weekdays on channel 5, and 13. five times on weekends on channel three (including the new episodes) four times on weekends on 45 and 49.  Too much of it makes this show possibly the most annoying show ...EVER!

Who doesn't like The Simpsons? This adult cartoon (yes, it is mainly for adults) is one of the best cartoons out there. The Simpson's began in 1987 or 1989. What had it's origins as a late night controversial adult animated television series has now become wildly accepted for both young and old alike. The series follows the lives of the Simpson family and their awesome community (that I would love to live in). The town is Springfield and there never is a dull moment. Whether it's Bart getting in trouble at school, or Homer screwing up in some way or another, there is a reason this series has been running so long. The series really brings out the human condition and many other aspects such as television, society and culture. Creator Matt Groening based the Simpson family on his own family and Bart was to portray Groening. The series has won several awards and in today's world it is a nice escape to watch the Simpsons and realize things aren't really as bad as they seem. - Asif Zamir

This title which is not already finished is a brilliant art of Matt Groening.It is a great achievement which i saw when it first came out here in Greece.In my opinion,i liked the particular title because it is funny,it explains and informs us many historical things of America and it warns about dangerous things in our daily life.Also,some of my friends who are interested in movies and animated television(t.v)series told me that it is not as good as other series.They justified that it contains black comedy scenes,the comedy is not so good and generally the movie is bad-created.Finally,for me the best and the funniest episodes are from the seasons 1-10 and the other seasons are not so funny.Brilliant effort to the creator of these series.I wish to come out other television animated series like this one!Great Job!!!!

The Simpsons has become one of television's longest running animated productions: from 1989 to now, the show has become a longstanding icon leaving its mark on entertainment history with style. The Simpsons family has become synonymous with television animation everywhere: Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa and Maggie are wonderfully rounded characters that are arguably as recognisable as Bugs Bunny and Mickey Mouse. In fact the whole town of Springfield's cast for characters have become timeless television icons themselves: you've now got your Flanders archetypes, the overly critical teacher archetypes of Skinner and Ms Krabappel, the nerdy Comic Book Guy, the selfish billionaire circa Mr Burns, the donut loving cop via Chief Wiggum and the bully archetype Nelson. The show's stories vary from being Simpsons centric to focusing on supporting characters instead: it's a sitcom that's become a fixture for the animated sitcom in Hollywood.Need I say more? Sure the later seasons don't hold up as well as the earlier ones do, but it's still a fun time nonetheless.The Simpsons is classic stuff.

The Simpsons Season 13 just came out in Denmark. What can you say? Who knew it would have lasted this long. Flintstone episodes (160) times three. Unbelievable.The old producers, animators and writers are still hanging in there, providing insightful commentary, not just the audio kind, but in every aspect, be it social, pop or historical with a lot of insanity thrown in.I do read comments on the internet and I totally agree with the writers that they are sometimes nasty and unfair. They have criticised Mike Scully (show runner season 9-12) of ruining the show. They have criticised Al Jean for being self serving, when he put another character from a different show into the Simpsons. Come on, what do we want? I loved that insane humour of George Meyer and Mike Scully. Where else but animated shows can you show a male character try nurse a doll and a billionaire try catch the Loch Ness monster. This is animation for C....sakes. Why not have a little fun with it? Reality shows have taken over the fun you used to have escaping from that reality. Now to survive we get shows with some kind of horror or supernatural element that mostly rely on special effects, not well written stories. That's fine, but we need good comedy as well. Most of the sitcoms today does not have any edge to them.So, let's hope we all learn to stop complaining (ironically I did just slam sitcoms and space shows) but as Homer would say: Yeah, but what are you gonna do? Congratulations on beating every record there is in showbiz, Mr Scully, Mr Jean and all animators who were ever involved with the Simpsons.By the way, I am a nerd when it comes to the Simpsons. I do tend to groan when I see something not consistent with character development. But I have never said: "Worst Episode Ever" - Oh, s...! I just said it.

I honestly wish this show could go on funny.  The writing is sharp, the humor is always dead on, and it still is my favorite show after all these years.  Realistically, i know the show will have to end sometime.  May it live on in syndication and those overpriced dvd boxed sets!

The Simpson's is and will be remembered as one of TV's best ever shows, but for me it would have been the best...if not for the later seasons. I don't exactly know when it was the show started to deteriorate, maybe after the 10 year mark...maybe when Phil Hartman died (RIP) I'm not sure. The Simpson's first season was crude, but the potential was there. The second season kicked off and the show was improved, and again in the third season the show was improved...but the fourth season, for me was the Simpson's strongest...it was consistently funny, it had some of the greatest one liners ever and they didn't over do the physical humour. The attention had changed form Bart to Homer, which was good...Homer is one of the best creations ever , especially in season 4...he was dumb, but just so funny. Anyways, the show continued and was great, but as i said before...there was a point were it just was not that funny anymore. Homer has become loud and annoying and just isn't the character he once was, even the shows older writers admit this. The storylines really are clutching at straws and i do not watch the new seasons...i prefer to just watch earlier season. Matt Groening should have stopped it earlier but i guess all he could see was the money...and the show is a complete sell out now, I'm not interested in `The Simpson's bath towel's' or `The Simpson's video car racing'....it breaks my heart at what the show has become because it was my favourite show of all time...for a long time. Even though the later seasons do dampen the Simpson's, it will be remembered as a classic , and rightly so...that's how good the previous seasons were...

The Simpsons has gone downhill for many many years. It's writing sucks, comedy sucks, storyline boring and so many out of character moments. But the first ten seasons tho will always hold a place in my heart for being not only being a lot funnier but far better written with heart, soul, drama, storys that were emotional and thought provoking etc. That's why the show is getting a 10 since its based on these seasonsSeason 1 to 10 10/10
Season 11 to 13 6/10
and the rest 1/10.Worth the watch but make sure you stop at 10. Since that's when the show fell apart.
This show would be a 10/10 had it stopped at 5 seasons. 9/10 before 10 seasons.

The Simpsons is a classic, I am sure that almost everyone knows what the Simpsons is by now.The show starts off good, then it gets worse. The newer seasons are much worse than the older ones. I don't know why it's bad, but other than that, I do love the older seasons. I just wish that it wasn't cropped to 16:9 on Disney...

The Simpsons has been increasingly maligned for the past twenty years and frankly, justifiably so. But there's a reason this long-running show gets more flack for a decline in quality than any other: during its' first decade, which is what I've based my ten stars on, this was the greatest American sitcom of all-time and one of the greatest ever made worldwide.In the '90s, this show could make you howl with laughter, but occasionally warm or even break your heart. Back then, celebrity guests were used wisely and sparingly, rather than just being written into lackluster scenarios for the sake of having them. It was thoughtful in a way that most U.S. shows could not grasp and they made no secret of their awareness of that fact, which endeared them to the public even more.Advice to new viewers: stick to seasons 1-8, 9 and 10 are a decent encore. There, you'll find this once colossal show in its' original brilliant form.

The Simpsons is definately one of my favourite animated shows, but I think it's been going for too long. Season 1 and 2 seem really slow and boring now, but seasons 3-9 kick ass, after that I just think it got rubbish. They should have cancelled this and kept Futurama running!

anyone who thinks this cartoon isn't that great, then i don't know why you even bother watching anything else, because the Simpson is one of the most longest and one of the most best cartoon ever. Also, the cartoon has all the things it needs, like comedy, a big dumb, fat, lazy idiot, an smart person, a bad kid, a caring mom, and also a lot of great stories for each episodes. I think its kinda incredible to see the creaters to put together a really funny cartoon, and last for a long time. also, i think its kinda funny whenever homer Simpson kept saying do'h and kept on almost dying in a lot of the episodes. Sometimes, i think it would be pretty funny if i actually see homer dies, and goes to hell, and actually make an episode about that. Oh, and also, i think Marge is kinda stupid looking, because of that hair of hers, i mean, like whats up with her hair anyways?? because that hair is just really bad. anyways, overall, i think that the Simpson is one of the best cartoons there will ever be, and i think the creaters will keep on making new episodes until there's absolutely no actors/actress anymore to replace them.PS. i would've given this 12/10, but 10 is the highest score i could give it on this.

Finally... worked through all 28 seasons of "The Simpsons" (618 episodes and 1 movie to date). A rocky road, with the first ten seasons being the best "classic" or Golden years period. Then it went downhill with many unfunny, clichd or just plain boring seasons for a few years. Hasn't really picked up again as well as it could, but did improve eventually. I think "South Park" has done better at keeping up with social events and remaining consistent.

I remember when this was the best show on TV. Bravo to Matt Groening for when it was. It was so funny and entertaining from its premiere in 1989 until about 2002. They had great characters, story lines, humor, etc. After that, it became way too "far fetched." Now days, episodes are way too unrealistic. I know it's just a cartoon, but it used to seem possible. Suddenly, they got new writers, new story lines, and changed the plot. Ever since, the things done on the show have become so bogus and bizarre, nothing is enjoyable anymore. In the old days, this show made you think about how dumb everyday people are sometimes. NOW, dumb people seem smart compared to how dumb and unrealistic this show can be. My recommendation: Get seasons 1-13 on DVD, and avoid ever watching any new episodes. Hasn't anyone ever heard of quitting while they're ahead?!?!?!?!

Let me first say, that I am a HUGE fan of this show, but I think that it (unfortunately) is starting to go down hill. When I say that, i simply mean that The Simpsons has started to repeat itself badly. It's always the same things that happens to/with characters. Let me give a couple of examples:Homer: Still as bald, fat, stupid and caring as he was from the start. He still tries to strangle Bart, and still tries to make Lisa happy. He drinks as he have done all the time, he keeps on doing the most stupid things when he has spend a couple of hours at Moe's and so on.Conclusion: Does the same (BORING) stuff all the time.Marge: She is one the most boring characters in The Simpsons, and will never be anything else. And you can't even say that she keeps on doing the same BORING stuff, because she doesn't do A THING. She has always been sitting around at home, trying to be "the head of the family." Okay, through her life she have had a couple of jobs, but how many? 4 or 5? And for how long has she been able to keep those job? One episode.Conclusion: She never really does anything, so I gues that there is no conclusion...I could keep going on like this for a lot longer, but I am sure we all have other things to do, so I am just gonna say one more thing.
I admit that The Simpsons is one of the greatest shows ever made, but FOR THE LOVE OF GOD, STOP IT. It is starting to get so-so.... BORING. I mean, when the episode where Flanders dated a movie star were send, I just sad through the hole episode and HOPED that his relationship with her would evolve into something, but (of course) it didn't. And that was my opinion ;)

Simply put, the best. Each show is funny and intelligent, and have jokes that nobody else could have ever thought up. Sheer brilliance. Even if it is sinking a little now, it's still funny. People are just dissapointed that it doesn't live up to the standards of the classic episodes, but it doesn't mean that they SUCK or should be CANCELLED, entirely. Keep going as long as possible Simpsons, I support you!!

WARNING: Possible spoilers if you click on the video or read this review. This show was one of the greatest shows of all time. Funny jokes, emotional appeal, all of that. But now it turned to crap. This video explains all of it.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KqFNbCcyFkk you can see how it made the best show ever, but turned into what it didn't want to be. It needs to change, or it needs to end. If none of this happens in the coming years. Its going to get worse and worse tainting its name fully from funny animated sitcom to ugh is this show still on? Fox I believe has a contract lasting till' season 30. So if at the end of season 30 it ends, don't be surprised. But also don't be surprised if it doesn't. Fox is milking it dry, and will keep milking it until there's nothing to milk. What I'm saying is that Fox won't cancel it until it starts to not make a profit from the show. And its coming soon. There are too many shows that are too good instead of what this has now become. Watch a different cartoon. BoJack Horseman, F is for Family, or even Early Simpsons. But not the smut that is still existing and needs to be put to rest.

Hi, I'm from Mexico, and I just want to say something that everyone knows. This is the best show ever and I think when I'll birth 80 years (Im 20 now) this show will be standing yet, like the Flinstones right now. I love that chapter when Homer thinks that Mr. Burns is an alien, and Molder and Scully take place in Springfield. I remember when I was five (1990) I saw that chapter when a babysitter takes care of Bart, Lisa and Maggie, and she try to rob the house. Since then I never stopped watching this show. I know this could sound like too much X-generation, but the best moments of my life have a relation with some quote of the Simpsons. Hey, and let me tell you something: Here in Mexico is sold the Duff beer! But is not like the Australian Duff beer. Is the Duff beer of The Simpsons! Believe it or not! Same logo, same colors. I saw an interview with the guy that has the idea of selling Duff beer because Matt Groening never registered Duff as a trade mark. And he said something that is really true: Duff has about 17 years of free publicity. Interesting, all right? Well, everybody knows this is the favorite family in the World!

I love the Simpsons ever since I was a little girl I am 21 now and still adore them and still find them very funny and entertaining.i don't care if I sound like a little girl that has never grown up but I think the Simpsons are going to be fresh even to our kids in the future.so I long story short I adore the Simpsons.and they will never die the funniest show in animation out there that has gone on for so many years.no other animation will ever animation will ever beat the Simpsons.not only are they great actors and comedians but they are a animation family that will be strong forever I have seen that for many years.thats why I love the show and I will never stop watching it.<U+0001F607><U+0001F607><U+0001F607><U+0001F44D><U+0001F44D><U+0001F44D><U+0001F44D><U+0001F44D>

It always feels like something semi-religious is going on behind the scenes on this show, even if the creators try hard to make it fast-paced and daring at times. Like a lot of shows, it churns out a true conventionalism and a dont-make-waves approach toward the viewer. It is revealing itself to be more conservative than controversial, so as to not lose any of the misdirected praise or adulation - truly, Daring is not a word for The Simpsons.  Is it funny ? Not really. Do they have funny voices ? Well, some of them, yes. Could they stand to be compared to say, Duckman ? Sure, when hell freezes over, because a show like Duckman is Truly Hilarious, with great characters and intensely funny scripts - try and find the equivalence to the drool-bucket in any Simpson-episode if you can - No ? I am not surprised. Great Comedy. The only outstanding character in The Simpsons is Monty Burns. They should cancel everything else and give him the chance to shine in all his corrupt selfishness. If you have the opportunity to see The Simpsons - read a book.
One of the best animated tv series! Always funny, they create comedy with little.

I am one of the most elaborate Simpson fans of all time in my opinion. I have watched every episodde before season 12 possibly a dozen times and will stand by saying it was the greatest show ever. Yet the true question is how many shows run for fifteen years... Almost none if any and that simply is becasue after time they are ruined. The greatest show ever is simply not funny any more. I struggle to watch the new material. All I can say is get the first half dozen seasons all the way up to even season nine, anything after that is nothing more then a waste of air time taking up space that was once occupied by great shows now cancelled such as Family Guy, Andy Richter and so on. Which none of lasted more then four seasons or so.

The Simpsons is one of the greatest shows ever, but it needs to step down now. Since season 9 or so, it's been an almost total waste of time. The writers seemed to know this originally, and poked fun at themselves for it. But how many times is this sort of self-deprecation funny when they aren't actually doing anything to make the show better? Older Simpsons episodes are full of lovable, funny characters, but more recent ones are awful. Homer becomes selfish, stupid, and mean--sure, he was stupid before, but sweet--Lisa is a boring, one-dimensional caricature of her clever, formal self, and Marge practically ceases to exist except to occasionally utter her trademark grumble. (Oh, and the parade of guest stars only makes things worse.) The show is just embarrassing now. The first years of it, though, are simply some of the funniest stuff ever to grace a TV screen. An open plea to the writers and producers--please, for the sake of your biggest fans, please let the show die.Oh, and...go banana!
Not much to say other than this being my favourite show of all time. 32 seasons of pure entertainment and comedy! What can be better than that!

The Simpsons Graced the Australian screen for the very first time in 1992. At first it was dismissed as merely another trashy American cartoon with poor animation, and its popularity was surpassed by the mindless "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles."  Today, it is already an animation classic that stands on par with Japanese Anime like "Neon Genesis Evangelion" in sheer depth of storyline, voice acting and lovable characters who touch our hearts with their humanity (Three cheers for Lisa Simpson and Krusty the Clown!). And for an American Cartoon to equal Japanese Anime, "The Simpsons" is a true triumph of a show.

There was one time, around about season 7, when every episode would have me laughing so hard I'd cry, the jokes were hilarious, the gags were very funny, and every character was brilliant and unique. For example, the episode with the Movementarians, that episode has to be one of the funniest episodes of any show ever. Lately however, it seems to have gone down the pan. The jokes seem less quality, the story lines are getting TOO far fetched and just not good. Now I would only get a couple of small chuckles from each episode, where as 10 years ago, every episode would be filled with brilliance, brimming with brilliance and so many laughs you would cry, no though, I feel it may be time to put the old dog down.

I feel sabotaged when my mother reveals that she thinks this show perfects american culture perfectly, but it's just a line of dumb sentences, parodying everything we love int to and bad before among citizens, The animation is ugly as hell! I reject the Simpsons, just like how Shuichi rejects Danganronpa!

The impact those classic simpsons episodes had on my family, friends, and even random people in the school bus yelling out quotes after quotes from the show. We were addicted. I was put in detention for replying "Excellent...." like Mr.Burns in the 10th grade when our French teacher said "tomorrow is the only day in the schedule where we don't have class together", everyone burst out laughing and he sent about a third of the class with me so we ended up having to stay in the library for a week.Me and my younger brother spent countless hours watching the show, in English and the Quebec French version, we would learn our English faster than most kids thanks to that show thanks to the close captions.The show became more silly and tried to emulate FOX's new big hit (undeservedly so, imo) Family Guy, which was plagiarissimo of the actual show. Homer turning into a Peter Griffin for season 11 in particular sucked, season 11 even had an episode that was made terrible on purpose (even the Comic book store Guy was wearing a "Worst Episode Ever" t-shirt when seen. That was the episode with the horse jockeys turning out to be underground elves or whatever....that would be okay if it was Futurama, bless that show, but that was the Simpsons.Al Jean took back control of the show and the next few seasons were hit or miss, it was a new thing to only like about half a season, but s12-13-14-15-16 were like that, still worth watching most of the episodes, but there wasn't anything as funny as it was when the show's main purpose was to make us laugh, with its humour being so "twisted", our teachers had us sign petitions to remove the Simpsons from the Quebec French TV channel that was broadcasting it, in the early 90's, I didn't sign it and passed, although then, I didn't find the show that funny, I got into it big time when I grew up just at the perfect space-time, when season 5 premiered, we were doing homework me and my brother and my mother was doing laundry and helping out in the livingroom and we just happened to flick channels to what was playing...the highly regarded "Cape Fear". "This coffee's too hot!" Before that, I was a bit too young and season 1-2 jokes flew right over my head.A true critic of the nuclear family, but at the same time, reinforcing the fact that there's nothing like family, it is all that matters, everyone without a family is either a really sad/mad/insane person in the show (pretty much). My fav seasons? Season 5,6 and 8 are memorable to this day. My girlfriend can come back from work and launch a quote to me and I'll reply "you spent 5200 dollars on beer?!?!" as regular small talk.I don't know what the show is past season 32, without Azaria...I don't know what 20th century Television is, but it seems to me like all voice actors were changed and thus for bad reasons. The Apu fiasco, when the character has been integral and practically fully Americanized ever since we saw him. He's the coach of a pee-wee hockey team ffs. Azaria voicing Carl like a black guy despte being white and not wanting to do it anymore....the show has become what it always mocked, political correctness, false value signaling (I hate that expression but it is what it is). I haven't seen much past season 16, I started watching s17 and by then I was more interested in the golden age of South Park (season 5-10...be honest, SP being known by the general public as what it was in the first 3 seasons are annoying and don't get how smart the show became...while keeping some of the ridiculous and grotesque humour at the same time).Last product from the Simpsons I thoroughly enjoyed was the Movie. It felt like great closure to me, sure it did employ some tropes from some episodes, but it is very prescient of where the world was going....your house or if luckier like me, your city my be "the Dome". It shows that they had put a lot of effort into it, having worked on it in secret for a good while I understand.But I agree with those speaking of the "Zombie Simpsons" by now, they should have stopped after season 20 if they wanted to get to a nice round number....now the real last season is season 32 and that new fac simile of season 33+ I will not watch, when I heard Azaria quit and the voice actress for Martin died and Mrs. Kavner not being sure she could do it anymore at her very advanced age.I think that the show was able to bounce from the general failure that was season 11-12 (don't get me wrong, some of those seasons have some great A+ episodes, but we were used to A+ all the time...) when Matt was forced to stop supervising Futurama due to FOX almost destroying the show and some old writers being brought back into the fold (Matt Selman. Dan Greaney even George Meyers was back and he hadn't written an episode in a very long time). When he left to supervise Futurama again, it showed, and it was painful.They could have quit before all this cancel culture s**** and the rebirth of extreme PCness (causing the Streisand effect and bringing us the President we still have for a month).So I bow to you, Matt, Al, David Mirkin, Bill Oakley, Josh Weinstein, John Swartzwelder and even Mike Scully, you did write funny episodes but you were the worst executive producer. As for you Mr.Swartzwelder you wrote 150+ episodes in those first 15 first seasons and almost every line is etched into my brain and I manage to make people laugh by classic-simpsonizing my speech to people I suspect will not get it (too young or like many quit watching after season 11-12 and forgot a lot about the show), and so many of your episodes are among the best in each season, your name should be as well known as Matt's!I could go on, but I think anyone reading this knows where I could go next. Thanks for bringing me all this joy in the rocky times that was my teenage years and still doing it because the show (without syndication cuts) is played on a canadian channel, 2 shows in a row from 4:30PM to 5:30PM, so when the cycle of the translated for Quebec show hits its ceiling (extremely high quality voice casting, to anyone doubtful, compare the Quebec French voices for each character, they really did a great job). I also got some seasons on DVD, but some dingbat stole my season 1-2-3 DVD cases, good luck getting a season 1 DVD pack these days for a price that makes sense)...the actor speaking for Homer died and they decided to quit when season 27 was translated. The man is as not replaceable, just like Dan Castellenetta is to the original.

Who woulda thunk that an animated comedy about a simple, yet funny yellow family would last decades. I remember wearing Bartman T-shirts and parroting Homer and Bart's most famous lines. Now I have kids older than I was when I started watching it!! I thought only soap operas lasted that long. But it is with much deservedness that it keeps going. "The Simpsons" is an American classic now and ranks up there with the greatest shows of all time. It is certainly the GOAT animation.

The first handful of seasons (up to 12 or even 13 debatable) have been great! But even with the occasional good jokes here and there on the new episodes or even the ever so rare good entire episodes, (which are to few and far between) are just not enough to sustain its previously untouchable legacy. The actors don't care as much, to much censorship (they even took out Apu for the complaints) which was a sign the creators had lost their nerve, they are to political and try to hard to adapt to an SJW world. Enough is enough. Please kill this show with mercy. It had a great run, but it's time. Thank you though, still give it a collective 7
Easily one of the most embarrassingly unfunny, poorly written shows on tv in 2021. Unwatchable!

A modern day 'Flintstones'.  This show is already a classic, and it is still running.  The writers are having a hard time finding new material, but keeps fresh with modern day social humor.  Homer can be a little too much at times.  The show pushes against Political correctness to the limit.  The only weak character is the Doctor, I know it is a poke at "the cosby show" but hey that show has been off the air for over 11 year and a lot of viewers miss that punch line.  It's getting too old.  My favorite episode is the time travel one with Homer.  Only problem, with the show's popularity, is the over play of reruns.  I am starting to become sick of the over played episodes, and it will become another MASH.  MASH used to be shown 7 days a week like the the Simpsons.  It is too bad, we had to wait for 4 years for it to come to Canada. You see a lot of Conan O'Brien humor in both shows.

There's not really anything I can say about THE SIMPSONS without sounding like I'm regurgitating talking points, but I will say that the recent FXX marathon (the historic one that made headlines, which should tell you how much of a pop culture staple this show is) has proved a ridiculously enjoyable binge over the past several weeks. I have no idea why I didn't stick with this show, even as I grew up with it, but I've certainly made up for lost time, and it's become one of my favorite series. The array of memorable characters, the sly wit, it's all here and consistently funny - which is not something I can say about any other FOX animated sitcom. One other thing: Hank Azaria is an American treasure. The series itself is a showcase of incredible talent (Shearer and Castellaneta, especially), but it's Azaria's characters that tend to be my favorite (Moe and Chief Wiggum). I love that Wiggum is a bad Edward G. Robison impression, and he never says something that's not funny. 9/10

almost legendary, it is one of remarkable social pictures. because, after the humor and the crazy situations, memorable characters and inspired dialogs, out of a Simpsons industry, remains the science to present the basic truth in best manner. a series about life challenges. honest , seductive, nice and, more important, precise. the adventures of Homer family are only at first sigh crumbs of fun. the deep roots in reality, the lovely way to rediscover the innocence, the remarkable portrait of each character are not only artistic good points but a form of social cure. that fact does Simpsons irresistible . and one of the most extraordinaries animation series.
