I remember watching the very first episode of The Simpsons when it premiered at Christmas in 1989, when I was 7 years old and I haven't stopped watching it since. I'm now 23 and it is still one of my absolute favorite shows. I can't get enough of the antics of the Simpson family and all their neighbours and friends. But if I had to pick a number one favorite character, it would have to be Barney Gumbel. He can't get through one sentence without belching and I find that hilarious. If I had to pick a favorite episode, there'd be way to many for me to name. But one of my favorite episodes is the one when Bart created the Angry Dad comic. I laugh and laugh every time I see that one. It amazes me that The Simpsons has been on the air for 16 years. I remember thinking it would maybe last a year or two, but it's having an awesome run. But whenever it ends its run, at least all Simpsons fans will still be able to enjoy them in reruns. Kudos to the creators!!! You created an excellent cartoon!

I propose the duel series theory to everyone who loves The Simpsons. This is a way one could also continue to love this proposed idea.It is common knowledge that the series took a dive around season 10. And by dive I mean they changed course, Homer got a little more less intelligent and the episodes seemed to have only half the heart.Now for the idea that we treat The Simpsons with a duel ideology. On one side there is the golden standard of The Simpsons and probably television in the 90s, which ended in the middle of season 10. After that we are greeted by a different show. A new retelling of the show even. This is the zany and crazy Simpsons. It is the point where the show became so huge it had to do something different to keep people watching. The story lines became wacky and disposable. Case in point can you quote more lines pre season 10 or post season 10? Are there lines worth remembering? Ask yourself that.After season 10 we are given a sitcom where crazy ideas are thrown around. Homer has a different job every week and character who were had very tiny roles are now given bigger and more time. Also, this is the time when Apu is hardly seen and heard even less. The new Homer has no time to visit the KwikiMart because he is doing all these crazy jobs. Comic Book Guy, Grounds Keeper Willie, Profesor Frink and Ralph are becoming more mainstay. They are given a line in nearly every episode just so they can get a cheep laugh, but is it memorable? Hardly.Next case, think about memorable Ralph lines. Then find out where those lines came from? They are prior to season 10 and this new consistent Ralph is less memorable.Even amazingly good episodes like Eternal Moonshine from this season lacks the pop to be memorable. Sure it was a very well done episode and we all know it because it was recent, but a few years down the road will you remember anything from it other than the plot? Will you remember the dialogue that made it so good? To be completely honest the only episode with lines that are worthy of remembering are from The President Wore Pearls episode and that was because it was done via catchy and good song parady.I know a lot of you are going to disagree with what I'm saying. You will call it all classic and call me crazy and saying I just have a small brain and cannot remember the lines and the stories. But I ask you to sit for a minute and think. Can you recall 100 moments after season 10? 50? 25? 15? There are 200 episodes to choose from, can you do it? Now I'm not saying it was bad after season 10, I still watch every new episode with my friends like I did 7 years ago and I still laugh, the show has always been funny. I'm not saying it hasn't been. I'm just saying it's not a memorable type of humor. I will always cherish seasons 1-9. They are my childhood and I will always see seasons 10-whenever as the show that continued in place of the Golden Age of The Simpsons. Which is The Simpsons, but still feels like a different series within the series.

It was a classic for the first 5 seasons. Unfortunately it has seen a drastic decline ever since. However the early episodes are excellent comedy. If only the creators had the dignity to stop when they should have.

well after the 2003 season, The Simpsons will become the longest running sitcom in TV history, passing Ozzie and Harriet's 13 year run. When the show ends in 2006 it will have 16 years. Marge, Homer, Bart, Lisa, and Maggie have all won a place in our homes. After the show ends, lets hope for a The Simpsons: THE MOVIE!

I watched "The Simpsons" for three or four seasons, and stopped when I sensed that grotesque satire was taking the place of proper characterization and plotting. These days, you never know what on Earth you're going to see if you tune in to this show...Though there are many, many hilarious episodes, I have to say that my final impression of "The Simpsons" is somehow negative. Maybe I'm just tired of people who think that dropping quotes from the Monorail episode into casual conversation is the height of wit. In the past, sarcasm was actually labeled the lowest form of wit - and that just about pegs this show. Clever, yes, to a degree. Good, to a point. But also most definitely tiresome, especially after so long, and not really worthwhile on any substantive level. Like the Catholic church, I think "The Simpsons" went wrong when it stopped attacking institutions and became an institution itself! It's now every bit as bloated and bad as the things it mocks. Too bad, since it started out as an honest and sometimes even insightful critique of the middle class.

Ive heard a lot of complaining about the new episodes of the Simpsons lately. Everyone says the show isnt as good as it used to be in the 3rd and 4th seasons. Well, Ill have to disagree.Sure, it may not have such great stories as ten years a go, and the jokes may not be as funny as they were in the episodes 8 years ago, but at least I cant find another sitcom, animated OR acted that still makes me laugh at least once during an episode. All comedies get unfunny during time. Even Monty Pythons Flying Circus became dull in the fourth season. But the Simpsons was still keep on making at least one viewer (me) laugh.
Okay, the show was a bit annoying in seasons 9-11, when the writers must have all shoved crayons up their noses, because they came up with such ideas as Mr. Burns searching for the Loch Ness monster so that he could be loved, Homer refusing to donate a kidney to save his fathers life and the Simpsons killing an alligator and then running from the law. But nowadays the quality has improved. Some of my favorite episodes are from recent two seasons (In Finland we are currently seeing season 14); "I am furious yellow", where Bart starts drawing a comic called "Angry Dad", which is based on Homer "Poppas got a brand new badge", where Homer starts his own security company, but angries up the mafia and "Bart vs. Lisa vs. the 3rd grade", where Bart and Lisa get transferred to the same 3rd grade class, where Bart is a succesful student and Lisa is not.All of you who do not like the series any more do not have to watch new episodes, and if they do still watch the show, they might as well shut the hell up. Im tired of hearing complaints about this gem among animation, sitcom or in fact all television shows.

The Simpsons, this is a show that has overcome so many odds, and still has been one of the best shows to even hit a television. The Simpsons was the funniest, most original show you could find on TV. I used to watch the show at LEAST 5 times a day, I always needed my daily Simpson's buzz. The best of seasons were from 4 to 8, that is when they were at their funniest and most creative. But as the seasons went on, the show started to lose it's edge.Now going to season 17, I don't think I can bear to watch the show anymore. It hurts me so much to see a show that I have been watching my whole life, crumble down like Michael Jackson's empire. The last season was absolutely horrendous, it was the worst season yet! I do admit, though, there were a few good episodes, like when Homer smuggled drugs from Canada... but this season, the bad episodes overcame the good episodes. They have been starting to run out of idea's since season 12, but it definitely showed on this season. They need to get some of their best writers back, people like Conan O'Brien, or Bill Oakley, they were some of the best writers that the show has ever seen. Now that most of their people have gone, the show has crumbled in to nothing.It is so sad to see such a classic fall like this, but there is still hope... today, I just bought season 6 on DVD, and I can now enjoy what was once some of the funniest episodes ever, anytime I want. I will still always love the classic episodes, and I will still watch the new episodes (because I am a hardcore Simpson's fan), but the show should end now, it's getting to the point where it is unbearable to watch. Please Groening, just let it go, you are meddling with a classic.Overall, I would give the show: ********/10 stars, the show may have a lot of bad episodes, but there are too many good ones to ruin this show for me.Please end it...

I like the Simpsons, but the quality of this show has declined a lot since the late 90's. The Simpsons was once a funny, poignant show, and since it has become so popular, the show has been making fun of itself lately and becoming more like a children's cartoon than a satire of family life. Since The Simpsons have become pretty bad lately and been on the air so long, I guess the show should just be canceled and the episodes after 1995 or 1996 should be burned because they just aren't funny and/or poignant.

The Simpsons is the story about Homer Simpson & his family which consists of his wife, Marge, his son, Bart & his two daughters, Lisa & Maggie, in the fictional city of Springfield. The animation of this show is very unique, as all the characters are yellow in color! The Simpson family are a weird lot, because of the different values of each member of the family. Homer is a lazy & obese man, who works at a nuclear power plant. Apart from work, he mostly spends time at Moe's Tavern with his buddies. He loves his wife but, he sometimes gets annoyed due to the burden, of raising three children. Marge is Homer's caring wife & mother of three. Marge loves her family but she sometimes gets sad & angry because of Homer's forgetfulness, his careless attitude towards the kids & his excessive drinking. Bart, is a mischievous ten year old who loves causing trouble wherever he goes. He is the most notorious boy at school & his parents keep getting called to meet the principal, Skinner. Lisa is a very intelligent & kind girl. She's just the opposite of Bart. High grades, hates causing trouble & has no friends. Maggie is an infant, who hasn't learned to speak yet & is addicted to her pacifier which she keeps sucking. Some supporting characters include, Homer's religious neighbor Ned Flanders. Springfield police head, Chief Wiggum. Kwik-E-Mart owner Apu, who is an Indian. And a few others like, Marge's sisters Selma & Patty, Bart's best friend, Milhouse, who has always had a huge crush on Lisa(she doesn't reciprocate his feelings though). Nelson, Springfield Elementary School's(Bart & Lisa's school) chief bully. Moe's Tavern owner, Moe. He's an extremely ugly guy who hangs out with Homer & his friends, Lenny, Carl & Barney. He's also unlucky with women & is attracted to Marge & last but not the least Principal Skinner(principal of Springfield Elementary).Each character is unique & hilarious in their own ways. However, The Simpsons would not have been possible without the brilliant Homer Simpson. Bart, is another highlight of the show because of his mischievous pranks. Hilarious supporting characters include, Moe, Apu, Nelson, Ralph & Chief Wiggum. Dan Castellaneta has done a mind blowing job in his voice over of Homer. Julie Kavner is impressive as the voice of Marge. Nancy Cartwright has done an outstanding job in her voice variations of different 10 year old boys, Bart & Nelson to name a few. Yeardley Smith is effective as Lisa. Hank Azaria is just epic as the voices of Moe, Chief Wiggum & Apu. Harry Shearer is brilliant as the voices of Mr.Burns & Flanders. So to sum it up, The Simpsons is a must watch. Laugh till your sides hurt, while watching the events unfold in the colorful city of Springfield.

A worthy contender for the greatest TV show of all-time. The Simpsons may have withered very slightly in recent years but it remains a cultural phenomenon and a show that can be enjoyed by all ages on multiple levels.

The Simpsons is the best semi adult cartoon in the history of television and altho it does appeal to kids, adults love it to, Matt Groening is a complete genius for inventing this amazing show and although the new episodes suck a bit, it doesn't ruin what The Simpsons was: Here i will explain a bit about each member of the family and see where the show went by changing them!Homer .j. Simpson: Homer is the best character because of his constant stupidity and his lack of understanding Lisa' smartness and always been outsmarting him i.e "Mental note, the girl knows to much" you can see that he is proud of all his family but at the same time doesn't want be in the same room as them! Dan Cassenella is a genius! i don't like the new Simpsons Homer because they have made him smarter and his voice sounds dumber and i cant watch it because its sad, what they've done to him!Marge Simpson: She is the perfect housewife, does chores looks after the kids and cooks, thats Marge Simpson for you! She may have the occasional murmur but Marge is great, its funny when you that Moe has a huge crush on her and tries to hide it from Homer, but deep down i think that Homer knows! The problem now i have with this character is that Julie Kavner has made her voice sound more screechy and it kinda gets on my nerves because of thatBart and Lisa Simpson: i want to say something about them together so i'll put them together! Bart and Lisa are a great bro and sis and sometimes i wish that i could be related to them!! Bart has always been my fav because Nancy Cartwright is amazing and even tho she does Chuckie from 'All Grown up!' and 'Rugrats' you can sometimes hear Bart when Chuckie laughs and talks, anyway the problem that i now have with Bart is what i have always hated Lisa for, being a goody two shoes and he never plays pranks anymore and now Bart bores me! Lisa is an OK character but in the early seasons her voice always went through me because it was high pitched and squeaky but over the years Yeardly Smith improved the voice and its a nice voice, Lisa hasn't really changed much except some how she knows everyone in Springfield and shes also a bit dumber as well (whats up with that), the main problem i have with these two is that they never fight as much as they used to which sucks a bit! i wont do Maggie because not much to say, except shes never init anymore she always disappears!! random!Overall i still love this show even tho the writers have lost their touch and all they do is rehash old story lines and give it a new title, also trying to shock people i.e Making Patty in a lesbian, not very shocking, i can't believe they are making a movie, i cant wait but i think that i may be disappointed as well!i give this 10/10 because it will always be great and i will never stop watching it!

When I saw the Simpsons show I was really into it and entertained and I thought the show was hilarious. I enjoyed and loved some of the jokes they had, but as the show progressed it got offensive by it started bashing God and Jesus and I am a man of faith. I couldn't watch the show anymore because of the things the show said. After I still gave it a chance and stayed open minded and tried not to judge it, but the things the movie said made me uncomfortable. So I am writing this review to say that I would've enjoyed it, if only the bashing of not only my families beliefs, but also, other people's beliefs in a higher power wasn't thrown as jokes like that. It's fine to have your own opinions, but don't bash people's beliefs. That's messed up. All in all, I would never watch the show or movie again.

The Simpsons are by and far the best and most entertaining show on Television.  They are a breath of fresh air compared to the other shows on TV which are all ripoffs of each other with the same predictable jokes over and over again.  Also unlike most other shows on TV they seem to be getting better and better every year instead of worst.

Nearley everyone in the world has heard of The Simpsons, classified by many as the greatest cartoon of all time. The Simpsons started out life as a little cartoon show on "The Tracy Ulman Show." The very first episode of The Simpsons was called "Goodnight Simpsons." As the years went by, so did the cartoon. In 1989,the very first full episode of The Simpsons was broadcasted, the episode known as "The Simpsons Roasting on an Open Fire." The episode was very successful and throughout the years The Simpsons became more successful. Personally, I think The Simpsons is probably the best cartoon ever made. The Simpsons is of course extremely funny. The Simpsons also has the power to go deeply into the emotional side, dealing with issues like marriage,death, divorce, etc. There is really know need for me to mention the names of the characters, because most people reading this will know who the characters are. These times, The Simpsons maybe having hard competition with Family Guy, which is slowly creeping up on The Simpsons. The Simpsons movie is coming out on the 27th July 2007, I hope that it is as good as the T.V. show. Long live The Simpsons.

This is absolutely pure genius of a show. I will never find a show this good. It was the most hilarious thing, especially the first 5 seasons, but though the newer season aren't as good, still a 10. Here are my judgments of the seasons:1-3: The best seasons of the Simpson's ever! Absolutely hilarious, I couldn't go 3 minutes without going hysterical. If you just started watching the show, watch the first season. 10/104-6: Hilarious seasons of the show. It is such a clever thing to see. Maybe not as good as the first 3 seasons, but still gold. 9/10.7-9: Great seasons of the show, absolutely awesome. Can't go one episode without getting a memorable quote (which earlier seasons had like 4 quotes an episode). 9/10.10-12: Very good seasons of the show, still hilarious. But, they did kinda change a lot of the story maybe adding a lot of drama for me. Still some great episodes from these few seasons. But can't beat the previous seasons. 8/10.13-15: Pretty good seasons of the show. Still with some laugh moments in a lot of the episodes, but not as much as you'll get from the previous. Some show changing moments, and colorful characters were added, but can't compete with others. mid 8/10.16-19: Good seasons of the show. Some good moments throughout some episodes. But I never seem to laugh as much as I used to. Some parts where you'd chuckle, but not as good. Though I give the show a 10, I am a little disappointed with these seasons. 7/10.As you could tell, older seasons are better.

Let's face it, under the hand of Mike Scully as producer, the show really took a nose-dive right around season 7 after Mr. Burns got shot.  Despite the fact that the quality of the material was nothing compared to the best of seasons 4-6, the show managed to turn out a couple classic episodes and at least has one laugh-out-loud gag per show, even on the lamest of episodes.However, recently the show has improved quite a bit with Al Jean taking over where Scully was sorely lacking.  It seems that not only has the writing and timing improved in the current season, but the characters are acting a lot more "Simpsony".  There's a lot less of the goofy sensational stuff like Homer running off to a desert island or becoming a cannon freak, and a return to the subtle basics and nonstop clever comedy that made the Simpsons such an enduring (and endearing) enterprise.A lot of people are starting to wonder how much longer the show will last before they pull the plug.  My guess is whenever a major voice actor on the show dies, because the show has to be raking in tons of cash even a decade after it came into being and after numerous bad-episode fiasco's.  Let's face it, even a bad episode of The Simpsons is funnier than a usual episode of most other shows still on these days.

If it weren't for "Married<U+0085>With Children" or "Roseanne," shows about white-trash middle-class people struggling to live, than we wouldn't have "The Simpsons". The cartoon itself is phenomenal, dealing with everyday life than ever before.The family includes Homer Simpson who works at a nuclear power plant, loves to eat donuts, drink beer, hang out with buddies and get himself into goofy situations where audiences learn a lesson; Marge Simpson is the all-American woman with a big yarn of blue hair, who has two sisters that hate Homer, and loves the fact that no matter what, she'll always love him; Bart (everybody's favorite) is the oldest child who loves Krusty the Clown, violent things and loves getting into trouble. His best friend is Milhouse who is a dork, and a Nancy-boy that doesn't agree with Bart most of the Time. Yet, he's America's kick-ass son; Lisa is second child and the brightest in the family, who enjoys playing the saxophone, being a vegetarian, and dreams of going into a good college. She may not agree with her family, but she is there; and Maggie is the last child, the infant for many seasons on the show who never has spoken her first word, but just sucks on her pacifier.What makes the show interesting throughout the years is the interaction of these characters and the people that surround them; from Ned Flanders, the pious neighbor who is a geek to Homer and most of the town of Springfield, he's got some cool stuff, and yet Homer considers him his buddy. The other characters in the show involve Mr. Burns, the oldest living man in the town; Kent Brockman, a replica of Tom Brokaw, is the reporter who loves living the rich life.Though there are many characters in the show to list, what the show promises is making fun of everyday life from families, competition, politics, work; even the holiday episodes (which are a joy to watch) where a lesson may be learned. The Simpsons will always be there through years and generations to come.

The Simpsons........ Ah, what to say about this show that hasn't already been said? It is the smartest, best written, and most fun series on television, and has been for more than a decade. The quality of the stories has dropped in recent seasons, as the show has pretty much covered every idea that it could. Still, it's one of the most entertaining shows on television.The Simspons look just like the average family, if their skin was yellow and they only had four fingers on each hand. Dad, Homer, is the chief provider and resident idiot. Homer is a man ruled by impulses. He swings from highs to lows, and back, in the blink of an eye. He is probably not the best person to be safety inspector at a nuclear power plant; but, then again, the rest of the plant isn't that far ahead of him.Marge is the glue that holds the family together. She truly loves Homer and the kids, even though she is constantly embarrassed by them. Still, she's not perfect: she has had problems with gambling and drinking, and usually dives right into the lunacy.Bart is the bad boy, Dennis The Menace taken to the Nth degree. Bart delights in pranks and mischief, but also shows great character at times. He has defeated Sideshow Bob at every turn, reunited Krusty with his estranged father, gotten Principal Skinner his job back, and stuck by his sister when it counted most.Lisa is the brains of the family, and the most positive character. She delights in knowledge and learning, but enjoys a good prank, or an Itchy & Scratchy cartoon. She has such wonderful hopes and dreams, that you hope she is never disillusioned. She delights in Bart's escapades, even though she often chastises him. Her intelligence often makes her an outcast in the community, yet she rarely seems bitter.Maggie is the cute little baby, expressing herself through gurgles, burps, and sucking noises. She is often the silent observer to the family hijinks, and sometimes their savior. Just keep her away from the baby with the one eyebrow and Mr Burns.A friend once described the three kids as the embodiment of Freud's id, ego and super-ego. I doubt this is intentional; but, those attributes do hold, when you examine Bart, Lisa and Maggie. Sounds like an interesting idea for a book.The cast is rounded by great supporting characters: Mr Burns, evil plant owner and resident fossil; Smithers, his sycophantic aid; Lenny and Carl, Homer's friends and co-workers; Barney, the recovering alcoholic; Moe, his enabler; Krusty the Klown and the former sidekick, Sideshow Bob; Apu of the Kwik E mart, Principal Skinner, Mrs Krabbaple, Comic Book Guy, Prof Frink, Chief Wiggum, Mayor Quimby, Dr Hibbert, Squeaky-voiced Teen, and so many, many more.The show has showcased some brilliant writing and animation, not to mention the amazing voice work. The cast and characters have grown over the years to become dear friends.Despite my love for the show, including the incessant need to quote lines and plots, I think it is about time to put it to rest. I still enjoy the show, but each new season seems less than the one before. It's time for our favorite family to move on. I will miss them when they go; but each new season will make me miss them less. All good things must come to an end. Still, I'll be there until the end.

In 1977, Matt Groening appeared in the face of earth and made a comic called "Life in Hell." It's based on a true story about Matt moving to Los Angeles. It is a funny comic/serial and very animation. It's all about rabbits and humans and stuff. Then in 1985, Matt was hired by James to create a series of segments based on Life in Hell, But due to the loss of his rights, He went to a different direction and thus, The Simpsons were born! When the Simpsons premiered on the Tracey Ullman Show, The network executives and the viewers turned green from shock and American television burnt to the ground like MAGIC! *pig noises* Although It premiered its first and second series premieres, It broke the world record for longest running TV Show. Today, It's still the best show, But I give it a 10/10.

I have been reading some of these comments and getting rather irked. I realize there are so many people who have written something on this show, but here I go. "The Simpsons" is by far one of the greatest shows that has ever been on television. Few other shows actually are worth a bit of anything by the time they get syndicated, but "The Simpsons" just works and has from day one. The interwoven satire, sight gags, downright dumb humor, and heart ... it speaks to people in a way most other shows just can't. It has always had something to say. As long as there is human nature, then this show will work its magic. And finally, for all of those other comment contributors who have slammed any given season or whathaveyou, this is what I feel: something so great always needs to be humbled and that is all that you are doing.
The series has fallen well short of 10 over the latest modern series. The universality of the great original comedy is gone

The 1980s ended as The Simpsons came. A show that is still fresh, young and memorable. You have some yellow people. That's right we also have multicolored ponies, and multicolored men in Doug. This show were different from family friendly shows in 1980s. In this show we have your family in a suburb. Bart, Lisa and many other known names. We follow their up and down in the everyday. Here are tons of spoofs from Casablanca and The Lion King to Pokemon. Many guests stars comes by to give voices. There are many Holiday specials too. A lot of memes, merchandise got made. If you want a show for teens and up I recommend The Simpsons. 10/10

This is by far one of the greatest shows of all time. It is outrageously clever and funny. There is such a wide array of lovable, funny, goofy characters, and a lifetime of memorable quotes and one liners. This show has hundreds of classic episodes that are just as good the seventh or eighth time as they were the first. I also can't imagine any other show that get so many huge celebrities to agree to parade themselves in such hilarious situations. This show has lasted longer than any other cartoon or sitcom quite simply because it's the best. I am proud to admit that I've been watching the show since I was eight and have seen each one of the 350+ episodes. I will undoubtedly watch the show until it's off the air and I will watch the reruns until the blood in my veins run cold

I'd watched Simpsons back during the early 1990s when it first came out and was pleasantly surprised by all the film references and spoofs. But after Season 8 things changed, and I don't mean in the good way. Jokes were reused and some episodes didn't make sense. Even that pushed the limits. But if you're looking for a good season with lots of memorable episodes, my advice to you is to try Season 4. This had many good moments, including Marge as Blanche DuBois, a Krusty-themed summer camp, a heart-throb babysitter, a guest star-studded episode for Krusty, and Lisa's first word. I won't say too much for those of you who haven't seen Season 4, but that's where to look. For me, that season was the best. Everything else seemed OK but not as fun.

The Simpsons is one of the most best TV-show on the entire planet! A very hilarious series about your every day average family that live in Springfield and I don't know which one. This is such a good show- you don't make over 30 seasons for no good reason! It's so carefully crafted and put together, there's so many references that you blink and you'll miss it, and jokes that just go over your head if you don't pay attention. It's funny for both kids and adults alike and appeals to everyone, Matt Groening and co are geniuses, not forgetting the likes of Harry Shearer voicing I don't know how many characters! It's hard to believe that over 600 episodes have been made and the quality is still there but it's true.

Ever since they started on The Tracey Ullman Show by cartoonist Matt Groening in 1987, The Simpsons have been a hit, but at one point of the series, I guess how to put it is that, the show stopped being funny. I use FXNOW to watch older episodes. Remember that one with Ringo Starr? OK, OK. Let's get to the point. I love the Simpsons, but it isn't what it used to be. Now it depends on jokes and pop-culture celebrities. I'm not saying it's horrible, bad, it just isn't that good anymore. It can be funny at times, but not what it was when it first started. One example is the Summer of 2014 where they said that a major character would be killed off. It was Krusty's father. (hollow cough).Thanks for reading! Chris Caracci

In 1987, something revolutionary happened: A new kind of family was introduced, something we had never seen before. We got acquainted with a family that was extremely dysfunctional, but no less loving than the Drummonds, Douglasses or the Keatons. While those were entertaining to watch as well, it was important to highlight that not everyone has it quite as together in their life.Conflicts stir up, someone might feel neglected, you sometimes struggle even trying to get by. The Simpsons' money troubles remind me in a way of my own family. My mother could sometimes be poor and struggle with the economy, but always took care of us and gave me all the love I could possibly hope for. In short, whether you were a Bart, Lisa, Homer or Marge, there was something in at least one of them you could relate to. I was very compassionate towards animals and spoke out against meat consumption just like Lisa. At times I thought my dad was like Homer as well.And not just that, but many of the other characters were great as well. Some of my absolute favorites were Mr. Burns, Smithers (the two of which I've often imitated), Moe, Lenny, Dr. Hibbert, Apu, Hans Moleman, you name it. And the humor at its best was satirically profound, whimsically wacky and daring. There were few other shows like it.This was the case for the first ten seasons. The next four it got more cartoonish and less down-to-earth than before, but still managed to be a lot of fun. But as time went on, the show became less and less smart and more dumbed down in nature. It got especially bad once we got to the HD era.And in trying desperately to get with the times such as constantly referencing Apple products, making politically correct changes (Such as removing Apu, deleting one of their beloved classic episodes just because of a controversial guest star and recasting characters just because it's seen as "wrong" to voice a black character if you're white), it's become not only depressing to see the show go down further in quality, but to see its crew actively trying to tarnish its legacy. I worry that all the negative aspects of the later years will end up becoming so distracting I'll forget about all of the good memories it's given me.So in short, there are two different ideas of The Simpsons: A show that changed the TV landscape forever, and one that lost its own identity along the way and forgot what made it such a beloved series in the first place.In the end, the golden years are worth all the stars I can give it, and the worst years only 3/10. Maybe even 2/10.But due to my undying love for The Simpsons at its best, I can't bring myself to rate it any lower than 10/10 anyway. Take that for what you will.

I kind of grew up with The Simpsons series, being THE series at that time. I hardly missed any series, I guess I've seen more than 150 and many of them twice or more. However i stopped watching the Simpsons at some point. At the point i noticed it became unoriginal and annoying, but more about that later in this review.What made The Simpsons so great, were its original and funny jokes, the interesting stories, the really great characters and all those allusions and mocks. And they always gave the viewer the feeling that this, although only being an animation, was somehow a bit real, authentic and comprehensible. Also the Tree House of Horror Trilogies made it even more interesting, making fun of popular horror films and at the same time staying true to the Simpsons universe. It was the perfect transformation of Simpsons characters into characters of Horror movies. I would give the first ~100-150 series 11/10 points for their funny original and sometimes touching stories which also had a lot of great social critique in them.However the later Simpsons series, especially the latest ones, show a great lack of its former originality (which is of course understandable after so much series) as well as bad and recurring jokes and what I would call "a rape of characters". The characters became dumb and somehow they became less distinct from each other, compared to how they were at the start. There are also less references and mocks of real persons and stuff. And overall they made the series a bit crazy and flipped out probably in order to try overcome the lack of new ideas. And additionally there is one thing many may not even have noticed, but I did and since i have noticed it i've not been able to watch those newer series: If you listen closely, you will notice a distinct sound of cricket chirping in the background in any outdoor scenes. It freaks me out because it's totally annoying due to the exact repetition of it and its absolute uselessness.All these things (that annoying sound only being a small part) forced me not to watch the series anymore. I think it's just a waste of time anymore and while I would give the first series a rating of 11/10, I would give the latest ones only 5/10.

The Simpsons has been on Television for a Really Time. the Ordinary Family lives in Springfield USA. First aired in 1989. Still to this day questions me how great it once was Seasons 2-10. Golden Age of when it had such great moments and I know Simpsons fan prefer the old episodes. When It was being funny too!Still The Simpsons should have ended after the Movie in 2007. but overall I still love them!

You know, I can tell you that the simpsons used to be a great show, but I'm pretty sure 95% of the people coming here already know that. It WAS funny, entertaining, satirical look at every day life. then they just stopped and brought in the insane plots. i mean bart befriends a western star? what the hell is up with that stupid crap? I wouldn't even mind the damn insanely stupid plot lines if you know it was actually funny? but no, it seems they forgot HOW TO WRITE JOKES. so in other words, watch the reruns but please for the love of the game don't watch any new episodes, maybe this show can die with a shred of dignity. now for my um... ratings. i'd give reruns (seasons 1-11) 8 stars. new episodes are worth a 3. making this show a 6. it may seem low, but thats because of the horrible new episodes. I guess that means this review is over. thank god/Jesus!

'The Simpsons' was and still is my favorite TV Show of all time, that is if you forget about all the newer seasons. This show is easily one of the greatest things to have come out. The Simpsons has shaped the lives of generations of people and has revolutionalized the meaning of the word 'funny'. The characters in the Simpsons are some of the greatest and most easily relateable characters of all time. Everyone loves Homer and Bart, there's no doubt about that but there are so many others such as Ralph, Chief Wiggum, Moe, Carl and so many more characters that are also hilarious. The voice acting is brilliantly done and for the animations, they are brilliant and yes the animation of the first couple of seasons was great for its time and still is definitely watchable As for the plots in most episodes, it is absurdly entertaining. Since the Simpsons, many TV Shows are beginning to simply 'steal' their plots and just recycle them. The Simpsons, is HANDS DOWN, My favorite TV series and definitely one of the greatest classics of all time!

Greatest animated show of all time. Maybe it's gone on too long but that doesnt take away from the greatness of this show. So many legendary episodes, awesome celebrity cameos back when they meant something. The money this show made on merchandise is most likely in the billions. This show will live on.

It's the biggest cartoon series ever created. It's won numerous awards, including Emmys. It has continued to be popular after a 10-year running span. It rocks.But why? Well it was hard at the beginning not to laugh at Homer's laziness, Lisa's brainy babbling, Bart's pranks and Mr. Burns' 'excellent's, and now, it's totally addictive.Although, I must admit the 1998-99 season wasn't up to the normal Simpson's hilarity I'd come to expect, so I'm really glad that it's managed to pull in better stories and jokes.As well as one of the biggest shows, it also has one of the most merchandising campaigns for a TV show. 4 CD's, singles, toothpastes, t-shirts, Chess and Checkers sets - yep - the show really had thought of everything!While The Simpsons probably won't be as big as it once was, you can guarantee you'll find me watching all the new episodes, and the repeats, too.Even the Simpson-haters must admit that it's very popular. Or else, why would Mel Gibson, Christina Ricci, Winona Ryder, Glenn Close, Britney Spears, Joshua Jackson, George, Ringo and Paul, Drew Barrymore, Adam West and other celebs guest-star on it??And there's denying that 'The Simpsons' is totally unique - from the couch gags, everyone's quotes ('Doh', 'Excellent', 'Come again', 'Burp', 'Mmmm'), Bart's chalkboard expressions - this is one show that never needed to copy anything else!Dan Castellaneta, Julie Kavner, Nancy Cartwright, Yeardley Smith, Harry Shearer, Hank Azaria, James L. Brooks, Sam Simon and Matt Groening - you've created one of the finest TV shows ever... thanks!
It's funny still to this day and season 31 32 and 33 are getting better and the first 10 seasons are so great if I could I would rate it an 8173929126/10 I might just hack IMDb so I can do that.

"The Simpsons" promises to remain the most reliable half-hour of laughs on television. The emotional dynamic for "Stark Raving Dad," echoes that of "Simpsons Roasting On An Open Fire". David Mirkin's debut as show runner resulted in the first episode that gives him sole writing credit, "Deep Space Homer"."Treehouse of Horror XXXII" delivers a decent number of laughs across its multiple shorts. The Simpsons continues its practice of PC superiority. How wrong can a once-great show be? Sunday's season curtain-raiser shows that "The Simpsons" hasn't lost any steam.

Now I know if I put that it was only good up until season 10 why would I give it a 10 star? I just can't say enough about "The Simpsons," which I think is one of the funniest shows ever!  It gets better all the time, whether the comedy is witty or just plain knee-slapping, silly humor.  I never miss an episode, and neither should anyone else!

I grew up with the Simpsons. I personally think that it is one of the best shows on television. Not only is it funny, but it also makes you think, bringing forward moral values combined with smart humor. Having said that, I think that the formula just isn't working the way it used to.I will always like the Simpsons, but I've noticed in recent years, that the episodes just seem to keep getting dumber and dumber. They aren't smart anymore and everything appears to be way too commercial. Its becoming obvious that no real thought is being put into any of the plots, the network is just interested in making money. Thats what it comes down to.The show is just not funny anymore, in fact, its annoying. Incredibly annoying. It seems as though no real thought is put into the storyline and things are awkwardly random and do not make any sense, despite the fact that it is a cartoon and is meant to be silly. But let me say this - compare the 2004 season to the 1994 season; you will see a major difference in storyline. Plotwise; smarter, funnier.But today; as I said, too commercial. I think it should wind down before it gets too stupid.

There is so much to say about the Simpsons, and all of it good, that it would never fit here and would take forever to write.  Every show is a gem, with superb voice acting and animation. What makes The Simpsons so hilariously funny is that it can do certain things that cannot be done on regular TV shows.  The aspect of animation opens up so many doors not available to other shows.  And what is even better is that the show has never experienced a lull or decline in hilarity... in fact, it seems to be getting better.  I am confident that The Simpsons will continue to bring joy to so many people for a very long time.

The Simpsons has to be the greatest show on earth. I started to watch the Simpsons when I was 10 years old and I continue to watch them today. Almost every episode is enjoyable to watch and gives you many good laughs. My favorite episode would have to be the one when they get the nanny "Sherry Boppins". Some of my other favorites include the episode when Bart sells his soul to Milhouse, the episode when Homer gains weight so he can work at home, the episode when Lisa takes dance lessons, and the episode when the Bart thinks Flanders killed his wife. "The Simpsons" has made a huge impact on TV. It is the longest running cartoon ever in American history. Why is it so great? The answer is well a lot of answers. The characters were extremely likable, the jokes were funny, the voice acting was great, the animation was good, and the show overall is just fantastic. Many say it started going down hill after a while I say it is still going strong. The first thing to be said about the show is that I love the characters. There is Bart the 10 year old kid who always gets in trouble at school, Lisa the nice 8 year old kid who gets good grades, Marge the mom of the family, then of course Homer the lovable idiot. Then there are tons of minor characters. Seriously this show has the largest group of characters in one show I have ever seen. My favorite character though is Homer. The runners up are Bart and Lisa. Then we have great voice acting. The voice acting for the show was, and still is top notch stuff. Then there is the nice animation. Throughout the years the animation has gotten better for show although it has still kept a great style to it. Lets compare that to a bad cartoon like "Johnny Test". When they changed their animation they changed the style it had, and changed the show from OK to terrible. Then there is the shows great sense of humor. I have gotten a lot of really good laughs out of the show. Each episode is funny, and is really entertaining. "The Simpsons" has become an icon in animation that that even the makers of another one of my favorite shows "South Park" were inspired by. You can shove as much "Family Guy" as you want in my face, but there will be only one "The Simpsons"

This is one of my favorite shows.  In fact, if you ask me a bunch of trivia questions about the Simpsons, I can gurantee that I'll answer just about, maybe even all of them correctly. When I had mentioned something about the Simpsons, my whole class asked me one trivia question after another about the show and were quite amazed of how much I knew about it. This show is loads of fun for the whole family to watch.

I have moved twice in the past 2 years, and each time I moved I would check local listings to see what time each episode or episodes would be on. I have seen each episode a hundred times, and I still don't tire of it. I can tell which episode it is almost instantly after the couch scene. Yeah, I know, it's weird, but I have been watching it since I was a lad, so I've had lots of practice. People are now saying that the show is old, and warn. I disagree; the way I see it is it's trying to keep up with the times, and it's changing humor tends to make people lose interest. But not to me! I think the switch isn't better or worse, but equally good. I also think the way the use the show's repetitiveness as a joke. Many of you reading this will disagree, but I have been watching and laughing for nine years, and quite frankly I can't see the dullness and warn down side, but that's because I find humor to be humor, and if it's funny, I'll watch. The colors fascinating the show are all my favorite bright yellow, bright yellow, emerald blue, simple and clever lines, but with delicate composition and omnipresent details, never rough. The titles of the two seasons are the same. If you look closely, you will find two differences: the easily recognizable one is that the bell rings after work, the whole family rushes home from all over, squeezes on the sofa to watch "The Simpsons" The posture of falling into the sofa is almost different; another thing that is not easy to recognize is that when Buzz was fined with chalk on the blackboard in the classroom after class, the camera quickly swept through, and the continuous writing of 20 lines of a sentence forever It's all different content-it can be seen that this child makes mistakes every day!
I saw that I was wrong when I saw the younger half. This drama is not to lie to tears, but it is not to deceive from the beginning like a Korean drama, or the audience is incompetent and the relationship is fragile. In general, this is not a drama with children as the main body, but it is for children who have grown up, and it reminds people of the funny things that they tricked their parents when they were children. Parents sometimes hate their knees. The child's heartless, sweet hatred. This family is lively and busy, not rich or elegant, let alone middle class, but everyone in the family loves each other, forgive each other and occasionally misunderstand each other, tolerate each other, despise money and occasionally lack money Realism can occasionally be a coincidence, but it has been quite difficult to please for twenty years. It also shows that what Chinese animation or Chinese film lacks is not a director, but a screenwriter.
An animated series that has been popular for 20 years, only the talents who draw it do not need to bear the ruthlessness of time, and they do not need to let the audience have regrets such as Harry Potter who grew up. The characters, scenes, and patterns in the play remain basically the same, only new stories continue to happen, or the current events are implied. In the United States, which is in a new position every day, this calm style gives people a sense of down-to-earth, like a box of toys hidden in the attic. It must have fascinated the countless American adults who watched it grow up, which is one reason for classics, no need for nostalgic classics.

In its heyday The Simpsons was a joy to watch. The characters were likable and the stories were humorous and well written. I always looked forward to the next installment of this piece of cartoon genius. Notice how I'm using the past tense, this is because watching a more recent episode is nothing short of pure torture. The characters have become obnoxious and the same story of Homer getting some wacky new job is trotted out seemingly again and again. I won't pretend that I have seen all the episodes much past season 10 simply because I haven't. I prefer to keep my memories of a good show intact and not taint them with the wreck of a cartoon The Simpsons has become. I think it would be cruel to make my eyes watch anything from the 16th season whenever that may float across to merry old England. I can appreciate that after so long the stories are bound to dry up, but it's at that point that most sensible people would decide to stop flogging the poor dead horse and actually bury it. Years ago celebrities who appeared in the show actually played a character rather than just themselves. These people are actors, for goodness sake let them act!!! A series cannot go on forever and after 15 years I believe that The Simpsons should end next year. If the rumours of the 3 movies that the main actors are contracted to do actually happen then I seriously can't see them being any better that what we have to put up with at the moment. So I send out a plea to all the writers & overpaid actors on The Simpsons, tell Fox where they can put the show and help track down any episodes past season 10 and destroy them so that they may never be heard of or spoken of again.
It's a great finale and the end and start and middle are all great.

Man, what a great show.  I mean, really, this is such a wonderful show. Love them or hate them, the Simpsons are a part of American culture.In factm Homer Simpson is probably one of the most recognized men in America. I was nine when this show first premiered and I watched every first and second season episode as they aired. After that, my schedule kept me from seeing as many episodes as I would have liked, but I think I've seen them all in reruns. In general, "The Simpsons"'s run has been like this: the 1st season was decent family comedy and drama (a bit too much drama) and the Simpsons were kind of sappy (always down on their luck); Homer was the serious and silly lead, and Bart was a novelty item; best and funniest episode: "Krusty Gets Framed." In the 2nd season the laughs really poured in; the drama virtually disappeared; Homer became much stupider and funnier; Bart developed as a well-rounded, hilarious kid; every episode was great--some of them border on absolute genius, such as the one in which Bart is going to jump the Springfield gorge (I died when Homer rolled down the cliff TWICE). In the 2nd season the show really mixed its terrific humor with realistic issues fantastically, such as when Homer cheats on his insurance to buy the hair tonic. For the next six or seven years, the show had mostly brilliant, hilarious episodes mixed in with some good ones, and during these years the show solidified its reputation, becoming undeniably the funniest sitcom ever. However, in the last three seasons, bad episodes have started to pile up. Some great ones have surfaced, but the show has become increasingly unbalanced (however, almost every Halloween episode has had a solid amount of laughs). In this latest season, 2001-02, the show has really become crummy. There has been a string of unbearable episodes, and Homer has become too stupid, and Bart has not been himself. The plots have gone way too far. Unless the show returns to its simpler roots, it should be canceled after this season. It has given us so many greats moments, thanks to great writing, animation, and fantastic lead and supporting characters throughout Springfield. It would be a shame to just run the show into the ground and spoil its reputation. The show has to shape up or call it quits.

The Simpson's changed TV for me forever. The amount of stuff they cram into each episode is mind-boggling, the writers must not sleep. Ever. I frequently have trouble remembering what happens in each episode because, beyond the fact that there are so many of them, the plot does tend to take sudden turns.The guest appearances are good, I appreciate the care with which this honor is bestowed - you won't find any duds in this group. However, the show itself is what I tune in for - no guest yet has improved the quality of the show. That says something.The frequent homages are brilliantly executed, the actors are amazingly talented, the writers must live on another plane of existence to be so creative & funny so consistently. Or they're insane. Hey, I'm not complaining, whatever it is - I'll take it. This is one of my favorite TV shows.

The Simpson's in its prime was the funniest show on TV, in my opinion better than friends or south park or Seinfeld or any other comedy show before or since. however the Simpson's is no longer at its best, it has become very poor imitation of its former self. At its peak between seasons 4 and 8 it was verging on genius, episodes like 'deep space homer' and 'who shot Mr burns' were laugh a minute. These kind of episodes are unfortunately no more. The more recent episodes which, i think are steadily getting worse, have lost all the wit and subtlety of the early episodes and replaced it with painfully bad satire, regurgitation of previous jokes and more and more crazy episode set ups that seem to only function as a source of cheap jokes. in short this once great show is dying a slow death and i haven't seen a new episode i've enjoyed for seven or eight years, if your want my advice don't even bother with any episode after the 10th season.

THE SIMPSONS is one of those TV shows that seems to have popped up unexpectedly overnight. It debuted on the Tracey Ullman show back in 1987. Then, in 1989, their Christmas special "Simpsons Roasting on an Open Fire"(1989) made its TV debut, and was the first half-hour episode. Since then, they have gone on for ten years and counting, still on the FOX network. The guest stars, from Glenn Close to Rodney Dangerfield, and John Waters to Mel Brooks, are always an added treat. The songs by Alf Clausen are incredible. The soundtrack album is a real joy to listen to. At times, the show seems like a veritable musical, which make it all the more enjoyable. The main cast (Dan Castellaneta, Julie Kavner, Yeardley Smith and Nancy Cartwright) are always impressive, not to mention the regular supporters (Harry Shearer, Marcia Wallace,Russi Taylor,Pamela Hayden, Maggie Roswell,and Hank Azaria) are always on hand to perform the roles of the famous side-characters. This is what makes the show so incredibly successful. The only time the show loses its magic is when it either becomes too preachy or too crude, which have popped up occasionally in the last ten years.

Imagine if you had created something that powerful and successfull. For this it has to be a 10! any show that has 600 episodes will have fluctuations in quality over time its been 35 years for gods sake! The success is down to great design, top acting, genius level writers, accurate cultural references and diversity. Masterpiece.

I don't know how to completely describe my feeling about "The Simpsons". The show is just too good.  All of my friends love it, and while its extremely popular among younger generations, I've had English teachers who say that everyone should watch it, while a columnist for the New York Observer called it the greatest television show of all time.  It is full of wonderful satire of modern life, as well as simple, silly, humor.  My favorite episodes are the Halloween specials.  Recently I have also enjoyed watching some of the older episodes and noticing things in them I didn't see when I was much younger.  When future historians talk about American culture and society in the 1990s(and beyond) they will refer to "The Simpsons".

The Simpsons is the greatest TV show ever made. Since it aired on the Tracey Ullman show back in 1987 to the present day The Simpsons has always been fun to watch. It's been on for ten years and it's still going strong. Not a lot of TV shows have that kind of power to dominate prime-time for a decade.In this show, we join Homer(the bald, fat, father of the family who works at the nuclear power plant), Marge(the cheery mother of the family who holds the Simpson family together), Bart(the ten-year old son whose the trouble maker.), Lisa(the depressive, smart, middle child.) and Maggie(the pacifier-sucking baby who doesn't talk). This show also has great supporting characters, Mr. Burns, Grampa, Krusty, Milhouse, Flanders, Barney, Ralph Wiggum, Hans Moleman, and Cletus the Slack-jawed Yokel to name some of my favorites.In every episode, Matt Groening(the creator) gives you great laughs. I don't care what anyone says, The Simpson's is and always will be the best television series in the world, Family Guy is the second. For sixteen years, The Simpson's has been clever enough to balance out sophisticated adult humour with family fun. Homer and Bart are fictions greatest creations, they are both cruel and kind, clever and dumb, Marge and Lisa provide the moral tone which keeps the show in check, while the supporting characters ranging from Apu to Chief Wiggum to Milhouse always have their moments.A number of people have been saying the Family Guy is better because it is wittier and more interesting but I don't think this is true at all. Whereas the Simpsons works for both adults and children alike, Family Guy is truly adult animation, in that it's humour is dark and satirical and covers issues that adults understand and enjoy and which go above children's heads.I think if the Simpson's did this, it just wouldn't be as much fun. I say long live The Simpson's and I hope that someone at Fox has the intellegence not to cancel this since they've got rid of everything else of any quality, notably Family Guy and the hugely underrated Futurama which I think has gone because there are not enough intellegent people in the world to understand its humour.

The Simpsons is perhaps the most undeniably greatest TV show ever. It has broken more records than other shows. It's the longest running prime-time TV sitcom, the longest running animated show, the largest cast of characters on a series, and a complete staple of American television. I grew up on the Simpsons it started when I was 6, I'm 18 and it's still running, and still a damn good show, that is a feat all it's own. How many shows basically have a generation of people who have watched it?The Simpsons have evolved over the years: It's early days saw The Simpsons being the wholesome family sitcom tweaked, it had pretty crude animation, cute jokes, and a usually happy ending. The show then evolved into the sitcom chock full of a variety of different humor. The latest years of the show, take advantage of the fact that it is animation, and therefore boundary-less offering up more sight gags, slapstick, crazy stunts, and more far out plots.The show can make fun of anything, and pretty much already has. It's touched on racism, homosexuality, enviormental issues, and religion. The show is not afraid to get very un-PC and no one really complains when it does. The show is not even afraid to mock the fact that it has been on for 13 seasons and it's getting harder to think up plots.So even after this show ends, it will still be around, it will still spawn copy-cats, it will still be in the memories of a large amount of people. The proof: "D'oh" is officialy a word in the dictionary.

Spoilers!Set in Springfield, USA, no doubt located somewhere between Hollywood and the beach, this aging cartoon takes its cue from the same old Honeymooner/Flinstone ethos of the 1950s, with a 1990s Hollywood leftist overlay, and a lead character based somewhat on Archie Bunker, or Curly of the Three Stooges. The politics of the Simpson's is often annoying and cumbersome. As the Flinstones was probably considered crude for its day, so this is a crude FOX presentation, but with some genuine humor appropriate to a cartoon, seen poorly imitated on other FOX live action shows pretending to be cartoons.As for the politics, they seem not to have ever met a Democrat they didn't like. The swindling, thuggish, Democrat mayor is a loving parody of a member of the Kennedy clan, who does business with the underworld and turns them in at just the opportune moment, and so on, while the swindling Republican Congressman is quickly 'stung' within hours by the FBI spurred by the able work of little Lisa and a host of government investigators (I-i-i  work for Uncle SAM!!). Sideshow Bob prances around as a tyrannical Republican when it's merely a case of party role reversal. Clinton's foibles are related as eccentricities at worst, as he courts Marge in person, while the only showing for Dick Nixon is as a member of hell's own jury trial, seated next to the person of Lizzy Borden. Carter is amiably portrayed, even though as 'Mr. Malaise' in one episode, while Gerry Ford stumbles. And Bush is the infuriated ex-CIA neighbor, in this Hollywood subdivision, when Homer, and particularly Bart, comes to call.That is, the location of the town is the great mystery, and joke of the show, as well. Somewhere near Chicago, and certainly in the midwest, they seem to suggest. But with its bustling port, international airport, teaching hospital, university (s?), big indoor shopping mall, huge museums, as well as of the Hollywood celebs near the lake (studios and Mel Gibson premiers, etc), and the rest, it most certainly is rather some generic suburb in and around Bel Air and Beverly Hills, with access to greater LA, which would further explain the cloying politics of the show, as well (if not, then we'll split the difference and call it Denver).It might also help explain that rather confused attitude of the writers with regard to religion (or even physical fitness), where the representatives of Christianity are insincere Protestants, or in the case of Ned and sons, 'emotionally disabled', the former winding up in a mental institution, and/or bankrupt, and/or homeless, the latter perpetually afraid of their own shadows and unable to relate to any of the other children. At worst, Ned is literally portrayed as the devil, himself, in a Halloween 'dream' episode. Yet the same are on occasion the beneficiaries of a 'rapture', or warm praise and the homage to It's A Wonderful Life, respected community volunteers, and so on. The writers can't seem to make up their minds.Homer, himself, is the star of the show. His supporting cast is brought forward on occasion, particularly Bart Simpson. But Homer's one size fits all character is the man. That is, as with all the characters, they have multiple personalities, as the town of Springfield itself is multiple towns depending on the episode. What seems more or less constant is that he is the angry 'white male', couch potato Archie Bunker, who on a politically correct show could never utter any racial epithets routinely hurled on the old Lear program (PC for its day, but never today). Like Archie, he is sometimes a good guy, given just the right situation - family man, brave, loyal and true, and willing to accept people once he gets to know them. But the typical Homer is the grossly obese and proud of it, bully, abusive neighbor, arrested adolescent as are his two 'Ph.d' plant buddies, Lenny and Carl, a petty thief and moonshiner, who is considered a loud moron by those who know him, a whining and selfish child by those closest to him, and a friend to others because he is no threat and/or is a source of revenue. He's essentially the vehicle for the self-loathing of the writers, themselves.The multiple personalities are demanded by a show which insists that a 'small town' with big city attractions should be peopled by 50 or so souls. When the mall opens, the mob on the hillside rushes in - the mob of just a few character you know. When the mob chases Homer in a Halloween zombie episode - same old crowd. At the farm of the 'Heaven's Gate' cult leader - same crowd. And so on. Not merely is Homer simultaneously a trucker and astronaut, heavyweight contender and all the rest, but so is the rest of the cast, in a way. It's as if once one enters into the inner circle, the secret society, as it were, all the other people . . . literally . . . disappear. Given the amibitious range of movie parodies and situations the writers wish to explore, the mock of the closed masonic societies, as it were, becomes unintentionally a mock of the very design of the Simpson's, itself. One could argue that cartoons, Peanuts for ex., are locked into a small world of established characters. True. But the Peanuts gang dreamed of the Red Baron. In the Simpson's, Homer would be the Red Baron. The humor can be lost when everything must be flat and literalist. It takes more than a village for that, and certainly more than just a few established characters.At its best, in whatever season, the humor was honest, it pointed out at least some hypocrisy, if not that of the writers' own crowd and causes, and the community and the family poked through as worth defending, on occasion. Marge and Homer always reconcile. Bart comes home. Lisa learns to appreciate family, despite her forever failing precociousness. The cynical Moe - ya, drunks! - is somehow still a friend - and fight manager. The whole community wants the old 'Skinner' back, just so the relationships won't be upset. The real Skinner is unceremoniously tied to a train and shipped out, same for the mock Eliot Ness who gets heaved a ways away, while the delightfully gangsterish and crooked mayor is always welcomed back, as Homer finds his place is not to outdo civil bureaucrats who run the garbage collection. The small group knows its place and keeps its place once the next grand adventure is over. And they fight for that safe consistency, those careful suburban assignments, even, in this supposedly 'edgey' cartoon sitcom. On the other hand, and as suggested above, maybe The Simpsons is just a funny cartoon about a particularly wacky . . . cult.

The Simpsons is funny as hell. I've been watching the show since its debut over 11 years ago, and it's hard to believe that it's still on the air. There are generally a lot of TV shows that I actually end up liking more with time, and The Simpsons has been no exception.In addition, I can do impressions of many characters from the show. They include: Moe, Dr. Julius Hibbert, Mr. Burns, Chief Wiggum, Otto, Hans Moleman, and Comic Book Guy. However, I usually have a hard time imitating the voices of the Simpsons themselves (though I can sometimes do Homer's giggle).Although, I knew that The Simpsons would eventually become a long-running hit series, I didn't really expect it to be on for as long as it has been. In fact, I kind of thought that the series would end by the late '90s (perhaps at the end of season 8 or 9). But I know that one thing is for sure: Every TV show comes to an end. And whether we like it or not, the time will come when The Simpsons will end. (D'OH!!!)But we should be consoled by the fact that, with over 260 episodes, the series will be forever seen in daily reruns. (WOO-HOO!!!)

'The Simpsons' is easily the best show on TV. No other program is able so deftly to cut across age boundaries and offer every viewer, from my elementary school age brother to my university professors, a thoroughly enjoyable half hour of television. All of the elements seem to gel perfectly - the brilliant songs, the clever dialogue, the slick animation and, best of all, the voices of incredibly versatile actors like Dan Castellaneta, Harry Shearer and Hank Azaria who each play up to twenty distinct characters.Matt Groening and his self-confessed team of 'Harvard-geek' writers are to be commended for tackling topics such as relationships, religion, prejudice, immigration, class issues and American cultural hegemony with a sharply satirical but never blunt or unsubtle hand.And the viewer is often rewarded with a rich array of cinematic and literary references and the occasional surprise guest voice artist, as well as plenty of self-satire and meta-humour.I feel 'The Simpsons' will endure while other animated series of the 1990s will fall away. 'King of the Hill' dropped from sight, 'Ren & Stimpy' got boring and, unfortunately, 'South Park' which showed great early promise has fallen into the trap of profanity=laughs.If there is only one reason why Rupert Murdoch should not be banished to a cell for crimes against human consciousness, it is 'The Simpsons'.

The Simpsons was a groundbreaking show.Married with Children was a groundbreaking show.They both defied how the typical American family is presented on TV. In many ways both shows presented the American family perhaps more accurately than any other. They skewered the traditional portrayal of the two successful working parents (The Cosby's)with two cars in the garage with an "adorable" small child and the happy household (Full House) where all of life's problems are solved in 25 minutes and everybody is happy.
But like anything that defies convention, they spurned countless inferior imposters (Unhappily Ever After, the Family Guy) and eventually redefined how sitcoms are presented. Notice how practically EVERY TV family these days is dysnfunctional? From Malcom in the Middle to Titus, the Brady Bunch era is well and truely dead. Even spoofing the perfect sitcom family has in itself become a cliche. So with nothing left to make fun of the shows are forced to become self-parodies. Married with Children reached it'z zenith when they added the much maligned "adorable small child" to the cast. It was perhaps the most blatant use of a laugh or sympathy track ever used on the show. "Seven Wanker" disappeared for good after only a few weeks but the show evolved into a cartoon. They pulled the plug in time. But barely...But the 13th season of the Simpsons is upon us. Now I would not disagree that the show is immensely popular despite the inferior writing as of late. But the plots seem to get more and more tired. The characters seem to become more, I don't know how else to put this, cartoonish. The plots become more outlandish. The charming thing about the Simpsons of old was the touch of reality that pervaded each episode. Now each episode revolves around a wacky caper. And Homer does something wacky. It's the same every single week. Remember that episode where Grandpa Simpson pulls up on a Harley out of nowhere and says "I'm going to haul ass to Lolapalooza" for the sake of being wild and wacky? They were spoofing shows that are "wacky" for the sake of being wacky. And they have sadly reached that point. Pull the plug...and let's cherish the memories.

The Simpsons is my favorite television program of all time (And Frasier). The animated sitcom is witty, and incredibly brilliant. Sure, it is no longer in it's climax, but it is still the most entertaining program, made up of interesting and humorous storylines, clever jokes, some cool guest-stars (Although many of them are annoying, I enjoyed the guest-star appearances of Kelsey Grammer and David Hyde Pierce), and one of the best elements of all: parodies! If it weren't for the Simpsons spoofs on classic movies, I may not have been introduced to such marvelous films as Cape Fear, An Officer and a Gentleman, The Night of the Hunter, and Cat on a Hot Tin Roof. So, yes, you people who dislike the show nowadays do make some good points, but I believe it is still a great animated sitcom, definately worth it's acclaim and glory. As Mr. Burns would say, "EXCELLENT".

THE SIMPSONS is one of the funniest TV shows ever produced. Dismissive of the parameters of the filmed medium, the makers of this cartoon have allowed this series to lampoon modern life (particularly American) through a demonstrated capability to employ nearly all forms of humor: parody, slap-stick, wordplay, vaudeville, puns and given the variety of some plot scenarios, even surrealism.Some have even gone so far as to say that the Simpsons inform us as much about the human condition as Plato, Aristotle or Kant. Superficially, the show revolves around the high-jinks of a drunken father (Homer), his moralizing house-wife (Marge), their delinquent son (Bart), intellectually inquisitive daughter (Lisa), and perennial silent infant (Maggie). There is a large cast of ensemble characters satirizing just about possibly imaginable sociological form.The first few years were certainly quite Christian in content with Ten Commandment-type dilemmas posed and resolved usually quite haplessly by the Simpson family. The portrayal of life as a series of binary conventions lasted under make the third or fourth year when the show became openly and hilarious satirical. Here is where the show took off for the brilliance of the Simpsons lies in its openness to attack everyone: ordinary folk (the Simpsons), the two-sides to the well-respected Religious (the Flanders and Lovejoys), the corrupt and scheming politicians and company directors (Quimby, Burns), actors and entertainers (the Schwarzenegger analogue, McBain), and perverse and alarmist Newshound corporations (Kent Brockman) amongst many, many others.The Simpsons, while not consistently delivering the charm and irreverence of its mid-years, is still a wonderfully delightful show. Some have advanced that the tri-partite of The Simpsons, South Park, and Family Guy has offered an incisive critique of Western civilization without leaving any stone unturned. Whatever the reality, these and other imitators (even filmed media) owes a considerable debt to the trailblazing Simpsons.

Brilliant television series that could probably be best described as "The Flintstones" gone stark-raving mad. "The Simpsons", everyone knows them. Some love the series and some could care less about it. Love it or hate it, it is near impossible to criticize the intelligence and creativity of this series. The titled animated family makes their home in Springfield, USA and gets into situations that are seemingly more outlandish and crazier than the previous adventure. Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa, and Maggie are still going strong after nearly a dozen years of television life and with each passing moment it seems that the series sets some new precedent. For several years the show seemed to be the only attraction to the then obscure Fox Network. It was the first prime time animated show that was treated like a sitcom since "The Flintstones" quietly left the air in 1966. Many people feared the series when it first premiered in 1989 because they felt that it was hardcore adult material in a candied form that would appeal to younger audiences. Well for the most part this was true. However, "The Simpsons" would prove to be much more for all audiences. The great thing about the series is that it caters to all audiences. True there are usually situations that may not be suitable for all viewers, but then again that is true with everything on television this side of Disney Land and Sesame Street. "The Simpsons" works because of great comedy of course, but also great lessons that can be taken from most of the episodes. The people within the program may be animated, but they are just as complicated and vulnerable as the people watching them. All the regulars have their quirks, but in some episodes you can understand what certain characters are going through because the show is so life-like at times. Former President George Bush (the one from 1988-1992) once made a statement that families should be more like "The Waltons" and less like "The Simpsons". His opinion is somewhat old-fashioned and unrealistic. In other words, many topics dealt with in "The Simpsons" fit life for people in the 1990s and 2000s better than "The Waltons" did in the 1970s. A crowning achievement in television art. 5 stars out of 5.
