I think this is the best TV show ever. It's funny, and tells the story of a nice family. Let me just say that I'm a huge fan and watch the simpsons whenever I can. Every episode is great, and I reccomend it to all people who like funny cartoons(although I bet many people have seen it). a definite 10 stars.

The Simpsons are without a doubt the greatest television program ever. They hire the best writers, and get celebrities doing all kinds of things that would otherwise being disregarding. Only an animated series is able to form a cast of characters into the hundreds, and still remember them all fondly.I'll admit, the series in all kind of took a dive around Season 8, considering it's hard to do 300+ episodes without recycling some formats. But it's clearly still the best in the market. Many sitcoms and comedies use tiredless old routines, from the heyday of vaudeville and early 'I Love Lucy' era of Television. That's all fine and dandy, however rather than pay homage to those acts, they try to pass it off as new and exciting to young viewers. But 'The Simpsons', no matter how unsensical, or mundane, is always on the top of their game.'The Simpsons' essentially in roots has basic stock characters. Homer, the patriarch, is dumb, bald, fat, stubborn, and kind of (very kind of) strange. Marge, the wife, is a worrier, and has the typical transgressions with her husband. Bartholomew, is the troublemaker. Lisa, is the brainy loner one, and Maggie is a baby, she holds no significant value.But what makes 'The Simpsons' so great is the way Matt Groening envisioned them, and the writers for 14+ seasons have molded them. With top-notch voicing talents (Dan Castellaneta as Homer is the gem), Only a show like this can make a baby who was voiced by Elizabeth Taylor, shoot a wealthy businessman, and still make complete sense.It's the eye of a true Hollywood story. Writing is the key to success. It started out as a simple one minute sketch filler about another typically-dysfunctional family, and evovled into the greatest Television program ever. Many shows have tried to capture it's charms, and many have failed. 'The Simpsons' are to the 1990's as 'Lucy' was to the 1950's.Don't Have A Cow, Man...

I love the Simpsons. Well, not all of the episodes are great, but all the early seasons more than make up for the new episodes, which have become rather stale. Pretty much everything started going downhill a couple of seasons ago, starting with the episode where Homer takes over the church. It was stupid, and very different to what the show used to be about, classic comical gags and witty lines and political satire in it's subtlest form.But now we have obvious references to current events (though strangely, I never saw an episode where the whole Iraq war was even mentioned, strange considering the show used to point out and make fun of the political incorrectness.) and we have stories that jump all over the place, and it's hard to follow because the writing is so boring. It seems to me that as the animation became easier to do, more episodes were churned out quicker than before, without the care that went into the old episodes.But, watching Krusty shooting Luke Perry out of a canon straight into a brick wall in 'Krusty gets Kancelled', along with all the many classic lines and episodes, more than makes up for these new episodes, which have prompted many people like me to wonder if it is finally time to let the series end and retain it's magic from the classics, before the writers end up making a huge mistake and breaking all the fans hearts by creating episodes so bad even the most hardcore Simpson's fan would cry.

Before Iwrote this comment on The Simpsons, I looked at the other users comments and about 99% of the comments were possitive about the show.I just have one thing to say about those comments, ARE THESE PEOPLE OUT OF THEIR MINDS!!!!!.Are these people blind.The Simpsons is a terrible show!All the comments about The Simpsons are like, best show in history or #1 show in the world.Hello, reality check, welcome to the 21st century people, cause The Simpsons is the ABSOLUTE WOREST SHOW IN THE ENTIRE WORLD, HISTORY, GALAXY AAND UNIVERSE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

The Simpsons has done something that no show had done before it and no show has done since. Made the audience look at every single character, no matter if they are a main character or a supporting character or even a one-off character, and say "Gee, I can relate to that character" or "Wow, that is so true". The Simpsons, which is no doubt the most groundbreaking animated series in the history of television, has, over more than 20 years, created characters that have been slowly and gradually etched out and refined, until the ending result has been reached: An amazingly satirical cast of characters. From Cletus, Springfield's resident hillbilly, to Chief Clancy Wiggum, the incompetent police chief, Groening and his team have covered every aspect of modern America's social spectrum. The writing crew has also been a force to be reckoned with. Conan O'Brien, John Swartzwelder, Groening himself and Matt Selman are just some of the always changing writing team which have provided innovative ideas to keep the audience engaged for over 500 episodes. The voice cast are awesomely versatile; there are under 10 principal voice actors who provide the voice behind Springfield's many residents. The only reason I have docked a mark here is because of the newer episodes. It would perhaps be a little unreasonable to think that every single episode has been an absolute classic and the shows quality has declined over the years.In conclusion, if you do not watch this show, please, take the time to watch some of it. If you are thinking of buying a DVD, I recommend any of seasons 2-12. My personal favourites, however, are seasons 7 and 8. Happy watching.

The Simpsons is one of my favorite shows. I try, if able, to watch AT LEAST one episode a night, and catch the Sunday "new release." My favorite episode, however, is the one where John Waters guests stars. That, or the one where Homer has a chili pepper from an insane asylum somewhere in Mexico.I also like just about any episode with Cletus. I swear, that show gets away with the most amazing things-- because it's humour, a cartoon, and run (sometimes) on Fox.It's funny, I love The Simpsons, but am kind of opposed to the News Corporation-- Rupert Murdoch's conglomerate that owns Fox, FoxNews, ESPN, etc. It is just too Republican for my tastes.

The Simpsons was once a classic but is now a shadow and parody of itself. The first blow to show came in the transition from season 3 to season 4 when the true creators of the show, Matt Groening, Sam Simon and Jim Brooks, retired from being show-runners. Whenever characters go out of their creator(s)' hands (ex. Ren and Stimpy, the Muppets, Mickey Mouse, etc.), things usually go wrong. Also, Klasky-Csupo's animation on the show was a lot more artistic, beautiful and cinematic than Film-Roman's work on the show. The show didn't turn to crap immediately, but it started to gradually lose its heart and realism and cinematic-ness and storytelling. They made Homer a childish jerk instead of a lovable, good-natured dimwit; they changed Marge from a very realistic and deep character to a parent who tries to be cool and funny but fails; Lisa went from being an innocent, child-like constance to the show to an intolerant ultra-liberal tree-hugging hippie; and poor Bart and Maggie got shoved into the background. Also, Ned Flanders and Rev. Lovejoy became stereotypical right-wing conservative Christians and Moe started to attempt suicide all the time. But there are still good episodes, but season 16 was mostly weak and the only episodes from that season I consider solid are the ones that keep the characters in-character but aren't funny at all. I'm guess I'm still so sore over Futurama's cancellation (and I also am mad that the Simpsons is still the most popular cartoon in the USA while revolutionaries like Ralph Bakshi, Osamu Tezuka and Ub Iwerks are unknown to the common men) that I just don't like the newer Simpsons anymore. Matt Groening, please end the Simpsons, have Fry and Leela get married, and make a new cartoon.
This is easily the best show on TV.  It's witty, modern, well written, and downright hilarious.  There is NOTHING better.

This has been my favorite TV show for years, and I basically live off the two re-runs a night that are shown in my area.  The back ground humor and one-liners will stick with me for a while.  The cast of characters is so strong and memorable that removing anyone can disrupt the show, as seen with Phil Hartman.  His characters added many great plot twists and jokes that I will greatly miss.People who complain about certain characters miss the point of the entire show.  It is a parody of life, and the characters portray what people can be like in life, although in an exaggerated way of course.Speaking of parodies, the thing I think is best about the Simpsons is its sheer audacity in making fun of institutions of society. They never beat around the bush and make up a similar name for whatever they are mocking; they just come out and say it.  One hilarious example of this is in the episode when Bart and Lisa are nominated for "Who's Who".  They come right out and  ridicule them without thought of repercussions.Unfortunately, I, in contrast to many other commentors, think the show is on its last legs. Almost none of the episodes in the  last two years are as good as the repeats that I live on.  My friends and I don't even discuss the past week's episode many times because of the lack of Simpsonesque humor. Granted, the show is still pretty funny sometimes, but it does not have that laugh a minute that it had before.  With Groening's new series coming out, "Futurama", I think that this American institution of a family will bow out and be replaced by this new series, which, if it is half as good as the Simpsons was in its heyday, will be quite successful.Goodbye, Springfield.

The Simpsons is an animated-comedy success, which has hit our screens since December 1989, appearing first as shorts in 1987 on the Tracey Ullman Show.I am currently on its seventeenth season, and so far I have had an amazing adventure filled with laughs and great experiences!Although, the Simpsons has passed its "Golden Age" 25 years ago, it still remains an animated sensation, with people still watching it all over the world!I personally, love this show. Although, I have found since around Season 10 or 11 some episodes have been quite dull and unpredictable, I still love it in its seventeenth season.My favourite episode is "The City of New York vs. Homer Simpson" it is a timeless classic, filled with class comedy. Not only that, it is considered to be the last episode of the Golden Age, and it is a great end to it. I also adore it when the Simpsons go on holiday to other places such as Brazil, Hawaii, New York or even London (which is where I am from).My favourite season has to be Season 6, it is filled with many great episodes including: Bart of Darkness, Itchy and Scratchy Land, Treehouse of Horror V, Lisa on Ice, Homer the Great, And Maggie Makes Three, Lisa's Wedding, and the finale two part episode: Who Shot Mr. Burns Part One.Although the animation in some of the earlier seasons is poor, some of it is good as it looks wacky and goofy and that doesn't stop the storyline from being spectacular.I love this show, and I always will.Thank you.

What can I say.  Having been a fan of The Simpsons since the very beginning, I have to say that there is no greater show.  I have grown up with it.  It started as a 'kid's show' which was alright for me because I was a kid, but it has certainly gone uphill from its humble beginnings.Admittedly, I cringe when I look back at the old episodes, they had poor animation, simple humour and very few supporting characters.  Now the show is more complicated and I have yet to see a single episode that didn't make me laugh out loud.Rating:  11/10

The Simpsons is an excellent comedy. There are a lot of different characters that are all very unique in there way. There just can't be a bigger idiot than Homer Simpson. He does everything on impulse and really is a bid kid. He is not fit to have any responsibility what so ever, but instead he is in charge of safety at a nuclear plant!!Homer's boss Montgomery Burns, who always forgets the name of his most disastrous employee "Who's that, Smithers?" "That's Homer Simpson, sir. He works in sector 7G" . Waylon Smithers, Burns' assistant and secretly in love with his boss, the very stupid head of police; chief Wiggum, Apu, Grampa, Groundskeeper Willie, the corrupt major Quimby, the Bouvier sisters, Moe, Barney, etc. They're all brilliant!!!

I'm basically repeating what has already been said countless times, but oh well. :)The show is without a date one of the greatest things to happen to television in recent history, but as of late the series has been on a sort of downhill slide.  You just can't beat the earlier seasons - there was an air of reality mixed in with the comedy.  As an early user review pointed out the characters and plots were more complex and fulfilling in that regard.Fast-forward to today and what you've got is a series that is still good but has descended into slapstick and caricatures. Take for instance Homer - he has always been a dimwit but he always cared about his family and did his best.  Nowadays though the producers just focus on his stupidity for the quick joke and don't really try to go beyond.I'm probably making the show sound worse than it is - it's still a great show, even today, but you can't beat the early seasons.  If there are still people out there who haven't seen it yet, I strongly advise seeing the earlier episodes first, to gain a better appreciation of how great this show is.

This is undoubtedly the best show ever created. I started watching it about 3 years ago, and I couldn't stop laughing. Homer is so stupid yet so funny and he is my favorite character. The jokes are great and they never get to old or boring even if I've seen the episode 10 times. I will watch The Simpsons as long as they're on.

We all know the show has become the very thing it set out to initially mock, but let's focus on season's 3-8. The simpsons is the perfect mix of heart, intelligence, ridiculous humour, pop culture and pure entertainment. Those years of the simpsons were absolute perfect. And let the following years be a lesson to the rest of us that you should quit while you're ahead to keep yourself from falling.

The Simpsons,a show that will always be remembered as a classic for its wit and biting satire was just that,one of the best creations of human beings.I remembered that every sunday my whole family would sit in front of the tv and laugh at the antics of our favorite family,they were funny and at times touching,leaving some at the brink of tears always wanting more,all of the plots were always original and covered new ground and closed a storyline for example this classic episode.Mother Simpson:Glenn Close gives a wonderful performance as Homers long lost mother who left Abe and Homer to protect them after she was seen by Mr Burns blowing up his lab,the reaction of the simpsons family was convincing and their acceptance was too,the ending was quite emotional and nice closing to the show.Homer 3d:Not an episode but a story in treehouse of horror with Homer trapped in the 3d world it was what every fan wanted to see and I was really satisfied by it and an appearance by Bart.After that new episodes started coming they were still funny but then the new writers came in,Ivy League graduate losers with absolutely no sense of humour,all of the storylines were weak rehases and new characters(the blonde executive)are really annoying,the jokes(boo-yah!)are used in every chance and they are bad ones by the way.The Simpsons are terribly out of character and the original storylines are outlandish(Simpsons go to africa),what Matt Groening said the simpsons wouldnt be,and in the way messing with previous better storylines(The Simpsons return to the farmhouse,according to Days of the jacknapes Krustys carrer wouldve started in 89)and the jokes are telegraphed from a mile(the la di da cop in Pokey Mom)I wouldve cried 4 years ago if The Simpsons were cancelled,now I would be happy.I hope that the old writers returned for The Simpsons movie or the new writers came up with something as good and funny as the behind the laughter episode.

I've been watching The Simpsons over the past 12 years and I still yearn for more like I did all those years ago. I've never thought a show could last this long and still remain entertaining, appealing and well-written.It's true the best episodes of this wonderful show are years behind us (most notably "Who Shot Mr. Burns" and "The city of New York vs. Homer Simpson"). But I still loyally watch this show, even now at its 13th Season.Matt Groening is a brilliant man who managed to create characters I've grown to appreciate and respect. By creating The Simpsons, he started a phenomenon that seriously affected our society.Other two geniuses are James L Brooks and Sam Simon, who alongside Matt Groening, were directly responsible for transforming this animated family into a prime-time half hour television series. They were truly ambitious in attempting to take that step and deserve their applause.Throughout the many years that have passed we've seen many writers and producers pass through The Simpsons, most notably David Mirkin, Bill Oakley, Josh Weinstein, Greg Daniels, Mike Reiss, David S Cohen, Mike Scully, Al Jean and George Meyer. They all contributed to keep this show fresh, alive and interesting.David Cohen deserves even more praise, for moving from The Simpsons to Futurama. He and Groening helped create an even better show. It's too bad FOX is pulling the plug on such an outstanding show like Futurama.I was born in Rio de Janeiro and I still live here. Rio is, in my personal opinion, the most beautiful city in the world and I always wanted to watch a Simpsons episode based here. I had the chance to watch "Blame it on Lisa". It was exactly what I expected. This episode worked just like any Simpsons episodes that show us famous international cities in a critical point of view. Rio's tourist officials were plain wrong to criticize a simple animated show because it made the city look bad.I won't deny Rio has its share of problems, even for a city as pleasant. Although tourists aren't actually kidnapped by cab drivers or attacked by monkeys, I will admit it's not a perfect city. However, it was wrong to threaten to sue the producers. After all, The Simpsons has always been a more than just a TV show. It's been a weapon of criticism of today's culture and society, targeting the American family, its values and several other similar values throughout the world. If there are viewers who can't comprehend that and can't take a little criticism they should simply change the channel.Putting that polemic discussion aside, I can conclude that watching The Simpsons can be not only an entertaining experience, but an instructive one as well, if the viewer cares to question the aspects of our society. I hope The Simpsons goes on for many years to come.

The Simpsons is the best animated show ever. It is great and hilarious after all these years. I think they might be running out of ideas but from far fetched plots they make fun of sitcoms, thier network and themselves making it O.K. Everything on the show is just laugh out loud funny and so clever. Plus it has such a fan base that it has had over 150 guest voices on during the 13 years. I know people think that the show is getting repetitive and stale but i feel that it is still wonderful and hilarious. Out of all the charactors Homer Simpson is just the best. He has a good joke every second. The simpsons is just of the best shows on TV. I hope it will stay on the air as long as possible.

I remember when I first started watching this show. I grew up with it, it was with me through my entire life and still is today. Not a day goes by when I don't thank the people who make this show for keeping it on so long. Every episode has made me laugh and smile from beginning to end, and that is something that no other TV show has ever made me do.One of the things that makes this show great is that the humor can be enjoyed by the whole family. Each episode is packed with jokes; some wacky, some witty, some dumb, some clever, but in the end there is no doubt that you will be laughing. In some cases you may even be crying, or just smiling. It has been this humor that has kept me attached to this show for the past years, and it is that humor that will keep me from ever letting go. Some people will tell you that this show has gone downhill and that it is terrible. Personally, I don't know what they're talking about. Each episode has jokes and gags that can make anyone laugh. There are new plots every week and that is an amazing feat considering the show has been on for 18 years. Some people don't like the new ones and that's fine, although others are being a bit purist and aren't giving them a chance, but if you are just looking for a good laugh, a fun story, and a pile of great characters, the The Simpsons are the family for you. Like a majority of their viewers, I love this show's past and present, and I will always look with happiness towards it's future.

The Simpsons did it! It's a joke in a specific South Park episode but it's oh so true; The Simpsons have been pioneers in the animated comedy world for so very long and they continue to be today. People who say that it's gone downhill since season whatever arbitrary season they decide clearly haven't been watching the same show I have! The Treehouse of Horror episodes have gotten funnier and edgier each year, the characters (even random side characters) have continued to develop and grow resulting in some awesome new canon to a show which already has more to it than all 8000 years of Westerosi history, and the parodies of other TV shows/pop culture events and couch gags with guest animators have continued to amaze and showcase the amazing wit and talent that exists within the writer's room of The Simpsons.It has grown with us over the years, evolving and adding more and more to its ever-expanding world. Since I've gotten Disney+ I must have watched every episode now at least 3 or 4 times but there are still new things that I find when I sit down to watch it with my son...and it's a blast being able to share something with him that brought me so much joy and comedy since I was a child myself.Speaking of the comedy, I did not realize just how edgy and biting some of it was until I rewatched old episodes as an adult! Some of the things that Moe and Groundskeeper Willie vocalize are just completely insane, to say nothing of Homer or Marge's hilarious outbursts. And recent episodes have just gotten that delivery and joke format totally down pat. A particularly favorite line that illustrates the genius of The Simpsons was Homer saying to Marge regarding gaslighting, "yeah, you've always said that Marge. Remember? Remember?!" It can be satire at its absolute finest...and also as slapstick, sarcastic, dark, or silly as possible all in any given episode. The fact that after 30 years, this show is not only still going strong but still drawing in new generations of viewers who get to experience the evolution of the comedy is such an amazing accomplishment. I hope The Simpsons goes on forever; with such a rich, dense universe in which anything goes and the impossible is only improbable, it's no wonder it still attracts so many smart and famous guest stars and fans. Any show that gets Stephen Hawking rapping with Flight of the Conchords will win my loyalty and affection any day of the week!Which leads me to the music of The Simpsons, an oft overlooked achievement of the show but one that delights and entertains in an ever evolving way, helping to keep the show feeling fresh and memorable. Whether it's classics like the Maison Derriere song or Lisa It's Your Birthday to the newer, aforementioned Flight of the Conchords/Stephen Hawking mashup, Weird Al's many appearances, or The Great Phatsby, this writers and guests collaborate to make tunes that are impossible to dislike and stay with you long after the episode has ended.Truly, it is amazing what The Simpsons has accomplished in it's 32 seasons on the air; it still delivers fresh stories, beautiful animation and music, and absolutely hilarious jokes that you can watch with the whole family. There's so many shows that have followed in the footsteps laid down by The Simpsons and found success and it's no wonder when the source they've chosen to emulate has such brilliant writers that manage to keep the show from feeling stale even when some of episodes are definitely formulaic (and when the show goes meta and jokes about that very fact, it just makes things even funnier). It will be a sad day when The Simpsons finally hits its end but until then, my family will continue to be avid fans of America's #1 animated family and hope that it goes on for much, much longer!And if you don't like it, well don't blame me, I voted for Kodos <U+0001F609>

The Simpsons are one of the greatest pioneers of all time, without them cartoons would still be aimed JUST for kids. Without Homer and the gang there would be no South Park, Family Guy, P.Js etc. I love the Simpsons, it is by far the funniest show ever, and the list characters are great. Bart, who was the first to make headlines, is a perfect stereotype for pre-teens. He personifies the average youth, rambuctious yet has morals. Marge is the the housewife who holds the family together and Lisa is the brainy sister that thinks she knows everything about the world. Mr. Burns is hilarious, as he mimics Darth Vader with his ominous presence and maniacal thinking. I love how he can never remember Homer's name. Speaking of the king, Homer is by far the most influential sitcom character ever. He created DOH! and Mmmmm...; and even though he isn't the smartest guy he is a perfect role model for all dads. No matter how confused he is, Homer always tries his best to help his family. Unfortunately that can't be said for all fathers. I do agree that the Simpson's better years are behind them however after ten years no comedy can keep up its sharp as a knife wit and gut busting jokes. Also with the death of the great Phil Hartman many of the characters have been wiped out. I long to laugh at the crazy antics of Lionel Hutz, and the over arrogance of Troy McLure. However the Simpsons will always live on in repeats because you can watch the episodes over and over, but the laughs will never die!

I have seen every episode except maybe one or two and they are all great. There is something for everybody when you watch. Weather its Homer's hilarious simple minded laziness, or Bart's one liners you won't stop laughing once it starts.One of the greatest things about every episode is that the begining of the episode has nothing to do what so ever with the ending. One example is in season 12 "Tennis The Menace". The episode starts out with grandpa winning a tallent show and his prize is a free autopsy. In the end there is a huge tennis match between Venus Williams, Serena Williams, Andre Agassi, and Pete Sampras. It sounds crazy but its hilarious.In the years the show seems to revolve around Bart whose catch pharses made him a memorable favorite, but now it revolves around Homer and Bart and their individual adventures as well as adventures together. I think this is great because Bart is funny, but Homer is funnier than Bart could ever hope to be.But recently "The Simpsons" has become tired, and the quality has dipped. Going from great jokes that make you think or taking a cheap shot at someone with out actually saying anything to cheap laughs. I mean they are great but how much more can be done. Homer has gone into space, Bart was part of a famous boy band, Homer saved Springfield, Lisa was President, and the list keeps going on. They have almost exhausted what they can do with the show.If you love "The Simpsons" try watching "Futurama" probably the next greatest show next to "The Simpsons".

Here's my brief review of the Simpsons:Seasons 1-6: The finest moments not only in cartoon-sitcom history, but also in Television history. Who can forget the James Bond-esque villain Hank Scorpio(which was my fav. episode), Milhouse being chased by a FBI agent "The Fugtive" style, or even one of Homers many misadventures? I will watch these seasons in syndication any time, and I will most likely wear out my DVD player when they come to the DVD format.Seasons 7-current: Since season 7, the show has been going down. I would almost say it's hit rock bottom. The concepts are just not that funny anymore. I mean, c'mon:A judge that binds Homer and Bart together or Krusty losing his daughters violin to the mafia just aren't as funny as they should be. It's almost as if Matt Greoning has stopped trying with theis show. If The Simpsons doesn't pick up the pace, it'll go out with barely a whimper when the time comes.(Which should've been 5 years ago.)

I chuckle when, every once and a while, I meet a person who for their own (twisted) personal reasons, is not fond of The Simpsons. Yes, for those who aren't too knowledgeable of American popular culture, many of the jokes are a dead-end and not funny. But still, you have the visual gags and wildly strange-looking characters and animation; though by far the cleverest jokes are the witty ones, not just what you see. Being young doesn't help, either - how are you going to laugh when Moe mentions the movie "Mistery," and you only have the vaguest clue who Kathy Bates is and you've never even seen the movie? But even when I watched this show as a child, I could appreciate the humour, even if not at all levels. The Simpsons - are America. Every horrible stereotype, every truthful fact, and every weird person, place or thing is summed up onto one show that has been bound, since its beginnings, to make fun of it all. If the show had a motto (excluding "D'oh"), it might be "We don't discriminate - we make fun of everyone, equally." And it's the honest-to-god truth. Still don't like it? Hell, maybe you're not clever enough to like it. Maybe you don't have an open mind. Who knows? Sure, after SO MANY years (are we talking fifteen already?) sometimes the show can be hard-pressed for laughs. But just as I think the average yellow American family may be losing its style, something pops up on the boob tube that has me laughing hysterically. If you don't have a taste for satire, maybe you wouldn't get me. But if you understand that the heart of The Simpsons in the American culture itself, and we really can be that dumb, or slow, or funny, or strange - then The Simpsons will live forever. Maybe they won't make a feature film - I'd like one, but I also don't want the disappointment (do we remember "Star Trek" the Movie? If so, than you know what I mean). Maybe it will go off the air in a week. But still, this show deserves the greatest respect for what it is, not because of what people think it tries to be.

Though strictly about a compilation video, this seems to be the forum to add my views on The Simpsons.England has always been behind America where US TV shows are concerned (though this is usually a very good thing).  I believe, on terrestrial TV here, we are currently a year behind the US schedule, but I can already concur with what I have read from a great many other Simpsons Fans.The Simpsons, once the pinnacle of satire and slapstick, has definitely taken a nose-dive.  It still scores over everything else that American TV has to offer, but in the latter series' I have actually (please forgive me) been relieved to get Homer off the screen for a few seconds.  He is undeniably the best developed character in a sitcom (simplistic but extremely well rounded) and because of this it is so apparent when he steps out of persona to follow an "adventure" plot-line.  Because the majority of the shows are now driven by Homer, his personality (usually a constant to monitor the madness around him) is becoming warped and pulled out of shape by the demands to have "All Homer Episodes".In actual fact, some of my favourite episodes have concerned other people - Primarily, it must be said, Montgomery Burns - An inspired comedy creation.What will happen to the Simpsons?  Everyone has some point to conjecture, but the facts are that it has now overtaken The Flintstones as the longest running TV cartoon and unless Dan Castellano outprices himself from the series, it should continue into the future.  One by one we will stop watching it, and in the days to come of 'Futurama' the Simpsons will be showing on Channel 57 in the middle of the night watched only by the unemployed and alcoholic.But hey, that accounts for me, see you there!

I remember reading one comment on The Simpsons that kept calling it "dumb" and that it ripped off material Family Guy. I wish people would be more specific in describing something as "dumb". As for it ripping off Family Guy, that's just silly. The Simpsons began as a revolutionary "real life" example of what American families are actually like. Iconic. No other show quite like it. If I could only take one show to a desert island it would probably be The Simpsons.Writing a review for a show like The Simpsons should be easy, but it's not. So here are the positives by the numbers:#1 The show is an uncontested classic. The longest running US show by far can't be too bad. That many Americans watching that long can't be wrong, esp. Considering how many other shows there are to choose from.#2 Plots contain consistent Christian messages. Despite what so many have said about the Simpsons being a godless show... it actually depicts hardworking God fearing folks and practical Faith without being too on the nose.#3 Episodes were better in the beginning, but are still going strong. Not every episode can be a winner and the ones that are, resemble masterpieces. But they still are only 22 minutes of tv and fit into the same framework as other episodes. But some episodes are rated twice as highly as others. Example: marge v the monorail, Lisa needs braces, homer's enemy.#4 Basic formula has inspired numerous imitation shows. As much as family guy has funny moments it is a parody of a parody. The Simpsons was meant to be a somewhat genuine show depicted a parody of American life, but so many other shows have copied the formula and essentially the animated sitcom genre was started. People only watch those because they first watched The Simpsons.#5 They can't help being somewhat off-putting with the yellow skin. I refused to watch for years simply because the yellow skin was to bizarre. But the animators did that for some reason. Just watch, it's a good show. Don't let the skin tone put you off.Season 4 is wonderful tv from start to finish!

How can a TV show in this day and age - a cartoon nonetheless - be so wickedly sarcastic, politically taut, culturally accurate, and gut-burstingly humorous?  "The Simpsons" accomplishes all of those feats. Despite its mainstream success (although Bartmania faded in the early 90's) it has a strong underground following as well.  My friends and I could probably recite lines from any episode...and frequently do.  The guest stars are great, the writing perfect, and the show outstanding.  I am positive that decades from now, it will be regarded as a cultural marker of what America was like in the days of otherwise mindless programming.

The Simpsons is by far the best animated comedy series I have ever seen. It is about the Simpsons family of Springfield; however, it is never stated where Springfield is located. Enter the Simpsons family, Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa, and Maggie.Homer Simpson is the basic idea of the American dad: an overweight slob that's a little slow-minded. Homer works at the local power plant and though he is fired several times, he keeps coming back. His catchphrase ("Do'h!") has even been added to the English dictionary. Homer also loves Duff Beer and is often seen at Moe's Tavern.Marge Simpson is the run-of-the-mill mother. She cooks, she cleans, she runs errands. She loves Homer even with all his faults and she has mothered three children with him. Marge is most famous for her blue hair that's almost as tall as she is.Bart Simpson (mistakenly called "Brat" by Homer's boss) is the average ten year old boy. He gets into trouble, and is basically the young version of Homer, except with two alterations: he has hair, which is spiked on top of his square head, and he does not have the same weight issue Homer has. He likes skateboarding and also calls his father Homer instead of Dad, Daddy, or Father.Lisa Simpson is the smartest one in the Simpson family. She is eight and plays the saxophone. She has hair that is spiked like a starfish, and see is amazingly smart for her age. In fact, she even has more wisdom than her ape of a father! She always wears an orange dress along with matching shoes, yet she doesn't really care about her looks (minus the season four episode Lisa the Beauty Queen).And let's not forget Maggie. Maggie is Marge and Homer's youngest child. She is an infant and always has a pacifier in her mouth. She spoke once in the entire series, yet no one heard her, except the show's audience. Maggie wears an over-sized blue garment, which might be what makes her trip and fall flat on her face. Every once in a while, at random times, Maggie makes a sucking noise from having her pacifier in her mouth.While people say that after a few seasons this show got old, I disagree and love it 100%. Let's hope that Matt Groening, Simpson's creator, continues on for a little longer, until everyone on the planet is screaming, "ENOUGH ALREADY!!"

It almost seems unnecessary for me to comment on "The Simpsons," considering the tremendous amount of well-deserved praise everyone is giving it, and always has been. It is simply a wonderful show, and even "Worst Episode Ever," (which really was the worst episode ever) was worth watching. You can never tire of "The Simpsons." One of the best things about it is how you can watch every episode again and again, and always notice something that you previously missed.The characters on "The Simpsons" are such interesting people, and even the smallest characters catch your attention. There aren't enough shows where small, unimportant characters can keep returning when you least expect it. This is a wonderful thing about "The Simpsons." There are so many great supporting characters: Apu Nahasapeemapetilon, Comic Book Guy, Kent Brockman, Chief Wiggum, Mr. Burns, Smithers, Reverend Lovejoy, Troy McClure, and so many others. The guest stars on "The Simpsons" are also hilariously written and voiced.The thing that really makes "The Simpsons" an extraordinary show is tremendous amount of wit, sarcasm, jokes, and pop culture references that fill every episode to the top. I recall an episode that was entirely devoted to the short-lived 1967 television series "The Prisoner." I felt lucky that I was one of few people that could really understand and find the humor in that episode. That is what makes "The Simpsons" the best television show on the air today.

I've been watching The Simpsons since it debuted in 1989 when I was 12. Now I'm 25. And I only have one question: How can anyone NOT love this show? It is smart, creative and insightful. Seeing the first season again reminds me how much I love the newest episodes because of the chance to enjoy the development of the characters and style of the show.I've seen quite a few comments on this board about "why does Fox keep this show on the air?" I'll tell you: it is the highest ranked Fox show in the Neilsen ratings -- in it's 14th season!! Why would they cancel their highest rated show?! And why is it still pulling in the ratings? Because it is still hilarious. Not every episode makes every person laugh, but that's because the content of the show is so varied. And I find that over time an episode that you may not have originally liked begins to grow on you.
But on average, this show has more silly, harmless fun than anything else I've seen. It keeps you laughing and can make you think. Well worth watching.

Being 17 years old, and having grown up watching the Simpsons, it sort of breaks my heart to read these constant Simpsons bashing threads. I'll be the 1st to admit, the show is not nearly what it used to be. The Simpsons lost something a long time ago, an element I cannot exactly pin-point. Watching recent episodes, and thinking back to the ones I grew up loving (Timmy O'Toole, Homer in love w/ Mindy Simmons, The monorail, Kamp Krusty, just to name a few) its seems like 2 diffrent shows to me. Even though the new ones are still funny, I dont like them nearly as much as the ones made in The Simpsons's heyday (probably 90'-98', or something).In my opinion, Simpsons fans have every right in the world to be upset w/ recent episodes, but should also keep in mind how great the show USED to be. The Simpsons was a ground breaking show that pushed the limits of what was acceptable on TV at the time. The show itself was a pop culture icon, and was consided quite edgie(even though such shows as Family guy, or South park now make those ground breaking shows look like the smurffs). Even though I was very young, I still remember schools across the country banning simpsons shirts.The Simpsons is (to me) like an old family dog. Sure, its not as fun as it used to be, and may be a bit stale, but that doesnt mean you should go tie him to a tree and shoot him. The Simpsons deserves respect for being the great show that it used to be. If you dont like the new episodes, dont watch them.  Remember The Simpsons , not as the show that YOU outgrew, but the show that may have outgrown YOU.

This show started off being funny, but now it is amazing. The way they've moved it on from a childrens show, using Bart as a typical cliche boy, to a hugely funny show that many adults enjoy is fasinating. Bart has matured so much and so has Homer whilst Lisa and Bart now often join forces making the so much more unique and leading to much funnier situations. Homer is now not simply a stupid, fat, middle-aged man but a person that everyone can relate to and laugh at aswell as empathising with. Sure not everyone is fat and Lazy but there is something about him that makes everyone love him. The shows to are so much better now, funnier, more mature and well just so much better it's hard to describe! When an "old one" is on Tv me and my sister spend the whole thing thinking how much it has improved, everything from the voices, to the charctors, to the story lines and to the jokes is so much better now and I can't see how anyone could dissagree with this show being absolutely amazing.

Over 24 years of air-time and more than 500 episodes. The feat this show has achieved is unmatched. The Simpsons is the longest running animated TV show and longest running prime time TV show. It has won 115 awards and been nominated for a further 150. The show has received so much praise, being named as the greatest TV show ever. The influence this has had on other TV programmes has been incredible. Animated shows once considered dead was single handedly revived by The Simpsons. Its unmatched success also carved a niche for adult "cartoons", leading to other great shows such as South Park, Futurama (created by Simpsons creator Matt Groening) and Family Guy.I began to fully watch The Simpsons 5 years ago and i have seen every single episode, most of them probably two or three times. I watched it a few times as a kid, many years ago, and played several games but never understood the sheer genius of the show, until one day i flicked through the channels and Bart the Daredevil was on, seeing Homer fall down the ravine twice, i laughed so hard and was instantly hooked to watch another episode. The Simpsons also generated my interest in animated programming, which is literally all i watch today and i'm currently studying.The are so many reasons to watch The Simpsons, wacko larger than life characters, the pop culture references to everything including music, books, TV shows and mostly films. The parodying of nearly everything. So many celebrities have made an appearance or given their voice, which gives it the record for the most guest appearances. There are hidden references and messages in every episode, some that may be only be seen after watching one episode 5 times. Every character has a gag, a catchphrase and a background story, which many shows and animated programs do not. In each season there's a clip show special, three part anthology episode and of course the great Treehouse of Horror series, which has influenced many other shows to make their own anthology specials. Having been running for 24 years straight you would expect that there would be a decline in quality, which many people have criticized. Fans have been noting that there's been a decline in humor since season 9/10. I think it started when Seymour Skinner was shown to be a fake. Many fans have abandoned the show since the early 2000's. Being a long time fan i think it was still funny until mid season 22 but since the end of season 23 the show has begun a sharp rise again in humor, writing quality and touching moments that have not been seen since the earlier seasons.Main Characters include: Homer - the father of The Simpsons, the most beloved TV character, is the overweight lazy slob meant to represent the average labour worker in America. He is known to say D'0h, (which even made it into the English dictionary), after doing something stupid which he is always doing.Marge - the housewife who keeps the family together, usually supported by Lisa in stopping Homer and Bart in their crazy schemes, which can be annoying at times. She represents the typical American mother and wife. Her laugh is her so funny and annoying. Bart - Originally the Simpsons was all about Bart in the first few seasons, but Homer became more popular and more episodes began to feature about him. However Bartmania still rules. A notorious prankster, who's doing all sorts of crazy stuff, Bart is an extremely fun character that any kid can relate to. Bart has so many catchphrases such "Ay Caramba", which also made it in the dictionary, "Eat my shorts", "I'm Bart Simpson who the hell are you". Bart's recurring gag is causing trouble for Homer and prank calling Moe in the early seasons.Lisa - An 8 year old highly intelligent kid, who loves to play the saxophone, is always rebelling against the town. She is also convert to Buddhism despite only being 8. In the early seasons she was more fun character, supporting Bart in his pranks but sadly over time she has become serious, unpopular and in my opinion extremely annoying and selfish. Maggie Simpson - Don't let the child fool you. Famous for shooting Mr Burns, she has also saved homer's life on more than one occasion.There are so many more great characters that started as background/supporting characters, who have gone on to become major characters, some even having the whole episode devout to them such as Willie, Chief Wiggum, Mr Burns, Nelson and Ned Flanders.The Simpsons is no longer a cartoon it's a philosophy - BBC.
I love it! It's fun and makes you laugh. Yet It's not too violent.

Every once and a while, a brilliant and trancendant show comes along, something that puts all of the prosaic and painfully ordinary claptrap in its place, and more often than not, shows like that are cancelled. I know what I'm talking about here, I had to sit by and watch 'Action,' one of the best new shows of the past 5 years, get cancelled while the over-rated and preachy 'Will & Grace' was allowed to survive. 'The Critic' died fast, and I had to watch my beloved 'Sliders' deteriorate into second rate abysmal junk after 3 seasons. This brings us to 'The Simpsons,' a smart and insightful show that was somehow allowed to live, to grow, and, after a rocky first season, to become the greatest show on television. Creator Matt Groening cranked out biting social commentary and domestic satire on a weekly basis, and all was well with the world. Seasons two through nine were perfect in every way.The show was always a cut above the rest, and then season ten came along, and the show dropped a few notches, still great, but faltering (the focusyn episode rates as one of the worst television episodes ever broadcast). Every once and a while, it would achieve the same level of quality that it had once delivered on a regular basis (the perfect game episode, the guest star episodes with Parker Posey and Mel Gibson, and of course, Behind the Laughter). However, I still had to face the facts, after eight years of delivering top notch entertainment, my beloved 'Simpsons' was becoming mediocre. By the end of season ten, and with Matt Groening's rookie series, 'Futurama,' doing better episodes than it on an almost regular basis, it had almost dropped to the level of 'The Drew Carey Show,' which, although it is another favourite of mine, is no 'Simpsons.' Just when I thought it couldn't get any worse, enter season eleven, which started off promisingly with a good Halloween special and the Who episode, but has quickly faded into even greater mediocrity than season ten.Don't get me wrong, I still like the show, it isn't bad, all you have to do is compare it to 'Dharma & Greg' to see that, but its becoming painfully average. Watching it now, I get the feeling of watching a beloved family member die. I grew up with 'The Simpsons' and now its falling apart, the scathing satire, the beautifully crafted wit, its all melting away now, and I'm sad to say, I hope for cancellation to come soon, for the shows sake and my own.

Living in Norway, we don't get that many american show on TV.  Sure, we have Frasier and Ally McBeal, but we don't even get SNL !!  It is nearly impossible to find out what channel Conan O'Brian and David Letterman is on. The Simpsons on the other hand, started off poorly on a small norwegian channel broadcasting from England. But, suddenly the series exploded. What at first glance looke like a poorly animated kid's show, is actually the most humorous TV Show out there.My favorite has to be Chief Wiggum.  Once my father(who is a police officer) had a meeting at home with about 8 other officers, when they were done I was allowed to watch Simpsons. This particular episode highly portrayed Chief Wiggum, what can I say, all the police-officers loved it, they laughed so loud people heard us through the entire neighbourhood. (And this is in the norwegian countryside).There you have it.Prepare to be Offended !

The Simpsons is unparalleled in its ability to hold up for ridicule human institutions and is witty and clever in satirising human behaviour. The Simpsons mocks with very effective satirical devices the police force, the government officials and makes hilarious usage of stereotypes.
One of my favourite Simpsons techniques is the way that often a character will look to intend to do one thing and then contradict themselves, or criticise some other character and then suddenly do the same thing wrong the other character was doing. Eg: When Moe is watching the wall in the tavern and then Homer says to Moe "Can I watch to?" Moe replies "yeah but it'll cost ya". Homer runs off to get money and then Moe says "He's so stupid and now back to the wall". Moe is stupid himself as he is leaving the tavern vulnerable to theft with his back turned.The Simpsons also does and excellent job in parodying musicals. I really enjoyed the send up of Mary Poppins with 'Shary Bobbins' the parody of her. The songs 'Cut every Corner' and 'Minimum Wage Nanny' do not put down the musicals, they merely place a humorous twist and new flavour on it.Finally, without The Simpsons many adults would turn away from cartoons. The Simpsons is useful in showing us "The dysfunctional family". Many families are not necessarily well-oiled machines. This is good because it contrasts to other T.V. families like "The Brady Bunch" and "The Partridge Family". These families were unrealistically always happy and well functioned. You should watch Simpsons whenever you get the chance because its simply unparalleled as a hilarious, satirical and animation masterpiece!

Little can be said about the Simpsons in 1,000 words or less, and that fact alone says a great deal about the longest running sitcom on television.  Academic books have been written about the Simpsons, and its longevity and success in both production and syndication speak to its quality as a series.  Since most readers are already familiar with the Simpsons, I will address my remarks to the newcomer.  The Simpsons is an animated series about a dysfunctional family and the dysfunctional town in which they live.  It is at times satirical, analytical, heartwarming, downright silly, and everything in between.  This is because the Simpsons has changed a great deal over the course of its long run (14th season as of this writing).  In the beginning, Simpsons episodes were more down- to-earth; great detail was given to even minute aspects of the show, and in general each episode made a subtle point about American family life.  As the seasons progressed and the writers experimented more with the freedom animation allows, the episodes became less like real life, but were then able to make points and generate humor in ways viewers had not seen before. Recent seasons of the Simpsons have presented episodes that have more emphasis on humor and satire, and less on the small details (both in animation and story layout) that made earlier seasons so different from traditional cartoons.  Some people believe that Homer, Marge, Lisa, Bart, and Maggie have served their purposes and need to retire to syndication for good, but I for one think they have a few good years left.
The Simpsons is a classic of classics, a pity that it has declined in quality and humor.

My favourite episode is probably Revenge Is A Dish Best Served Three Times. This is a great, funny cartoon.

The Simpsons is my favorite television program of all time (And Frasier). The animated sitcom is witty, and incredibly brilliant. Sure, it is no longer in it's climax, but it is still the most entertaining program, made up of interesting and humorous storylines, clever jokes, some cool guest-stars (Although many of them are annoying, I enjoyed the guest-star appearances of Kelsey Grammer and David Hyde Pierce), and one of the best elements of all: parodies! If it weren't for the Simpsons spoofs on classic movies, I may not have been introduced to such marvelous films as Cape Fear, An Officer and a Gentleman, The Night of the Hunter, and Cat on a Hot Tin Roof. So, yes, you people who dislike the show nowadays do make some good points, but I believe it is still a great animated sitcom, definately worth it's acclaim and glory. As Mr. Burns would say, "EXCELLENT".

The Simpsons is the best television show ever made. Seasons 2-7 (and some of 8-10) have produced some of the defining moments on television history. Last Exit To Springfield (the one where the plant goes on strike) is hands down the best television program EVER in the history of television. In fact, Seasons 2-7 are perfect except for a few blunders.Unfortunately, in recent years, the show has declined in quality. It started at the very end of Season Seven with Homerpalooza, the worst episode of the Simpsons ever. It was a grim vision of things to come. Season Eight was OK (it did have the second best episode ever, The Springfield Files), but it lacked the quality of past seasons. Season Nine was a huge disappointment with some real clunkers (Principal And The Pauper, the one where Principal Skinner is found to be a fraud), miserable writing and no really great episodes. Needless to say, my hopes weren't that high for Season Ten.Season Ten was a bit like Season One. The show's popularity was at an all-time high, but the episodes were pretty bad (although most point out that Season One was a foundation of sorts to the Simpsons, which is definitely true.). Season Ten was embarrassingly awful. Most of the episodes were absent of any magic that embraced the earlier episodes, and most importantly, dumped satire for pop culture references. All of the characters are now fully developed, and there's nothing much else to do except retread, which can be pretty painful.I therefore say that Season 11 will most likely be the last season. And it should be. The Simpsons are done, the show has finished developing. It's pointless to continue to produce such crap and tarnish such an incredible series.Before I close, I'd like to say that even though Season Ten was horrible, I still look forward to watching the Simpsons as much as I can. If you watch a bad episode enough, it'll either grow on you and you'll stop hating it. Sometimes, you watch it a lot, and you still hate it. But at least this show is so dense and deep that you can argue about the best and worst episodes. You can't do that watching any other show (except maybe Star Trek, All In The Family and Frasier).

The Simpsons, at first, started out quite well. It was enjoyable to watch, and added some clever humor at times. It also had characters that had distinct personalities that you could get to know. Now, it is time for The Simpsons to be put to rest. The first couple of seasons were good, then it started to degrade into cheap slapstick humor, and totally impossible situations. The characters have all changed too, and are not as good as they used to be. It seemed before, that the episodes had some sort of resolve to them. Now, it had sunken to the phase of random insanity, where the episodes make little or no sense. It is truly time, for this show to die, and for the developers to move on to better things.

Hey, im a simpson fan at the age of 17. This masterpiece started when i was three, but that had not stopped me from watching the first few seasons. I, like any simpson fan, have the 1st season on dvd and some books about the simpsons, a guide if you will towards mastering the psyche of every character in this tale of one city. I know that after watching an episode, i not only laugh, but the show makes you think about events in history, and thoughts on what will happen.Let's all face the facts. The Simpsons has been running for a tremendous amount of time, entertaining a variety of age groups and re-kindling lost cultures. Many people liked the first seven seasons of it, and hated the 8th.The best episode in my opinion in the 8th season was entitled "Burns, Baby Burns". The guest star was Rodney Dangerfield, who played Burns' son. This episode had quite possibly the best ending in any Simpson episode. It was in front of the "Aztec Theatre", and Rodney's character was pleading for his father's love in front of everyone in Springfield, but the cold-hearted Burns refused. Rodney quickly threw an impromptu street party; The song being played? None other than the same song being blasted from Dangerfield's golf-bag in the film "Caddyshack"; Journey's "Any Way You Want It"Some people say that too many celebrities are used in the show playing themselves and should play random characters in an episode. The fact is, hardly anyone's voice would be recognized if their name would not appear while the credits are rolling. They've tried it with the obvious Kelsey Grammer playing "Sideshow Bob" and they did a very nice job having "Cecil", Bob's brother, be played by David Hyde Pierce; who if you don't recognize, plays Grammer's brother in the television series "Frasier". These voices are familiar to most Americans. And the fact is, like some lucky americans, they meet a celebrity here and there. I have met a very funny celebrity named Jim Breuer, who lives in my hometown.When will this masterpiece come to an end? Hopefully never. But sadly all good things must come to an end. When the show finally gets cancelled, im sure America will not react the same when "Seinfeld" stopped playing new shows, but it will affect alot of people. I hope that the simpsons remain on the air on some television station. A creation so remarkable must. I do know that the Simpsons now have ten old episodes airing per week and one new episode. Please support the show. Fox has been great to this show. Look it up in your tv guide and put it on, i know you'll laugh and think after you watch an episode.

More intelligent than Family Guy, More child friendly and not as obvious as South Park and just plain funnier than King Of The Hill.And came before all of the above.Even in its 18th series its still probably the best animation on TV and still up there with the funniest shows around.Its glory days were season 4 to 8, every episode was genius and the way the characters have evolved since the early days is amazing.As people have said it works on so many levels, I can sit in a room with kids who laugh at the visual jokes, myself (23) and my extended family of all ages who all find something in the show.It did trail off somewhere pretty badly in the early 2000's but I do think the last series of so is a bit of a return to form.For the best though I recommend series 4,5 and 8. The Simpsons has been on the air since 1989.  It pokes fun at everything and everyone, including itself.  The episodes work well on many different levels of humor and each time you watch you'll probably notice something new or some detail you missed before.  That's part of the reason the Simpsons do so well in syndication.The characters have changed over the years and new ones have been added, but the general feel of the Simpsons hasn't changed. Satirical humor at its best, no one is safe from their comedic gaze. The Simpsons has become the longest running television comedy and I for one still find the new episodes to be hilarious. Sure, some things have been done a bit much, but the great part is, the writers know that and at least acknowledge it before they milk a certain plot some more.Kudos to you Simpsons!

I know some people think it's fashionable to say that the Simpsons has "lost it". Lost what? Has anyone actually tried watching some of the episodes from the earlier seasons? Those episodes are so inferior to the later ones (and I am not referring to animation/technical issues here, but everything) that I can't really believe I enjoyed them when they were on the air. On the other hand I was something like 12 years old or so when the very first episodes (dis)graced the TV-screen. Recent episodes have lost the miserable sentimentality which all of us already get far too much of from any lousy sit-com, and are now all about satire, which is just the way it should be. Come to think of it "recent" might be the wrong term - the show gained momentum somewhere around season 5, and hasn't really lost it since (apart from some relapses into sugarcoated BS, particularly in episodes featuring much of Lisa). Apart from Family Guy, which cannot be beaten even by the original, this is by far the best show to ever come out of the US. All categories included.

For eight seasons, the Simpsons was the greatest show ever. It had hilarious writing, colorful amiation, lovable characters, and a life-time supply of brilliant one-liners. What also amazes me about the show is how consistent it was in it's prime. Some of the episodes stood out more than others, sure (Rosebud, Last Exit to Springfield, Homer at the Bat) but each one was great in its own way. Also, the show depicted a flawed but loving family who always survived in the end. This was a refreshing change from sitcoms that showed families who were perfect and never had any problems. This show also looked at serious issues like alcoholism, religious fundamentalism, feminism, etc. The show had so many memorable moments its hard to write them all down. But who could forget Sideshow Bob singing the HMS Pinafore at Bart's request, or Homer's ''Land of Chocalate Fantasy after Mr. Burns sells the nuclear plant to Germans. Unfortunately, after season 9, the show began to slip. The animation became less inspired and the jokes got stale. The writers began to rely more on celebrity guest appearances than clever writing and sight gags. Its a shame, really, but thanks to DVD we can still enjoy the show during it's glory days.

Why do I feel the need to post the 200th review in the 25th season of a show that's almost universally known? Because it's a show that defined an era. Has it declined in quality? Yes, but that's normal. Everything has a golden age before slowly cracking and crumbling away. However, I don't believe the show is crumbling yet. It may have cracks, it isn't perfect (you show me a show that is), but it's trying. There have been massive failures like Lisa Goes Gaga *shudder*, but also massive successes. However, people tend to focus only on the negative, that's just human behavior, and refuse to see some of the episodes for the comedy gold they truly are. Have the newer episodes been a bit of a letdown? Unfortunately, yes. Still, I hold out hope that they will get a second wind and dominate Sunday night once again. If you're looking for a show to watch and are on the fence about this show, don't watch the newer episodes (season 20 and up), try to watch the earlier ones (seasons 1-10) and make the decision from there. I also believe there's a certain pressure to hate the new Simpsons episodes. Because the internet doesn't like it, you shouldn't either. But you have a mind, use it. Form your own opinion and if it makes you laugh, laugh away. I rate this a 9/10 simply because, like I said, it isn't perfect, but it's pretty darn close. Thank you for reading and I hope this helped you or was at least mildly entertaining :)

Although seasons 9 and 10 are greatly inferior to the previous 8 seasons, The Simpsons still ranks as a show that's incredibly funny and insightful for anyone who watches it.  Many TV critics praise the show as being "subversive satire."  They're all wrong; satire is but one of the many comedic styles used by the show; we also see subtle sight gags, pratfalling slapstick, character-based foibles, thinly veiled self-reference, fullblown parodies of movies like "It's a Mad Mad Mad Mad World," more subtle, obscure references, spoofs of trite TV and movie cliches; and so on.  The fact that the show is a cartoon lends many advantages, the biggest being the wide range of characters voiced by a small troupe of actors.  Over 60 residents of Springfield join the core family as recurring characters, from crochety, ancient nuclear-power tycoon Monty Burns, to ambulance-chasing attorney Lionel Hutz ("I've argued in front of every judge in the state.  Often as a lawyer.")  Another advantage of being a cartoon is that the adult voice actors bring to life a subcast of children who are as rich in character as the adults; Bart, for example, is well-known as a troublemaker, but his everpresent feelings of guilt and remorse set him apart from South Park's Cartman and the like.  Lisa is simply one of the deepest characters ever created for TV.  The quintessential Simpsons joke comes in the episode where Homer moonlights instructing people on how to have a successful marriage. When Homer starts telling tales of his sex life to his students, Marge justly gets angry and throws him out of the house.  In a scene near the end, Marge is driving through town, and she hears Homer's ghostly voice in her head: "Won't you marry me Marge?" "I'll be a daddy? Oh, that's wonderful!" "We'll always stay together.." and as the expression on Marge's face softens, we can see where this is going: she's going to forgive Homer, drive home, and make peace with him.  But instead, she turns her head around, and sees Homer in the back seat talking through a cardboard tube.  She throws him out and drives off, as angry with Homer as ever.  We were set to believe this was to be the touching climax, then we're thrown a total curve (and are left wondering how Marge mistook Homer speaking out loud for her own memories!)  Of late, the show has started to center around Homer getting into wild adventures, but this still can't tarnish the legacy of the Simpsons. Ignore formulaic, restrictive sitcoms like Seinfeld and Friends. This is THE defining TV show of the 90's.

The more recent episodes (200th was so disappointing), I do not feel are as good as they were in the late eighties/early nineties.  I had watched it almost every week since I was seven(in 1989)years old, however, since around 1995, it has slowly lost a lot of humor and characters seem to have taken different identities. For example, Lisa used to be presented as an innocent, childlike, though intelligent little girl. She loved ponies (remember the Christmas list?)and The "Happy Little Elves"(from the Babysitter Bandit episode).  She refused to watch stolen cable "Sorry, I'd rather go to heaven!", but now an eight year old knows what sodomy means? Then there's Homer. He was silly and dense.  He obviously wasn't very smart and he knew it. He loved his family but felt inferior because he knew they weren't perfect. "Be normal! Be NORMAL!!"  I remember a time when he brought the family into the dining room(instead of in front of the TV) to eat. He was just a silly old guy and now he's terribly annoying.  He had a dream in which God spoke to him, and several years later he said how he liked God because he's his "favorite fictional character." Marge has always seemed like a moral person. She didn't want the Casino put up, she wanted to fix main street instead of buy a monorail, and she opposed Homer skipping church.  Now wanting to get rid of the burlesque house makes her an annoying person(how did she look after the Spring in Springfield song?" Sideshow Bob was being dragged away after one of his first or second schemes had failed(before '92), and yelled that he would be out of jail when the democrats were back.  A few years later he ran as a rep. for mayor.  Did he change? Now the famous Bart- He's not a bad kid but he was presented in a sort of Dennis the Mennace kind of way, a mischevious little boy with little boy problems;trying to pass 4th grade, getting a crush on a girl, melting little plastic army men with a magnifying glass- I don't think his character is as developed in that way anymore. I say it used to be an 8.5 but more recently has gone to 6.5. Good episodes- War on Nelson, 1st/2nd Halloween Special, Stolen Cable, Genius Bart, Babysitter Bandit, Bigfoot Homer, Bart Gets an F, Catfish Lake, Lisa's Birthday.We the purple?  What the hell was that? -Father to son on his essay topic, "Lisa in Washington"

"The Simpsons" had five-and-a-half seasons of near-perfect episodes from the beginning of the 1990-1991 season to the middle of the 1995-1996 season, and it was a little depressing to see the show come down from that high, but the slide was inevitable.  You can't sustain intelligent, multi-layered, laugh-out-loud brilliance like that forever, and I was astounded to see the writers and producers keep the momentum going as long as they did. It's a different show now than it used to be, with a bigger emphasis on Homer's wacky adventures rather than the entire family's dysfunction (call me a sap, but I miss the tenderness of episodes like "Lisa's Substitute," "When Flanders Failed" and "Sweet Seymour Skinner's Baadasssss Song"), but it's still consistently funny.  Many of us have grown up watching "The Simpsons" in awe and therefore feel very protective of it and defensive about which seasons are best.  It's understandable since the show has been so terrific for so many years and has given all of us lasting memories of well-earned laughter.  This show has had such a strange history, starting off with a huge merchandising push and media blitz in 1990, which led to some of the first 13 episodes landing in the Top 20 of the Nielsen ratings.  I think most of the fans would agree that the first half-season doesn't provide many laughs these days, but it's interesting to watch these episodes now and see the blueprint for future greatness.  By the fall of 1990, as "The Simpsons" entered its first full season opposite "The Cosby Show" on Thursday nights, the media hype died down and the ratings fell.  And then a wonderful thing happened: the show became a work of art.  The writers realized that repeating Bart's catchphrases each week wasn't going to satisfy them creatively, so they opened up the show to the vast realm of comedic and animated possibilities.  Even though the show is wackier now than it used to be, it has always operated on dream logic.  Unlike "King of the Hill," which I also love, "The Simpsons" has never tried to be realistic.  It takes full advantage of its cartoon status, and that's one of the main reasons why it's so rewarding.  It also features the greatest running commentary about the love-it-or-hate-it medium of TV that I've ever seen (although "SCTV" and "Late Night with David Letterman" came close).  And no other show that I've seen has featured so many memorable and endearing supporting characters; we could all rattle off about 50 names.  Simply put, "The Simpsons" is the funniest TV show any of us will ever see.

Everybody knows The Simpsons is an extraordinary accomplishment. I don't really need to elaborate on the finesse and universality it meticulously speaks to... the fact that it can be the subject of University courses, and yet still be watched with as much enthusiasm by a third grader, or the guy who owns the Pizza shop (and stay on for so long!), is a television triumph.What I would like to speak about, because it matters a great deal to me, are all the dramatic complaints about the 'dip in quality', which is a perfectly legitimate argument. What it comes down to is this though - does it make your life better to bash it, to watch it just to reaffirm how much you hate it? Are you really giving it a fair chance with those glasses on? Are you becoming Comic Book Guy, or are you staying real about this? That's not to say get a frontal lobotomy as you walk through life, but rather, to be strong enough to see the world and all its facets with an inclusive optimistic spirit. We owe it to ourselves, and we owe it to the world. That's the only way to create a life that's beautiful.When one sits down and watches an episode just to nag, they're always finding reasons in which they're 'right', but they never go away feeling very good for being right. Being 'right' is also being selfish - its a complicated human foible, but by being conscious of it, we can notice it when it creeps into our day to hold us down. Live for possibility, not for destructive things you think are there and reaffirm are there.I haven't been perfect at this state of mind while watching The Simpsons, or anything, but that's hardly the point. Its always a process. The point is, I've worked at doing the mature thing, which is actually GIVING IT A CHANCE! And believe it or not, I LOVE EPISODES FROM THROUGHOUT THE WHOLE SERIES! And I'm grateful for that. There's a definite shift in style and content, and yes, at times I feel its devoid of conscience, but its also a choice to be bitchy, just as its a choice to complain and tolerate - either get out or get in, the fence always hurts! I've decided I'm gonna still see whats great about it, and perhaps even write for it one day. Either way, I'm gonna let myself win by still loving it! Just a few later season recommendations (seasons 15-23): Girls Just Want To Have Sums, Marge Vs. SSCCATAGAP, I (Annoyed Grunt)-Bot, Eternal Moonshine Of The Simpson Mind, The Haw-Hawed Couple, Simple Simpson, Fat Man And Little Boy, The Heartbroke Kid, The Seemingly Never-Ending Story, The Monkey Suit, Jazzy & The Pussycats, Ice Cream Of Margie, 24 Minutes, That 90's Show, The Debarted, Dial N-For Nerder, All About Lisa, Husbands And Knives, Mypods And Boomsticks, How The Test Was Won, Gone Maggie Gone, Coming To Homerica, Homer The Whopper, Bart Gets A Z, O Brother Where Bart Thou, Once Upon A Time In Springfield, Boy Meets Curl, Postcards From The Wedge, Stealing First Base, The Bob Next Door, The Italian Bob, Elementary School Musical, The Scorpions Tale, Homer Scissorhands, The Fight Before Christmas, How Munched Is That Birdie In The Window, Loan-a-Lisa, The Book Job, Holidays Of Future Passed, The President Wore Pearls, The Way We Weren't, Future-Drama...I'm excited to see where it goes, and I'm happy whenever it ends, however it ends. My happiness doesn't depend on anything but my choice to let it be present in my life. And yes, if you're wondering, I love Lisa the most :)

I think what makes the Simpson's so entertaining is the way it constantly forces us to look in the mirror and laugh at ourselves as a society and as individuals. It is politically IN-correct in this ridiculously politically correct world. It often brings into the open people's true motives and what people really think, something rare in our pretensious society.What's amazing is the that as funny and entertaining as the Simpsons family are, Groening has surrounded them with a cast of dozens that are all amazingly and equally real and funny. From Apu to Otto to Chief Wiggum to Smithers to Dr. Hibbert to Skinard, and so on and so on, they are all hilarious and identifiable. I would venture to say that I could watch an entire episode WITHOUT the Simpson family included and it would still be just as good. I've never seen anything like it on another TV series.It's sad that so many don't "get" the simpsons. They either don't get the humor, don't give it a chance, or think it's a kid show. The latter especially are sadly mistaken. This may be a cartoon, but it's hardly a kid show. In fact, my opinion is that the more knowledgable/intelligent you are, the more you will enjoy this show.the bottom line is it's the best 30 minute TV show ever created, hands down. I challenge anyone to say different.
